It was that bad that I wont go back.  There are plenty of restaurants in SF.  I'll find one where the staff has some basic people skills.
author: Lisa R.

description: Went there last night to celebrate a friend's birthday and the food was so good we barely spoke. The tom kha soup was delicious and enough to share among 4. The green curry was also amazing. I wish I had more space for sticky rice!
author: Mariana S.

description: Here's the deal - if you like Americanized Thai food - as in you think everyone in Thailand just eats Phat Thai - this is not the place for you.  You will hate this place and be disappointed.  If you want legit Thai food like what is served when you visit Thailand, this is the place for you.  Grew up in Thailand and always struggled to find Thai food in the US until I started eating here in 2006 - amazing food, great service.
author: Tarun B.

description:
Stuff I heart:

Green Papaya Salad ='s looooooooooove.
Vegetarian Chive Cakes. (Rich little suckers...)
Tom Kha Gai. (This is my best friend when I'm sick).
Pumpkin Curry. (Spicy. Tender. Flavorful. Yum.)
Pad Thai. (Definitely award winning.)
Pad Kee Mao. (Ohsospicydelicious. Sizzle.)
Garlic Rice (Great flavor. I kinda like to eat it alone. Is that weird?)

This is the place I hit up before I go to the AMC 1000 Van Ness, or when I'm okay with tipping homeless people who "found" a parking spot for me.
author: Natasha P.

description: The only real shame about this place is the service is so bad because the Tom Yum is one of the best out here in the city. Every single time I've been there the waitresses have been ridiculously rude. I have to say the food is too good, some of the best thai food i've gotten out here. Just don't dine there.
author: Bantu Z.

description: I did not enjoy my meal. The pad thai was not flavorful. It is one of my favorite dishes and I order it all the time. I would have to say this was the worst I have ever tried. The Sai Oou (another favorite) was overcooked and too dry. The only highlight was the Sweet Sticky Rice with Homemade Egg Custard which was very good. I wouldn't go back.
author: Nate W.

description:
Overall good Thai food. There are better places but plenty worse too. The servers are friendly and overly accommodating which is a bit rare in Asian establishments as we normally value efficiency and table turns over long drawn out doting service. And the food still comes out fast!

They're open late and don't judge you when you're not the most sober....

I particularly like their duck curry, pineapple fried rice and Thai iced tea.
author: Mo P.

description:
My favorite Thai restaurant in the city. I order take out from here several times a month. My favorites are the Pad Siu, Red or Green Curry and basil chicken. 

The staff is always friendly and they are open late.
author: Christy Z.

description:
Spent a few weeks in beautiful Thailand and although I'm no expert in how authentic everything is, I can say everything is prepared deliciously. My favorites are: 
Homemade beef jerky with spicy sauce
Crispy fried pork with some sort of sweet orange sauce
Tom yum 
Basil chicken 
Papaya salad 

But to be honest everything is great. Def my favorite Thai spot in the city. Castro one is not as good though, still better than other joints.
author: Mila A.

description: Best Thai I've found in the city. Try the Khoa Soi.
author: Brian H.

description:
Came here for a friends birthday. 

We ordered the Pad Thai and Pa Kee Mow. Both extra spicy, and one mild; all ordered Thai Ice Teas and none of these plates lacked flavor. There was a celebration in my mouth on how much basil was put into my Pad Kee Mow. 

The Pad Thai was extra special because they added all the fixings and didn't miss the peanuts. 

The service was even great and never did I have to ask for anything once or twice and the location was better than most restaurants. WE found parking in no time on a sunny afternoon. 

Very much in love with this place!
author: Carmen D.

description: If you're wanting a quick Thai fix.  This is a great place to go.  The wait staff is attentive and nice.
author: Roman A.

description: I came here with a friend and had the Green Curry with Jasmine Rice. When asked how spicy I wanted it, I had opted for "very spicy". Needless to say, it was pretty darn spicy when I got it. From the outset, it seemed like the portions weren't that big, but it was good enough to fill me up regardless. Just be careful with how much rice to curry intake so you don't end up running out of one too quick. (More rice would've been nice but that costs extra). In the end, for SF, this is a pretty affordable place.
author: Anders C.

description:
impressive menu. you can go out of your comfort zone and order what you can't normally get from a thai place. i recommend dishes from "house favorite" list. 
don't ask for spicy if you're not ready. i've tried a few dishes here.

- chan pad poo : more or less like crab pad thai. the sauce was way off though. so i assume that they don't actually make good pad thai here. and i can tell that by their main picture on yelp. good pad thai doesn't look orange. it looks brown-ish from the tamarind sauce. 

- pad moo grob (fried pork belly) with specialty curry paste : solid. spicy. delicious. 

- pork leg stew on rice : the texture for the pork was right. and it's cooked right. but the sauce is too sweet. (my mom taught me as a kid not to order pork leg stew from a restaurant owned by a thai person as opposed to a chinese. "thai's recipe" is too sweet. i can't believe that this lesson proved to be useful years later... important life lesson from mom) 

oh they serve beer and wine too!
author: Te R.

description:
Love it.  Pad see ew was the best I've had.

Great for people watching.
author: Mrs F.

description: Still my favorite Thai in SF.  The usually boring pad see ew is amazing at Thai House Express.  I also love the kao soy.
author: Wakako U.

description: The food is excellent. It's a staple in my book & a place I can treat a friend too for a guaranteed impression. The space isn't anything exciting and it's located inside of the ghetto of Tenderloin but it's worth the Lyft! The only other complaint I have is that they have a single use bathroom for each sex. And each time I go, I'm waiting 10 minutes to use the bathroom.
author: Brandon G.

description: Not the best Thai food in the world.  In fact, not the best Thai in a four block radius, but the food is good.  Maybe a little too American, but they are fast, and normally will seat you within five minutes, and their deliveries are quick, hot, and correct.  So this is my backup Thai restaurant.  A solid B.
author: sean d.

description: Salmon green curry. Talk about a party in your mouth!
author: Ed L.

description:
The atmosphere was a little fancy but it was nice, can't really complain there.
The customer service was excellent they are very nice.
The food was superb it was refreshing to have actual mango in the mango curry and likewise for the pumpkin curry.
5/5
author: Bartolo E.

description:
I tried their noodle dish, rice dish, salad, the food is consistantly good.
Fast & efficient service.
author: Yoko S.

description:
I had delivery from here tonight, and was quite pleased. I ordered online and the website was really great, professional, slick -- highly recommended if only for ease of ordering!

My only complaint is that the "medium" spicy was spicier than I had hoped. I would have rated it as spicy level 4 out of 5, but the only choices were "mild, medium, or hot" on the website. I like spicy food but it was a little aggressively spicy for me to enjoy. Your taste may differ though.

I quite liked the "Sweet Sticky Rice with Homemade Egg Custard" I had for dessert; that was a nice surprise. Of course, it was extremely sweet -- typical for Thai dessert, but I would have liked it toned down a little.

My favorite part of the meal was a fried rice dish with chicken and some veggies: "Kao Pad Gang Khew". Really hit the spot; chicken was great, spices were nice, and the proportion of chicken/rice/veggies was right on.

The "Pad Prik King" with tofu and garlic rice on the side was ok, but that's the one where I found it to be too spicy.

P.S. The order came with a nicely printed note saying that the name has been changed to "House of Thai" but that the management is the same.
author: E S.

description:
I was so irritated that I had to register and write my first review on Yelp. I have been eating at this place since 2000-2001. Back then, I have been told that this place was one of the best and most authentic Thai restaurants in SF. I am Thai, and I would say that it used to be good in terms of food and service.


However, the taste and quality of food have completely gone down hill after new management. I still frequent there cuz I love the coziness and the service. 


This evening, I and my husband went there for dinner. He tried to order the food in Thai. Then, a very tiny waitress  with a very long hair gave us a rude attitude. She rolled her eyes, and looked at us from head to toe. We did not say anything at all cuz we were shocked what went wrong. We thought she may had a bad day or on period. It seemed she treated other caucasian customers very well.

The most important part was when she slammed the dishes on our table.  It was so loud and so rudeeeee. How rude could it be? My husband accidentally said something like B* word in Thai I taught him long time ago.

We knew that she understood what my husband said cuz  my comrade never ever came out and brought us food but other servers. Never said sorry either.


          


Lakorn T.H.E    




R.I.P My T.H.E
author: Ari C.

description: They lost a bit of our business when they scaled back their late night hours, but this place has always been solid.  The tom yum soup is delicious and spicy, just the thing after a few rounds at the local bars.  This neighborhood is bordering on sketch, so be careful of your surroundings late at night.  Walk a block or two from here away from Van Ness and it gets progressively worse.
author: Dave N.

description:
I'm not gonna lie...I can not walk this area alone without fear. But the asian food here is so good, damnit. Been to a few thai places, and this by far is the best. The food really does taste like mom's cooking! Thai hot tea is one of my favorites!

We had pad see ewe chicken and chinese sausage fried rice. Sketchy area, but worth it when the light is still out.
author: Lola D.

description:
Hands down, the BEST Tom Yum Noodle soup I've ever had in the city. 

And it's actually spicy, just like Thailand! (although you have to request that they make it "Thai" spicy lol)

Business was booming and the place was nearly packed when I walked in. I knew what I wanted, ordered right away and got it in less than 5 minutes. The wait staff was friendly all the way, despite the hectic rush.

Really glad I found this place, will definitely come back!

P.S. Like other reviewers have said, the "spicy" here is no fucking joke! definitely not OSHA lol.
author: Mike A.

description: Very traditional Thai food, very good & affordable
author: lee s.

description: THE is my favorite Thai restaurant in the 'loin. Their prices are fair and food is consistently good. One of my favorites is the tom yum noodle soup, which I usually get with flat rice noodle. Be careful with this dish though, because even when you order mild or medium, sometimes it comes out extremely spicy!
author: Al B.

description: I placed an order online for eat 24hours.com the food came really fast. I ordered the Ganag Dang beef rice place and  the Pad Pirk King. They gave me a generous amount. I only gave it 2 stars because the food was really bland with no flavor at all. I am not sure how this place got 4 stars maby their other dishes are better. I can definitely say that I have had better and won't be ordering from here again.
author: T W.

description: I had some wonderful green curry.  Was with a large party, but we were served quickly and no issues with any food.  Asked for peanut sauce on the side, and a large bowl to share was brought out (and it was really good)  Despite the middle of lunch, wasn't very busy at all.
author: Noah J.

description:
My new Thai take-out place!  Typically we get these items:

Red Curry with Pumpkin
Pad Thai
#39 - Pad Woon Sen (Silver Noodles)
#40 - Kao Ka Moo (Stewed Pork Leg)
Pineapple Fried Rice

The food is cheap and delicious!  They're also open late!  AWESOME!
author: H. L.

description:
I just had the 5 spice duck here...
It was really awful.  The meaty part of the duck was very tough, and the fat just jiggled next to it.  Ewww.  These two elements of the meat should meld into the most perfect poultry known to man.  This was just inedible.
author: Jannea T.

description:
I absolutely love Thai House. 
You can find me there once or twice a week.
Basically anything with silver or rice noodles is a must have. 
Their red curry is very good if you like spicy.
Service is good, very authentic. 
Its also rather affordable. 

Compared to other Thai like Osha, to me it seems more authentic and also a lot cheaper.
author: Sami B.

description: Delicious and cheap! Doesn't get better than that. Pad Thai is just the way it should be. I've tried several of their other dishes (mostly meat + rice dishes) and appetizers and have not been disappointed yet.
author: Kristina B.

description:
Alright, AWESOME pad thai. AWESOME yellow curry. AWESOME thai iced coffee.

With all the places you could go for Thai (that are within walking distance), you should stop and go to this one before the others because it's AWESOME for the price.

Go here.
author: Kate K.

description:
My go to Thai place in the neighborhood. I've been going here regularly for years and like every dish I've had there. Really fast and quick at lunch, but can get really busy at dinner time which will slow down the service. Take out is a great way to skip the line and the (reasonably) slower service during dinner when the house is packed. 

Their new weekend breakfast menu (7-10:30AM, Sat/Sun) isn't strictly Thai, but rather a mix of American, Mexican, and a little Thai. I had the pozole, which was delicious with a side order of sticky rice. The drip coffee was delicious. Strong, rich, and awesome, unexpectedly perhaps the best coffee aside from Philz. 

Careful with ordering dishes spicy, they're not kidding around with that. I love hot, spicy food but my meal was ruined because my balls were too big for my taste buds (totally my fault). Medium to Medium/Hot is the way to go in my book.
author: Andres G.

description: I got Thai'd up here yesterday and had some Pad Kee Mao for lunch. Of course, Marnee Thai makes my favorite version of this dish but I must have enjoyed Thai House Express' too since I cleaned my plate. However, I wish they had used less onions and tomatoes in place of bell peppers. Oh well, Phuket!
author: Suany W.

description:
Really good Thai. I come here for atmosphere and most Thai staples. The papaya salad is delicious -- very flavorful, and no holding back on the shrimp flavor. They do spicy just right. Just note their level of spicy starts on an Asian not Western level, so order medium or mild if you can't handle it.

My favorite dish is the Tom Yum soup with thin rice noodle. They really do it right here, and give this soup the kind of attention given to Vietnamese Pho. The broth, levels of flavor and garnishes are sublime. Order this dish when you're craving noodle soup on a crisp day. 

Their dried beef appetizer is also very good, as are the fish cakes. Steer clear of the chive dumpling -- pretty unexciting. And don't bother ordering Chinese style dishes on the menu, go for their specialties and Thai dishes. I've seen many Vietnamese and Thai restaurants add Chinese style dishes to their menus to appease the kind of customer that equates most Asian cuisines to Chinese food.

A good sign of a restaurant is checking out the patrons. Thai House has a good number of Asian customers mixed with in-the-know Westerners. The restaurant is stylish, clean and spacious, considering the busy Larkin & Geary corner. And if it matters, the bathrooms are always clean. 

Next to Sai Jai on O'Farrell, Thai House is my go-to Thai in this neighborhood. Don't bother with Chai-Yo on Polk, the food caters to a patron that always orders a thai iced tea & pad thai --- bland.
author: Antoi C.

description: Priced slightly higher than its competitors in the neighborhood, but I'm not sure if it's worth it. I've been there several times and yes, I would go back. The menu is vast, the service is friendly, the food is good, but it doesn't really stand out to me. If you're a Noodle Whore, like me, then don't order the noodle soups here. They fill it with bean sprouts, leaving me carb-deprived. I've ordered noodle soups on more than one occasion just to see if there's a difference. No, stingy noodles is their thing! I did enjoy their "larb" made with duck, which is an option I'm not used to having at other spots. My GF prefers their "Thai fried rice" because it's softer than other locations, but for me, it's another dish that didn't stand.
author: Helen L.

description:
I have been coming here for years but I'm finally taking a moment to wax poetic. . .

Tried the beef jerky for the first time -- salty beefy bliss!  I had to fight over it with my boyfriend because I didn't want to share. . .

I also think they make the best pad kee mao in San Francisco.   

The servers are fast, attentive and always indulgent of my request for a side of fish sauce with green chiles.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Freida N.

description:
I come here probable about twice a month...if the other Thai place I love is not open. 
Love the food: #89 Pla Muk Gra-Tiem, Roti and Thai Ice Tea. 
Opens late, so, that is very helpful.
Staff is friendly. Food is cooked fast, so you get yours right away.
author: Jo'an R.

description:
We were catching a movie last night and it was freezing so we wanted to find some food close by to warm us up.  We both agreed thai would be a good option for soup or curry so we found this place.  The place was cute and the service was decent, but the food was only ok.

My friend got the stewed pork noodle soup which she very much enjoyed.  I went with a pork red curry which is my go to dish when I get Thai food.  I thought it was only ok.  I thought it wasn't particularly fresh tasting and definitely wasn't spicy enough so I had to add lots of chili paste and ate lots of their pickled jalapenos.  SInce it already had the red pepper next to it on the menu, I didn't think I'd have to make it extra spicy.  It was a really good portion for the price, though and came with a big mound of rice.  I think I would be more likely to try a new Thai place before coming back here, though.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Thai House Express, though a few blocks further than we like to trek, has now become our "go-to" spot for decent-size portioned, tasty, and affordable Thai food. 

I've tried the Pad See Ew, Stewed Pork Shoulder over Rice, and Roasted Duck Noodle Soup. Each dish is the exact portion I need and very flavorful. I never leave overly stuffed and that makes my skinny jeans feel comfortable. I don't have to worry about super fatty duck where there's barely any meat, or burnt pad see ew;  the stewed pork shoulder is tender and forks off in shreds; delicious and a little fatty = just right; and of course, my wallet is happy. 

Service is friendly, and though it gets packed the wait never seems too long, or we do take-out instead. I like to try new dishes, and so far nothing has left me disappointed. That's a good restaurant in my book. Four solid stars for the restaurant, but no stars for the poopy smelling neighborhood.
author: Donna H.

description: Service is very fast. Food is decent. I had the green chicken curry, which I thought was overloaded with vegetables instead of actual chicken.
author: Moby K.

description:
A group of friends decided to come randomly. We had 12 people and no reservation, but the staff were very friendly and quickly pulled some tables together to seat all of us.

The food is pretty good. The green curry with chicken wasn't that spicy at all. I would've liked it more if it were more spicy. 
The fried banana dessert was really yummy. It was a little pricey for the portion, but it was good. 

Parking, on the other hand, can be pretty terrible, but it's not a surprise for SF. Be prepared to circle the block or park a couple blocks away. There's quite a few other dining places in the area, so be prepared to fight for a spot during rush hour meal times. 

Thai House Express is one of the better Thai places I've been to in SF.
author: Florence S.

description:
They're really not kidding about the express in the title. They mean it. After you order, your food will magically appear under your face in a matter of minutes. It's honestly quite impressive.

Not only is your food prepared magically fast, but it's also pretty good, and the selection is much larger than your typical Thai-fusion, Osha-esque selection of pad thai, pad see ew, various curries, etc. Sure, all of those dishes are there, but there is whole assortment of dishes that stretches beyond that limited set. We ordered an eggplant curry and a fried pork belly dish among others. Everything was delicious, but the fried pork belly and eggplant were particularly good. Just make sure you don't miss the special menu and do try to make the effort to explore.
author: Tian X.

description: The papaya salad is legit!  After spending time in Thailand, this has the spicy factor needed to make it delicious.  Spicy is burn your mouth spicy beware.  We also had the salmon curry and it was very good.  The salmon is cooked perfectly and melts in your mouth.  I am not a huge fan of eggplant and there is quite a bit in there.  We also had the Pad se ew and I'd say it was pretty normal, nothing that was too memorable but not bad quality.  Will def order again!
author: Megan H.

description: Order delivery to my hotel room through yelp. Super easy to order, was delivered within time estimate, food was super yummy and carefully packaged. Not a drop of the Thai ice tea was spilled during delivery. Chicken and potato curry, cucumber salad, and fried veggie rolls were delicious all delicious and meat . Delivery guy was super nice. Whole experience was great!!
author: Becky R.

description: Although the food was great it did take a little long to arrive which is why im giving this a 3 rating. I'll order again since the food was great and if it arrives a little quicker increase the rating.
author: Edward G.

description: Dont ever go to this place, they have the worst food, too much seasoning made my wife sick after eating. Lucky we didnt come back and complain. I swear they put heaps and heaps of seasoning in the food, not good for ur tummy. You guys can try but be warned.
author: Evy T.

description: These guys are simply the most consistently delicious Thai food around and with the decent prices, its am easy recurring visit. The Pad Thai is better the most other places , I'm fond of spicy Pad Kee Mow, but the real treat here is the Pork Leg Stew noodle soup. Especially around the Fall/Winter time, this meal in a bowl is perfection that took me about 8 visits before I found and tried it. Keep up the good work THE.
author: Gabriel T.

description:
Great Thai Food here.

Tastey Tastey! - when they say Hot, they mean HOT.
I absolutely love spicy foods but sometimes hot is just overwhelming the rest of the dish, this is one of those cases.
Stick to medium heat if you want to taste anything else! 

Great food, super cheap price - service is friendly and efficient.
Anytime I'm in the area, I'm stopping here!
author: Roger C.

description:
So far this is the best Thai we've had in the City!

We requested 'extra-spicy' on all dishes (the waitress suggested that we just add more spices, available at our table. To our delight, however, each came out spicy without having to add a thing. Our mouths were aglow):

- Pork Shoulder Stew (tender pork that forked off in shreds, rested on top of Chinese gye-lan veggies, unique pickled peppers, served with a garlicky vinegar for dipping). It was outstanding! Loved the combination of sweet and sour flavors. My mouth waters as I typed this out. 
- Pad Kee-Mao with prawns (stir fried wide noodles). Delicious flavor and quite colorful.
- Gang Kew-Wan with beef (green curry). Not as much flavor as we were hoping for. 
- 1 serving of rice.
- Attempting to keep it a bargain bite, we stayed with water for our drinks.

Total tab with tax, $30. Could have saved more by simplifying our order down to 2 dishes, would have been plenty.

+ + + HIGH-FIVE + + +
- Flavorful, generous, dishes.
- Food came out immediately and were piping hot.
- Excellent, friendly service. Our water glasses were filled often.
- A definite bargain bite. We had more food than we needed and left stuffed.

- - - - DING - - - -
- The T-loin location. Our table, next to the wall of windows, allowed for incredible views of the hookahs, homeless, and druggies strutting by :-o
author: Kimbalee W.

description:
im not usually a fan of anything with "express" in the title.  HOWEVER, this place has become my favorite for take out in the neighborhood.

favorites: pumpkin curry and pad see ew

and it probably goes without saying but its FAST.  thank god they have express in the title.
author: Christy C.

description:
So as a huge Thai food fan, and a huge delivery fan, I'm always looking for a good Thai place that delivers.  Thai House Express is all that and more.  My experience in ordering Thai food is that places fall into one of two categories: places that have just the basics (pad thai etc.) and places that have everything but (i.e. a ton of stuff you've never heard of).  Well THE has both.

To celebrate this, I ordered my perennial favorite, pad kee mao (which was damn good) as well as something I'd never had before, namely "golden bags" (which were even better).  My only complaint was that the delivery took over an hour, but on the plus side they said that when I ordered, so I didn't sit around wondering where my food was.  Anyways, long story short: order here.
author: Adam L.

description:
Great place for the real Thai tastes...my Thai friends take me here first every time
-fast and friendly service
-Yellow curry my favorite
author: brian w.

description: One of the best Thai place in the city that does a good job of every basic and special dish, nice staff and clean.
author: Jane B.

description:
My favorite Thai place in SF. This place was introduced to me by a Thai classmate in grad school. 

GOOD:
- The beef noodle soup is awesome. It is like a richer version of pho. Apparently this is a typical home style Thai dish and they make it well.
- The pad thai is really good too. I know this sounds like a lame choice but I think theirs is the best I've had in SF.
- Parking is pretty easy around here. I guess people are scared to park in this area.
- Food comes out super fast like a Chinese take-out restaurant.

BAD:
- The whole pompano fish entree is terrible. The fish has a small amount of meat for the price you pay for it. The meat is all dry and friend and not that great either.
- Surrounding area can be sketchy late at night. Heck, it is a bit sketchy during the day.
- Sometimes they make their dishes way too salty/sweet. It can be hit or miss but usually their food is good.

CONCLUSION: A great Thai place that is more authentic and cheaper than popular places like Osha.
author: Alex P.

description:
This restaurant serves great food. We had the pork leg stew, tom yum goong and the Thai house plum duck. The pork stew was delicious. It was slow-cooked and the meat was tender. The duck leg was cook just nice & crispy and the plum sauce is a great match to it. Their tom yum goong was mediocre though.

I have no idea why they called have the word "Express" in their name though. Service wasn't slow but it was not express. And yes, the thing that keeps me away from this restaurant the most is the neighborhood.
author: Handoyo S.

description:
I'll keep this one simple. I ordered take-out pork noodles with sticky rice. The flat noodles weren't over-greasy, the sticky rice was sticky, the portions were a healthy size and the hit in the wallet was deflected with ease. In short, the food was good.

The restaurant itself isn't stunning, but it has a dark late night ambience that is great for a late night lovers chat.

I would definitely recommend.
author: Leon C.

description:
OK, I have been here four times now, and every time the food has been simply amazing.  I love their yellow curry chicken, their tom kha is super creamy, their pad thai is absolutely stellar.  And the capper for me is the "Thai beef jerky" on the appetizer list.  It is so so good, just the right mix of chewy, spicy and savory, WOW.  

The place is clean, and the service is professional.  It does get pretty loud if there are more than a couple of people in the restaurant, so I wouldn't go there for an intimate conversation.  And I haven't brought my kids, so I don't know how kid-friendly it is. It's in a pretty crappy neighborhood, but hey, what are you gonna do?

Highly recommended.
author: Lorelei S.

description:
Bumping this up to 5 stars because it's just THAT good. Went here again for dinner and was once again impressed at the authentic Thai flavors. We ordered the sup nor mai (bamboo shoot salad), kao pad naem (fried rice with spicy sausage), kuaytiaw reua ("boat noodles"), and the bamee ped palo (egg noodles with duck). It was all so tasty and authentic, it immediately brought me back to the streets of Bangkok. The kuayteow reua was a lot better than the version I had at King of Thai Noodles. Even the Thai ice coffee was delicious, with just the right amount of sweetness. 

Service was great as usual.....I left feeling full and satisfied. I will definitely head back again the next time I'm craving real Thai food.
author: Chrys U.

description: Great food, found this place when I was invited by a Thai-Fil friend for dinner. She said that its the best Thai place in the city, she was right..(^_^).
author: j g.

description:
My first impressions when I walked into this place were very off-putting.  I felt virtually ignored by the staff... The place was pretty busy.  It was unclear whether my friends and I should just be seated on our own at an available table, or wait to be seated by a host.  When I approached the counter to find out, it was difficult to near impossible to get anyone to stop long enough to even ask the question. 

Once we finally were seated, the whole experience improved dramatically. The wait staff were friendly and helpful. The prices were good. Most importantly, the food was delicious!  

I'm hoping the bad introduction was just the result of the volume of business that night, and otherwise just a fluke. If I were rating on the food alone, it would be an easy 5, but I can't be so generous until I go back and see better service.
author: Jarrod B.

description:
YUM YUM. I Love their food, it reminds me of the market streets of Thailand and I can order any Thai dish that I feel like eating. The service is pretty good but on top of everything the food is delishhhhhh. 

Everything on the menu is pretty much good. The only bad thing about this place is that while you eat your meal you can see all the crazy homeless people acting weird at the street corner.. but hey, its San Fran.. where wouldn't you see that.. right? 

In a convenient location and they are open at very convenient times. 12 to 12 baby! affordable, tasty and convenient -- you don't see those three words together often!
author: Patty M.

description:
Yay! 5 stars! I feel like it's been such a long time since I've done a 5-star Yelp review. This place definitely deserved it though. It's not as nice and fancy like other Thai restaurants in this area (ie: Osha), but if you are coming solely for the food and not so much the atmosphere, then this is certainly the place for you! I came in a group of 5, and a busser quickly cleaned off a table to get us sat. It took a pretty long time for a server to get to our table, but they seemed pretty backed up at the time. Speaking of our server, he was A-mazing! Great sense of humor, answered every question thoroughly that we had about the different things on the menu, and was just very helpful in general.

I ordered a chicken pad thai for $8.75. They give you a very generous amount, and the pad thai sauce they use is DELICIOUS. I know this is strange, but I'm also very particular on my plating. No, not like presentation... The actual plate. I hate when I go to restaurants and they squeeze all your food on a plate that looks like it should be used for a side of lemons. Then when I try to mix everything together, half of my food ends up on the table (or my lap). The plate they use here gives you more than enough room to feng shui your food.

Love love love. 5 stars!
author: Charmaine A.

description:
I love this place, but sadly they no longer deliver to my neighborhood.  
This was the best delivery Thai I've had. The pumpkin curry is awesome, but can be *very* spicy. We also love the Kao Ka Moo, Gai Yang, papaya salad, pad thai and the Larb is especially good.

I so miss this place.
author: Lyn s.

description:
I love this place. Not sure how much that love has to do with it being a block from my house but who cares!   There are nice big windows inside, so you can watch the interesting people that populate Larkin and Geary.  Dinner and a Show!

I enjoy their Tom Kha with tofu.  They put tons of veggies in it and the tofu is tasty.  The eggplant/tofu and cat fish salad flavorful.   A la carte portions are a nice size and if you are not a pig, can be divided into 2 or 3 portions.  
  

My favorite Thai in the TL.
author: Hillary L.

description:
Summary based on 1 lunch:
--Authentic and not-Americanized 
--Good service
--Prik nam pla had a piece of lime in it, instead of just lime juice.  It seemed to make a positive difference (and I'm going to change my recipe in the same way)
--Parking $2/hr street, pretty easy on Saturday, mid-day
author: Rich H.

description:
my friend rachel is a self-professed thai food snob. and she has a right to be - her grandparents were missionaries there, her father was brought up there and cooked thai food  all throughout rachel's childhood, and she has even been there herself two times. i'd say she knows her way around a bird chili pepper. so when our friend amy and i had a hankering for thai food, rachel was prepared to be disappointed, and promised to try not to be too disdainful. however, she was pleasantly surprised by thai house express. 

the place isn't anything special to look at; it's placement dead in the tendernob doesn't really suggest haute cuisine either. but the food is simple and simply delicious. amy is a frequent patron, and suggested the pra-ram (a chicken and veggies dish with peanut sauce) and the pad see-ew (a favorite noodle dish of mine). rachel was ecstatic to find the kao-soy; a traditional northern-thai dish that is rarely found in the states. i added the fish cake appetizer and we were all set. everything was finger-licking good, but especially the spicy kao-soy soup, every last drop of which rachel and i slurped up without amy's help. though we intended to have leftovers to fulfill our post-drinking munchie needs, we ate it all!
author: Kris G.

description:
I go to this place now and then because it's only a block from my house.  The biggest plus here is that the staff is youthful, friendly and genuine, and they really want to make sure you enjoy what you're eating.  I have food sensitivities and they are always very accommodating and don't get worked up and paranoid like some other places do.

They use a lot of MSG which I have become less tolerant of as of lately, but they are totally willing to forego that if you ask them.
author: Evie S.

description: I may have people disagreeing with me, but I don't care - On the table they have a card that says the name has changed but they still have great service.  I can't agree with that at all.  They were slow really slow I had to grab someone to take my order after several minutes and telling them that I was really hungry and wanted to order. - I asked for mild red curry, normally I ask for medium,  and it was still really spicy and it didn't have any flavor I asked them if they would replace green peppers  with some other vegetable and they said that would be an extra charge,.  When I was done I sat there for a really long time and no one came with the bill,  I finally just left money and took off.  They were really slow and there were hardly any customers and if I hadn't been starving I don't think I would have eaten it because despite being spicy it had no flavor.
author: Sara J.

description:
Decent.  Some of us really liked it.  My husband (H) and I think the place is just okay.  They can really accommodate a big group, though, and the food comes decently quickly.

Some disliked the coconut vegetarian soup; I just thought its flavor clashed with the rest of what we were eating unless we drink that first and then rested our stomachs before the next taste.

Some liked the steamed fish dish -- some sort of flattish fish.  H and I thought it tasted "fishy" but the rest were perhaps desensitized or didn't mind that taste.  I think they liked the texture and the perfect steaming.

The others really liked the roasted chicken or whatever it's called.   H thought it was rather bland, and he could have done a better marinade.  I didn't try it.

We all liked the crab pad thai, duck larb, and the papaya salad.  (We ordered two pad thai -- one spicy and one not -- and they both came out mildly spicy -- which was perfectly fine with me.)
author: Christine T.

description: Kao Soi! Best outside of Chiang Mai
author: Eric M.

description:
This is the best Thai restaurant in San Francisco.  Like with many great finds in this city, I was turned on to this place by friends.  There are fancier Thai restaurant and certainly more expensive Thai retaurants, but this is my choice when I want great Tahi food and fast service at a reasonable price.

My favorite dish is Gang Dang with Chicken.  Tonight, I am trying their delivery service for the first time!
author: James D.

description:
Food: amazingly tasty.  Waitress: could offer a smile every once in a while.

For $25, we got fried rice, eggplants+basil, and chicken+cashews+vegs+chili.  Everything was fantastic, really good!  

The area is kinda shady and you wouldn't enter this place just by looking at its facade.  But do venture in, and you will be rewarded. 

Don't expect good service though... I guess that's why it's called "express"
author: Rob G.

description:
Good food, decent price, come here once and a while when in the area,.
     Staff is nice, overall clean place
author: John L.

description: The food's okay. Had the five spice duck rice plate (#118) which was pretty good. I ordered it with garlic rice and either I didn't get garlic rice or their garlic rice is not very garlicky. In either case, I'm not pleased with the rice.
author: Sophia K.

description: Awesome thai food and great value too. To top it off, they offer quick free delivery. I've been happy with almost everything I've ordered - love the pumpkin curry, the pad-see-ew and most of the stir fry's. The quality of their prawns aren't that great in my opinion, which is the only reason I give them 4 stars. Otherwise, very happy with this  place - and two people can have dinner for ~$20 - how can you go wrong?
author: Aden Z.

description:
Thai Express is a lively Thai restaurant located on a busy corner of Larkin on the edge of the Tenderloin.  I grew to enjoy this place having lived in the neighborhood the past few years.  The food is consistently of good quality, the service friendly, and the restaurant clean.  Often, I get takeout from here. My favorite dishes are Gang Garee Gai (chicken and potatos in a coconut curry) and the Barbeque Chicken.  It used to be this was pretty dry and over-salted, but they seem to have juiced up the recipe and it is much tastier.  I usually get the a la carte as it comes with 5 pieces of chicken (a leg, a wing, thigh and two breasts).  I also like the Cucucmber Salad for 3 bucks.  

They did raise their prices a year ago or so, which had me miffed.  Over $10 for Asian take out just doesnt seem right.  Now, I concede inflation has taken a hit on everything so I guess that is the world we now live in.  

I do wish they served Angel Wings (stuffed chicken wings) but apparently they take alot of effort to make.  For that, you can go down to O'Farrell and check out Sai Jai Thai.  Overall, my experience has been consistently good.
author: Ethan R.

description:
Yummy Yummy Yummy ~

This is currently my favorite Thai restaurant in town!

Although the location is not really ideal for me, I love the food there. So far everything I have tasted (I have eaten there or taken out at roughly ten times) been amazing. 

My man is quite familiar with the people there and I can see why. The people at this place are like your family, very friendly and warm. 

hmmmmm those pictures make me hungry !!
author: Sayaha A.

description:
OMG, their food is LIKE crack.  Still love the Moo-Tod...but can't be seen in public after a dishful of that stuff. 

Bad news...had to deduct a star...the last time that I was there eating dinner with my friend, Scott....we saw one LARGE COCKROACH...side by side with 2 babies....UUUGH...they weren't in the food, but on the wooden bench where I was seated.  Everytime it would come towards me, I would give it my "STINKY EYE" .  ONE WORD: EWWWWWWWW!

Still love the food, though...the roach had me thinking twice...
author: Hiromi N.

description:
THE FOOD IS WONDERFUL.. . if you like Thai food but not to spicy with lots of kick and flavor its a must
my faves: GUI CHAI crispy chive almost like hallow pancakes 
                  SALAD NUER SUN beef salad with greens, tomatoes, onions
                  MOO TOD crispy pork with garlic lots of it and pepper
service was okay to good / nice for group events. it was  kind of loud but place seems clean and a jeans and t shirt kind of a place.
      again go for the food
author: Michelle A.

description: What's with the overpriced Tenderloin Thai restaurants? $10 for a rice plate while watching a guy take a leak outside the window. Maybe the price includes an entertainment surcharge? Had the crispy pork belly...it was good. Fish cakes, also good. Service a bit erratic as if they just opened three days ago.
author: James B.

description:
Came here with the family for Lola's birthday last night.  My first time here and it was great! 
Pad Thai - great flavor and the noodles were cooked just right
Shrimp Paste Fried Rice - Very flavorful
Beef Jerky - I didn't try this because I haven't really been able to eat beef lately.  But others say it was good.  It has a salty after taste though.
Pumpkin Curry - Very good!  A little spice but not too spicy.  Great flavor.
Cat Fish Salad - The sauce was a little too spicy for me.  But a good dish.
author: Eegnam A.

description:
I love it! Traditional thai food, served with the funnest, coolest, friendliest service around.

So my friends and I come here pretty often. They do have one mean tom yum noodle soup thats quite good. But I think their chicken garlic rice (Kao Man Gai) is amazing. Their duck rice is quite fine too. It somehow also reminds me of the Singaporean version of Hainanese Chicken rice!

Their fried chicken isn't so good but their kao niao (sticky rice) is awesomezzzzz. :D
author: Denise T.

description:
I'm always searching for a good Thai place that is open late..ladies and gentleman this is it! 
We got there around 10:30 and there were still a lot of people eating. The people there are so nice and sat us right away. We ordered the pumpkin curry with tofu med. spicy, and pad Thai. The food came right away and it looked so good. They were also very attentive with the water. The pumpkin had yummy pieces of fried tofu, bell pepper,  and pumpkin in a red curry sauce. The pad Thai was very very good  and it came with shrimp, tofu, noodles, and a whole bunch of bean sprouts on the other side of the dish. The pad Thai was very flavor full and you could have just eaten it by itself. The only funny thing is this place is located in the tender lone. While i munched on my food i watched these crack head couple pushing each other against the wall across the street. Other then the location this place is a great late night spot.
author: Isabella E.

description:
Good, reasonably priced thai food.  Open late, though they used to be open later.  

And how can you beat the live action theater of despair outside the window?  Definitely peep the bums with bloated "crack feet" stumbling down the street and the foil blocked window across the street.  Meth lab anyone?  Makes the perfect date spot.

But I digress.  The param pak (crispy tofu with peanut sauce over a bed of spinach) is the shit and is even better the second day!  The yum woonsen (silver noodles with minced pork, shrimp, mushrooms, onion and lemon) is sexy too.  However the crab noodles (chan pad poo) is what I come for.  They are pretty spicy but not to the point where you feel like you're going to sweat out your meal (always ask for mild).  The pouches appetizer is cravable too.  Pair with a beer and it's heaven.  My man loves the yellow chicken curry and always asks for extra potatoes.  

Overall, nice place with good value.  Clean chopsticks.  Never found any foreign objects in my food or on the floor::knockonwood::, and the take out is always correct and timely.
author: Margaret L.

description:
One of the better Thai places in the area. Get curry with chicken - the chicken will just melt in your mouth. Pumpkin curry is a hit too. Solid Thai food here.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: Thank goodness for the second location of Thai House Express! At the TL location, sure there are more sketchy people around, but there is more parking!  My all time favorites taste just as delicious, including beef panang curry which is slightly spicy and made my dad sweat after each bite, pork leg stew=super tender, and tom kha soup, which was a bit sour but still yummy.  The restaurant took reservations for our medium sized party on a Friday night.  The bill was super affordable for 9 people.  The only thing is if if you have kid(s) and you have a stroller, they make you stick it in a corner (away from your table). Nevertheless, this was a great bday for the bday boy!  I'm still craving more of that curry!
author: Steph W.

description:
First allow me to admit that I'm not asian, eurasian, thai, viet, pinoy, etc..  I'm really sorry about that.

So its true that I don't have any native credibility when it comes to asian cuisine.  But I have tried many Thai restaurants in the east bay and sf over the years. On one occasion back in 2003 I met a "colleague." for lunch at the Thai House.  He is such a mellow guy.  But he made one glaring comment.  "Oh wow, you've never been here before?"  I kind of sank in my chair....

I have been coming back ever since.  Yes, it is in the "Loin."  But the food at this joint gets my loins pumping.  Everything I have tried here is amazing.  I am completely hooked on the Pad See-ew.  Or the number 64 as I call it.  The noodles with your choice of chicken, pork, or beef and fresh steamed broccoli, are delicious and filling.  Plus I tried their hot Thai tea the other day and it was also really tasty.  This place is inexpensive, laid back, and is some of the best Thai food I have tasted in the city.  

As long as you avoid going across the street to the Outsider, (wink), for a cocktail.....you should have an enjoyable evening.  Good luck.
author: Georgio N.

description:
Great Thai Food. Great prices. Decent ambiance.

Not much more to ask for, I highly recommend going for the Pad Kee Mao and the House Special Beef. I always alternate the other thing that I get.

In terms of the Thai food that I've had, it's in the top 25%. You won't be disappointed.
author: David H.

description: Very courteous service and had some curry and pork belly, both very good and spicy if you want. Many options to choose from even if vegetarian. The vegetables were also very good and tasty. Service is very attentive and very willing to help you when needed.
author: Len A.

description:
I love that you walk into this (closest thing to real Thai in SF) spot, get a seat instantly, order 21, 50, 43, 103, rice and (sticky rice) and get served in about 3 minutes.

Be careful, if you don't know what 'Thai Hot' is...  ;)
author: Michael R.

description:
This is one of my favorite Thai restaurants in San Francisco. Service is tops, and so is the food. I ordered their chicken larb, and it was plentiful and flavorful. 
If you are going to see a gig at the Great American Music Hall, go to this place. Fast service and great eats.
author: Ericha F.

description:
Love this place. I consistently go back.

It was first recommended to me by a Thai coworker of mine; who insisted it was his favorite place in the city for authentic Thai.

You'll know by the moment you walk in the door this ain't no Applebee's. The people-watching alone is an adventure in itself. Let's just say some ...interesting... people will undoubtedly be lingering outside at the urbanly scenic crossroads of Geary & Larkin.

Nothing on the menu lets me down. The first time I came here, my friend and I arrived beyond-hungry, and we nearly demolished four entrees between the two of us. All were delish.

It's casual; so don't expect fancy. DO expect a good variety of well-spiced dishes, quick and friendly service (on most visits), great people watching and a cheap tab. Also, it's open late-ish.
author: Daniel P.

description:
It gets high marks for being open till midnight daily!

Still reviewing about the place I hit last year after reading about the Yelp 2008 list - http://yelp.typepad.com/files/100bestchecklistsf-1.pdf

#48. Kao ka moo - slow cooked pork leg with picked veggies....it is so good with the garlic sauce over rice making me feel like my mom was working in that kitchen 

Other dishes we tried:
- Tom Ka Gai - creamy traditional chicken sour soup with coconut milk that warms my soul
- Eggplant and Shrimp - great dish with a good heat us Chinese call "wok hay".....it is a good thing
- Yum Shanghai - didn't know what to make of this with clear bean noodles stir-fry with meat but was a good combo

I can't wait to start my softball season again so I have an excuse to venture out to the TL.
author: Katie K.

description: Since August, i've been eating at Thai restaurants around the TL.  Thai House Express was my first stop, and it may be my favorite. I love the Pad Kee Mao.  The noodles were very high quality, broad and flat.  Additionally, the other ingredients all the way down to the basil were very high quality.  Two thumbs way up!
author: Chris G.

description: I went here once about a month ago and it was the best Thai food I ever had. The Pumpkin Curry is amazing! It sounded like it would be too sweet but it wasn't. I ordered it medium flavored and it hit the spot. I'm gonna make it a point to go there every time I come to San Fran which is quite frequently now. Ever since I tried this place I've been telling everyone about it.
author: Jason F.

description:
Went here today for lunch. I've learned about a new thai dish I haven't tried yet. Sai Jai Thai doesn't have it so the waitress told me to go here since they have it.

It's Kao Ka Moo. Pork leg stew over rice. Also ordered Som Tum and Roti. This pork leg stew is pretty good. Reminiscent of a chinese-filipino called Pata Tim. When I ordered it, the waitress asked me "Is fat ok?" I of course said yes. You can't eat pork leg stew without the fat. I'm sold. I love it. It came with what I think some kind if pickled vegetable and a garlic chili vinegar sauce on the side.

Som Tum was ok and you can't really go wrong with the roti dessert. They have a special on the white board that caught my attention. Spicy Crispy Skin-Pork. They said it's roasted 3 layered pork. I instantly knew what it was. Pork-Fat-Skin. Similar to the Filipino Lechon except maybe thai style. I'm gonna come back again to try that dish.
author: Ryan B.

description:
This is pretty close to what you can have in Thailand....
Nicer places in the city like the Oshas have good food, but it has been extremely "westernized".

Now I understand that "real" Thai food might not be to everybody's taste, but if you are willing to try Thai House is as close as it gets. Not completely like in Thailand, but that's the difference between an $8 dish and an $800 plane ticket!
The only other places that can compare are Sai Jai Thai, Lers Ros and Ozone (conveniently, all 4 of them are within 3 blocks of each other!) but Thai House has better decor and is more comfortable than Sai Jai Thai or Lers Ros, and doesn't have Thai karaoke like Ozone, which I love, but might be unnerving to most non-Thai people.

The service is always good although not exceptional, but I don't expect that from a Tenderloin joint... it does get a liiiiitle slow when they are slammed.
But more importantly, it's one of the only places in the city to serve good Kao Mun Gai (steamed chicken over garlic rice) which I highly recommend!
author: Vithiet L.

description:
I love this place. I've gotten take out from this place like 20+ times. I usually get the pad kee mao (drunken noodles).

Why do I like it?

1. Convenient. My friend lives nearby.
2. Open late to fulfill any late night munchies.
3. Their bathroom key is attached to a steel ladle.
author: Jeff T.

description: Awesome service and so friendly!  The pumpkin curry is soo good.  Also really love the thai style beef jerky.  My friend lives down the street from here, so I think I have eaten here every time I visit her.  Its so great!
author: Kate M.

description: very good Thai food, the spiciness is awesome. You should try the Naked ladies in spicy sauce,very good. I love this place !
author: Suabot J.

description: The pork lag stew noodle soup is the best! So flavory, and meat is so tender. Not sure this is typical Thai food, more like Chinese! Other dishes on the menu are good too, but you probably can get them some where else! Pork leg stew is unique!
author: Emmy P.

description: Lived 10 years in Bangkok and this is by far the most authentic Thai food in the city!!! Gotta order the "sup naa mai" only place to find it authentic in San Fran.  This place has the best Thai food in town hands down and at a reasonable price.
author: Ngeean x.

description:
This place is great. 

Pretty much anything on the menu is good to go. But the one thing I did wanna say about this place is "Thai Spicy" and "American spicy" This is what our waiter would ask my friends when they requested it to be spicy. He explained that American Spicy is weaksauce compared to Thai Spicy but a LOT of people can't handle it because it's way too hot.

He was right. My friend decided to try ordering it "Thai Spicy" and it was way too hot. For every two bites, she gulped down her entire cup of water. I don't even think she finished 1/3 of it because she couldn't handle the spiciness hahaha

So for those of you who LOVE spicy, maybe you should stick with American spicy because my friends who LOVE LOVE spicy food, couldn't even handle the Thai Spicy lol
author: Diana Y.

description: This Thai restaurant has the best Pad Gra-Praw (or Gai Gra Prao) in the Bay Area -- no debate. I order this dish al la carte every time I eat there. The Thai fried rice with pork is also the best Thai fried rice I've tasted in any Thai restaurant in the Bay Area, and I've eaten at over 20 Thai restaurants across the Bay Area. The only problem is that I live in Oakland and there's no way that they'll deliver here. If I lived in the City of SF, they would be delivering to my house several times a week.
author: SodaPop Y.

description: How many people can say they'd walk more than half a mile to grab lunch?  Not many.  Thai House Express is just THAT good.  The food is consistent, they never skimp on portion or flavor, and when I mention that I want it spicy, they really know how to give it to me.  One of my top five Thai restaurants in the city..seriously.   The service is just alright, but the food is good enough to keep me coming back for more.
author: C E.

description:
After getting friends from the airport, waiting for them to check in to their hotel downtown and get freshened up, it was after 11 and we were all kind of starving.  We had other friends waiting for us though so we only had time for a quick bite.

Then, serendipitously, some other people called to say they were going to Thai House Express and when asked if it was better than Osha, one of them said it was his favorite Thai place in SF.  Ok, decision made.

We hurried over and they had already ordered a beef jerky thing, duck larb, pineapple fried rice and pad see ew.  We added a pumpkin curry with pork and because the portions were pretty large, that was enough for us.  I'd never had beef jerky at a Thai place but it was surprisingly good.  My favorites were the duck larb and the pumpkin curry.  Both of them had a really nice kick that made the dishes spicy but not overwhelming.

The food I had in Thailand was always more spicy and never sweet like what is usually served in the US so this felt more authentic.  And yes, the pretty Thai boys with the Korean drama haircuts were easy on the eyes.
author: Seong P.

description:
Thai House Express is probably one of the few authentic Thai restaurants in the city.  I lived/worked in Thailand for 6 months so I had my share of Thai food.  We always order the Kao Ka Moo, which is the stewed pork leg over rice.  This Chinese-y dish comes with a couple of spicy dipping sauces and "zha cai" (picked mustard greens).  The pork leg, which is stewed in a five-spice sauce, is extremely tender.  I've seen this dish in one other Thai restaurant in the city but this is the gold standard.

We also like the pad thai with crab meat, which is not too sweet and contains fresh crab. The mango with sticky rice is excellent here.
author: Anna S.

description:
Thai food after a trip to Whiskey Thieves is a given with me. Yeah, it sounds like a weird combination, but spicy food = I get hydrated. This is definitely a winning formula in my book! Extra points for being open late.

I've come here several times and they've never failed me. I love their Tom Yum soup (they actually use galangal in this!); it's better than Sai Jai's in my opinion (Sai Jai uses white button mushrooms instead of the canned straw mushrooms that actually should go in it). They do a really good green papaya salad with salty crab (not quite as good as Sai Jai, but you can't win 'em all). They have really tasty Drunken Noodles too. We've also gotten various other curries and noodles and it always hits the spot.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Even though this place has great dishes, and closer to Authentic flavors... it is not my favorite simply because of the service. 

We always feel like we are being ignored or having eyes rolled at us. 

Food is great though. The Pad See Ew is one of the best in the city. And the Rad Na is served over a crispy egg noodle with this amazing gravy that will leave you licking your lips afterwards. I think this is one of the few Thai restaurants in the city where I can pretty much recommend any of their Noodle dishes with confidences. Their curries are "ok". But I'm telling you, you can't go wrong with the noodles here. 


Great desserts too. They have Roti (which is a high point) but I'm pretty sure its not homemade. 

They are open 12 to 12!
author: Jay M.

description:
Went to eat here after getting recommendations from a friend.

PROS:
- Tom Kha Ghai: or coconut chicken thai soup is my litmus test of a good thai restaurant was outstanding. Loved it for lunch on a freezing December day in the city.
- Papaya shrimp salad: Made from young papaya, was excellent. By accident I asked them to make it spicy and it was too hot to handle !! I complained and they re-did and we enjoyed it 
- Prig King: Green bean chicken was good too.

Fast food and fast service, will definitely be coming back.
author: Vik K.

description:
Note: Ordered delivery

--Food--
2*

Pad See Ewe: 1.5* lacked flavor, which is hard to imagine since it's such a simple recipe.  The noodles had good texture though.

Pumpkin curry: 2* was only okay, basically was a watery Panang curry with slightly undercooked lumps of pumpkin in it.  

Sticky rice with custard: 1.5* Sticky rice was dried out in parts and felt like it had been cooked quite a while a go, not completely unusual for sticky rice desserts but sub-optimal.  

Garlic rice: 1* Was only flavored of ginger.  

And the kicker is that something there gave me mild food poisoning (and I eat off food carts in Central America without issue).  


--Service (Delivery only)--
1* Food was 30 mins late and lukewarm
author: Abbot S.

description:
I'd love to slap every bitch in this joint-- with the exception of 2 or 3 of the employees working here. They are nasty, rude, and costumer service is non-existent. If you're lucky, you might be greeted by the older, Thai woman (possibly a manager), or one of the young Thai shipments that are NOT bitter and angry about not finding the perfect farang of their dreams so they no longer have to work in what must be some type of indentured servitude. 

Anyway, aside from those wretched crows, the pad see ew with chicken (No MSG) is always my favorite. 
The pumpkin curry with beef is lovely-- a bit salty, but flavorful. 
The vegetable fried rice is terrible though-- way too bland, and I don't believe in iceberg lettuce, or serving it warm. 

All in all, they get 3 stars for the always-yummy pad see ew.
author: Angela M.

description: I have always been wanting to go to Thai House express for chicken over rice dish (Kao Maan Kai) since I came to San Francisco because I've heard that they serve authentic thai cuisine. Last year, I got a chance to go there but I was really disappointed. The place looked dirty especially the way the floor looked. I ordered chicken over rice and my sister ordered grilled chicken (appetizer). My food was ok. It wan't something special and the soup that came with it was tasteless, just like hot water. I wasn't very impressed by that. Grilled chicken was HORRIBLE! It was extremely dry and hard! and it looked like it was a left over or something. It was nasty. We didn't even touch that!
author: Pimwalan I.

description:
lifesavingly delicious. ..

+ :  fresh delicious ingredients. .. nice staff. ..

Tom Kha with chicken was just sO delicious!! to the very last drop. .. Salad Nuer Sun was real good too with dressing just right but wish it had more tomatoes and onions and cucumber. ..

- :  a bit of a wait but worth the wait. ..
author: Y I L I W.

description: definitely the best thai in SF!! Order the papaya salad with no fish sauce for my vegan friends... Pad ka na with brown rice and crispy tofu is tha bomb. The restaurant is willing to accommodate anyone who is vegan or veggie! Love yah thai house!
author: Kayla G.

description:
I really like the location of Thai House Express on Larkin because it's easily accessible if you're riding the bus. The service is very fast and the food is great for the price. It's a good place to stop at for a bite to eat before an evening movie, as 1000 Van Ness is right around the corner.

NOTE: I mainly eat soups and salads. That being said, I love the Som Tum Thai, #15, at Thai House Express. Its a delicious shredded green papaya salad with dried shrimp tomatoes, green beans and peanuts in a lemon dressing. Their Yum Raum Mit Talay, #25, is another tasty favorite. This is a combination seafood salad tossed in a lemon dressing. 

It's definitely a place I recommend to friends when they're looking for Thai around this area.
author: Danielle S.

description:
I havent had a Thai dish I havent liked at this point. My wife and I eat there frequently. The service is good, friendly and the food is outstanding. I love the Pork Shoulder stew, the curry dishes, the fried chicken , the soups. Its yummy thai comfort at its finest. 
Prices I think are reasonable, portions are also at least to me really good, but it depends on what you order. 
And you cant beat the location, right in the middle of Tenderloin Heights where if you get a window seat, you can see drug dealers, hookers, escaped mental patients,  homeless people ( and on a lucky day , they will walk into the restaurant and greet you !) 
But fear not, the Police cars are always there, and if they're not, its because they are eating at Little Henry's, one short block away
Great Thai food in one of the most active parts of San Francisco. What are you waiting for ? Get down over here ! 
Need some good Thai food with police protection, look no further than Thai House at Geary and Larkin :)
author: David S.

description: Oh my gawd this is amazing Thai food! Absolutely the best I've ever had. We started off with their sampler appetizer which comes with crab cakes, golden bags, and some fried rolls. All of them were fantastic. I reccomend the Pumpkin Curry or the Kao Soi noodles. Both dishes are wonderful. This place is cheap and it is definitely at the very top of my list of restaurants to eat at when I return to San Francisco!
author: Julio G.

description: Best Thai delivery in the city. The Gai Tod and Moo Tod are incredible. Their delivery is the cleanest and most neatly packaged of any delivery I've ordered in the city. You can tell they put care into how they prepare your meal.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Garunteed great Thai food and it is almost always speedy out of the kitchen. A little pricey for the area, and my service inside has never been terriffic; usually iting for water refils and if you request something after you have recieved your main course you can expect it to take a while. But don't let your impatience keep you from their delicious food!
author: Azlynn T.

description:
$7.25 for the Pad See Ew, so it's only slightly more than Sai Jai Thai.  It's equally as good so it'd be a toss up.

The Peak Gai Tod (Fried Chicken Wings) were freaking amazing though.  I would highly recommend getting an order if you eat here.

They also have quite a bit of specials listed around the restaurant so those would be worth a check next time.

Need a $10 minimum if you want to use a credit card though.
author: Jason K.

description:
Went here on night of 1/29th. Ordered Tom Yum ($8) which was delicious. Also ordered Minced Basil Chicken ($10) - which too was very good. The helping size was big enough to serve two (with ample stuff left over to take home). The garlic rice too is delicious. 
The place is in a shifty neighborhood - but the inside is clean and comfortable. The food is great. I'm going to go back many times!
author: Saquib P.

description: I was quite excited to order delivery from here after seeing all the great reviews, but the food was just fine.  Delivery was fast though! I ordered the pad Thai and a beef salad.  Flavors were all there, but the salad is quite difficult to eat since it was giant pieces of lettuce.
author: dublin a.

description: The food here is alright. I only come here for dessert. They have the BEST Roti! Hands down. YUM!
author: Natasha S.

description:
RESTAURANT CUSTODY AGREEMENT

Lainie L. (Party A) and  Future Heart Breaker Scumbag (Party B), do hereby agree that each restaurant they bring into the relationship shall be in the sole custody of the person who brings the restaurant into the relationship.  Dissolution of relationship shall render all future visits by Party B null and void.

AGREED that Party B shall never, ever bring new girlfriend to restaurant so that our regular waitress does not ask Party A if new girlfriend was Party B's sister.

So on and so forth. . . 

All right, so I love restaurants. . .I search out great ones and make them my regular spots.  Thai House Express is a favorite.  They have great food and had really late night hours (they close at midnight now - boooooooo!).  I brought my last boyfriend here and he loved it.  He'd bring all his chef buddies and show off how they knew us and what kick ass food they had.  When we  broke-up he got custody of the restaurant by geographical default. . he ended up living four blocks away and began frequenting MY restaurant quite often.  

He recently moved so now I got custody back. . . and boy, did I miss my Thai House Express.  

One of the things I love about it is that they have dishes that not every Thai restaurant has - and they do them very well.  My favorites are #1 Toong Gern Yueng - little, fried, chicken dumplings.  They are so cute and delicious.  #15 - Som Tum Thai - green papaya salad.  They make a really tasty Larb (I like chicken best).  #40 Kao Ka Moo - Pork Leg Stew over Rice - I am a sucker for braised meat and this is fantastic!   Along the same lines is #43 - Kao Moo Dang which is roasted pork over rice with this yummy gravy saucy stuff.  My most favorite thing is #72 Kao Pad Nam - the waitress might try to persuade you not to order this dish as it features a Thai sausage that apparently most American eaters do not like.  .do not listen to her. . .it's so delicious!  The sausage, rice, cilantro and Chinese broccoli all meld together with chili sauce and it's one of my favorite Thai dishes.  

Always check out the white board - there are sometimes some phenomenal specials - one of the best is the pork leg noodle soup with pickled mustard greens, duck larb or Thai won tons.  

It is not your normal TL hole in the wall - it's clean, kind of hip and funky and comfortable.  If you go to Thai House Express - steer away from the usual suspects (pad Thai, etc.) and try something you've never had. . .I think you'll be happy.   They only get four  stars because their curries are a little weak and I once had to witness someone's naked package pancaked against the window (it's in the heart of  the TL . . it can happen).  

I am just happy to get back custody of MY restaurant!
author: Lainie L.

description:
If you were are a server at a Thai restaurant, and your customer was a very nice and incredibly good looking young woman with nice hair (and striped tube socks) who ordered the number 29 chicken with cashew nut rice plate and you brought her a plate that was clearly not what she ordered, and the woman politely informed you of this and asked if she could have the number 29 chicken with cashew nut rice plate, what would you do?

A)  Argue with the young woman, telling her that it is what she ordered even though it was beef with some kind of noodle, and tell her that she is wrong, and she obviously does not know that chicken and cows are the same animal, and that rice has become the new noodle, and obviously she should just eat what is put in front of her and stop complaining because it's not like she isn't PAYING for this meal or anything.

B)  Stare at her blankly and forget how to speak English.

C)  Grab the plate violently away from the startled young woman and scream "Fine!  It will be a longer wait!" and march back to the kitchen mumbling naughty words, all while noticing how cute the woman's bangs look.

D)  Act like a normal server and apologize for bringing the wrong dish and tell the woman that what she ordered will be right out, and ask her if she would like a refill on tea.

If you answered anything but "D" you are correct.  

Why 3 stars you ask?  Because the cashew chicken here is really good when it's actually chicken.  And because most of the servers aren't assholes.
author: Starla D.

description:
This place gets 4 stars only because it beats out most other thai I have had in the city and its cheap. Ive had a tough time with Thai in the bay area and I eat a very basic dish.  But I keep trying.  This place was recommended to me and I was pleasantly surprised.  But I only get it to go because I have to doctor it up and add fresh veggies at home.

Biggest downfall- no delivery.  What is with all of these thai places in SF that don't deliver?!
author: Kiera H.

description:
Steph Secret #41: I am kind of lazy, and I believe in figuring out the most efficient way to use 20% effort to get 80% of the results.

Especially when it comes to making decisions about where to go out or eat, I tend to focus my efforts on seeking 1) Convenience, 2) Somewhere that would please all parties involved, and 3) Advice from trusted sources. In the case of choosing where to have dinner last week, #1 necessitated that the restaurant be somewhere near Nob Hill, #2 ruled out any of the fabulous Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the area because that could have spurned some awkward DYL encounters, and #3 pointed me to Yelp. My weird ESP thing must have kicked in because I was drawn to Lainie L's review of Thai House Express. Based on some of the review's recommendations and our own cravings, we ordered:

- Tom Yum Goong: this traditional Thai soup was most definitely hot (if this was "medium," I think my tongue would have fallen off for "hot") and sour, additionally flavored with lemongrass and galanga. . Thai House Express is quite generous with the prawns and straw mushrooms, which is always a plus. 

- Larb Pedd (duck salad): listed on the Specials whiteboard, not on the regular menu. Larb is a meat salad usually made with ground chicken, pork, or beef and seasoned with chilis, onions, cilantro, and a tart dressing usually made of lemon and fish sauce. Larb pedd switches things up with minced roasted duck (including the skin!). Larb is one of my favorite Southeast Asian dishes because it embodies the intense complexity of flavors that can spring from the amalgamation of very simple ingredients. Thai House Express delivered the promise of hot, sour, savory, cool, crunch. The duck was especially delightful as the backdrop because it added an extra layer of complexity with the fat and crisp of the duck skin. In terms of spiciness, we ordered it medium and THE did not insult us by giving us the toned down version of "medium." Yowza!

- Pad Thai: okay, okay. So, pad thai is one of those dishes that foodies scoff at plebians for ordering at Thai restaurants. But it is also one of those things that can serve as a measuring stick across restaurants because it's guaranteed that they will all have it! Not to mention that the menu noted that THE's pad thai was voted the Best of the Bay by the SFGuardian. I normally am very skeptical of these accolades (especially in Boston; never trust "Best of Boston"), but my preconceptions were proven wrong! This was some DAMN good pad thai...the noodles just the right firm texture, the chicken tender and plentiful, the bean sprouts providing a refreshing contrast, the peanuts giving a nice salty crunch, and most importantly - the not-too-sweet sauce completely coating the whole package. This was no wimpy, half-assed pad thai. Amen.

- Fried Roti w/ Coconut Ice Cream: ahh, the Clincher. Sooj O. recounts the experience with this dessert much better than I could. But let me reiterate that we started out with one order and proceeded to devour a second after the obligatory "Oh, I don't know...should we?" Interestingly, the roti's texture was different with each serving (one was much more flaky, while the other was more chewy - indicative of differences in the frying time). However, it was still freakin' good and that coconut ice cream was so rich and creamy that I was completely oblivious to the possible lactarded consequences.

Five stars for the excellent food and the excellent prices. Extra snaps to Thai House Express for the SUPER FAST, friendly service and for being one of the few clean, spacious places in Lower Nob Hill/Tenderloin. If you, too, are a lazy Yelper in search of a place to go, I hope that you used your minimal energy to read this review and trust my judgment enough to get out to Thai House Express!
author: Steph P.

description:
Have I had Thai before?  I don't know.... probably, maybe, possibly you spotted me but I know I had some Thai on Saturday night after Rock The Bells.

My best friend was up from L.A. with her dood and she wanted to go out dancing after the concert.  We met up with her friend and her dood at the Thai House on Larkin and Geary.  To myself I'm thinking, "hmm Thai, heard good things... lets see if it do what it do"

My BF is Japanese and Korean, her dood is Korean and White, her friend is Korean and her dood is Spanish.  

We walk in and my BF-friend and her dood were already sitting down (did I lose you) eating soup with noodles or, noodles added to soup, or soup added to noodles, I don't know.  First thing I saw was the prawns 

me, "I gotta get me some of that what did you order?"
BF-Friend" bla bla bla bla soup and I had them add noodles"
me, "umm what was that again?"
BF-F, "you want me to order it for you"
feeling like a little kid having his mommy order the happy meal from MC Donald's "yes please... oh no mushrooms though"

So I'm all excited.... Thai food, friends and what's that?  Trannies?  Dinner is always better with entertainment.

I get my soup in like 5 minutes (wow quick service) I reach for the chop sticks and damn near got karate chopped from the bestest... she snatches the sticks from my hand and scolds me (like I'm her kid)

"Don't EVER EVER use the chop sticks without cleaning them, are you CRAZY?" 
me," Damn, my bad" stretches out hand for her to slap.  So after she dips them in water and I guess washes them off with a napkin, I'm ready to eat.  One problem.

Me + Chopsticks + wet noodle soup don't work out.  Errreebody looking at the Brotha like "I bet he ask for a fork."  F*** that, I'ma make this work.
Talking to myself (hmmm grab the prawn, show them you know how to use chop sticks... good good... now grab a piece of tomato... good good.. now get some noodles... what you can't hold on, you idiot you can't even hold onto one noodle?  Hurry they are watching you... still no go?  Ask for a fork! SAVE FACE SAVE FACE)

Me, "I need a fork"
"WHAT YOU NO USE D STICKS?"  Ya that wasn't said by my Asian friends that was said by the Spanish dood.  Oh I feel *this big* the Spanish cat clowning me cause I can't use chop sticks?  Looking all dumbfounded like "what is these what is these" The bestest (making me feel like a kid again) grabs the chop stick and the spoon thingy, puts some noodles in the spoon thingy, dips in soup, adds a tomato and feeds it to me... I know whoever was working was in the back pointing at the security camera laughing their arses off!
FORK FORK I NEED A FORK DAMN IT.

Once I got a fork all was good... including the food that was absolutely delicious!  mmm... prawns, soup, noodles, tomatos, no mushrooms, and Thai tea... all that  for like $11 or $12 Nice nice.

However, mixing in some double jack and cokes later didn't really sit well with my stomach.

I will be back.  Chop sticks in hand!
author: Jamal G.

description:
Thai house Express, I havent stepped foot in this place since 2002 about. I remember my first time having a pad thai. Yup it was here, back then I wasnt too sure about thai food and everything else cause well, Ive never had it.
