Anyhow though, the pad thai was delicous. I enjoyed it and was thinking wow I have been missing out. So from then whenever i went to most thai restuarants I would order the pad thai. Now pad thai isnt something extravagent, just some noodles with shrimp and tofu and egg stirred in some sauce with crushed peanuts. But I like it...

so my lady and I decided to come here, she likes thai food...I am not too keen on it ever since the incident at Yukol. But hey I can trust this place so I suggested we come here. She had the pad thai and I had the steamed chicken with garlic rice...and yes Jason it was good~

We also had an appetizer suggested by our server, now I cant really remember what it was called but i know it was like a roll consisiting of egg and sausage and veggies? over a dark sauce with a bit of shredded crab. That was pretty good~

Portions was just as I remembered and the pad thai was just as good as I remembered it to be. Place is still clean and yea pretty much overall this place did wonderfully, our server was very nice, polite and quick. Oh yea and the thai ice tea was nice too~
author: phillip w.

description:
Oh my Asian! 

*^_^*   :-P   zZ(-.-)Zz   \(^_^)/   ;-)    ()^_^) (^_^()   xxXaZnQTPie4LiFeXxx

...eh, you get the point.

We were greeted to this restaurant by a marker board displaying a disproportionately drawn anime boy that had hearts coming out of his head and blush lines that made him look like he just dove face-first into a patch of poison ivy.  After seeing the "Tipping very sexy" jar at the cashier's counter, I knew this place was going to be amazing.

And it did not disappoint.  The dishes were pretty good.  And at 6-8 bucks a plate? awwww yeeeaahhhh.   They have a good selection of vegetarian dishes, the curries looked pretty promising, and I'm pretty sure I was able to get 9 water refills before my meal even came...impressive.   Minus points because my buddy's shrimp paste fried rice smelled like a sulfur bomb from World War II, but overall I was pleasantly surprised by this low-key gem.  Would definitely re-experience
author: Satyan P.

description:
I have become all about this restaurant these last few weeks.  It's a new favorite.  I still particularly adore the Tom Kha Gai.  As a child, I ate tons of this stuff called Lucas.  It's a little shaker full of chili powder, citric acid, salt, and a little sugar.  The overwhelming sour/salty flavor gave me this visceral flavor high when I ate it.  Same with the Tom Kha Gai.  The intensity is almost too much, but it's exquisite.

Pad Kee-Mao (#66, spicy noodles with Chinese broccoli) is another favorite of mine.  The Pad King (#76, choice of meat with ginger, carrots, jalapeno, and black fungus) is great for anyone who loves ginger.  I just tried the Gang Panang Nuer (#52, beef in red curry) last night.  It was fantastic and may be my new favorite curry.  The beef had zero fat or gristle.  I've also tried the Roti dessert with ice cream.  It was flaky and wonderful, but I thought the ice cream didn't really mesh with the pancake.  I think it would have been better with some sweetened creme fraiche or as an appetizer with curry dipping sauce.  On its own, however, the coconut ice cream totally rocked.  I've only tried about five different varieties, but this was the best.  

I do have to mention the Por-Pier Sod (#2, rice paper rolls stuffed with sausage, egg, tofu, and cucumber, topped with crab meat and sour tamarind sauce).  It was actually revolting.  I expected a regular cool, refreshing rice paper roll.  What I got was two giant rolls served side by side like a couple of burritos, cut into slices crosswise.  They were served warm (!?!) and were drenched in this gross sweet gravy.  They were disgusting and impossible to eat.  I also dislike their Por-Pier Pak (#4, vegetarian egg rolls).  And their Peak Gai Tod (#9, fried chicken wings) just tasted weird.  Boyfriend joked that maybe they were from Thai chickens and while absurd, it rang true.

Even though I disliked those three dishes, I still adore Thai House Express.  And it's like magic- even though most their dishes cost the same $7-$8 that many other places do, the bill always comes to surprisingly little.  I don't want to know how, I just want to enjoy it.  Before I ate at Thai House Express, I thought that the number of Thai restaurants in the city was seriously ridiculous.  Now I get it.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Allison T said they had the best chicken with garlic rice here...........she wasn't lying.  Number 44 rocks!!!

Went there with a buddy of mine and wanted to try something different.  As we sat down and given our menu another waitress comes by with our water.  Love that!!!  And she came periodically to refill.  I always drink three glasses of water per meal.  If it gets refilled without me asking for it, they are on the ball.  

This is what we had.  

Fried Chicken with garlic rice( I will have the steamed chicken next time)
It was very good but this combination would've been better steamed.

Spicy minced chicken with basil and garlic over rice.  Perfect

Pork with special house sauce.  wasn't good

Portions were perfect and I just love it when the plastic containers for the peppers and hot sauce are not sticky.  That is such a pet peeve of mine.  Again.......you are in the TL...........so expect the location to be a little sketchy.  If you can get over that ..........the food is fantastic.
author: jason g.

description:
This is my favorite place to eat Thai... even though the area around it is ghetto, I still like coming here. Sometimes I make the trip from SSF just to eat here. 

I usually start off with the Toong Gern Yueng and finish it off with a rice plate. The majority of the time I end up ordering the barbecue marinated chicken ( Gai Yang ) just because I enjoy it so much. The combination seafood is also pretty good. 

The staff is also very attentive and at times suggested certain dishes, there are times when it is very busy... so it's understandable if they are not there right away.... 

I've been to the one on Castro... but it is just not the same

.... oh yeah... Parking sucks !!
author: Alex H.

description:
I am so glad that Pengrin posted that photo of the fried roti with the coconut ice cream.

Kainani, Steph and I had been doing multiple rounds of gmail, trying to figure where to eat before the DYL at Ambassador.  Remembering the admonishments of Librarian Bella, I didn't start a new thread but actually used the search function and found a thread on best restaurants in the Tenderloin.  Based on that, we narrowed it down to two Thai restaurants.  Seeing Pengrin's photo of the fried roti, I knew we had to eat here.

As usual, it's great to hang out with Steph.  And the jolliness was made jollier by Kainani visiting SF.  What a gal!  She's rocking SF (I am too old...can't keep up with her).  I was way too full from my mega lunch pho, and could only try little bites of the main courses which were duck salad and chicken pad thai.  The duck salad was amazing, absolutely delightful little bits of duck, red onion slices, and a spicy hotness that builds up and permeates the palate.  I give Thai House Express credit for making one of the least gloppy and more interesting Pad Thais I've had in my life thus far.

The dessert: okay, so despite my pho-fullness, I was doing all my efforts to digest so that I could eat the dessert.  And am I glad I held back on all the other courses.  Soooo goooood.  Fried roti, crispy with the sort of nice texture that comes sometimes from fried sweet rice.  I am not sure what they made their roti with, but that's what it reminded me of.  And the coconut ice cream went so well with it.  Originally we had ordered one to share...midway through:
Steph: I could eat more of this. 
Me: Should we order another?
Kainani: I can stop eating it now (putting down her spoon).
Me: I want more.  Waitress!
Kainani: Okay, then I am having more (picking up her spoon).

So the moral of this meal: don't share your dessert.  Get your own fried roti and coconut ice cream.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Its been a while since I had lunch here, but from what I can remember, the food was tasty if unremarkable.  Service can be a little off and for some reason, the waiters here like to wear their tight, tight hipster jeans real low.  Let's just say seeing a flash of underwear every time they bent over slightly (as in bending over to place dishes on the tables) can be a bit disconcerting.  

We started off with their appetizer special of the day- deep-fried won tons that were crisp and filled with a delicious blend of pork and shrimp.  As for the entrees, we had the Moo Prig King (old Thai style pork with green beans and chili paste), the Pad Se-ew (pan fried rice noodles chicken, egg and Chinese broccoli), Gai Yang (barbecue marinated chicken served with sticky rice) , and chicken Gang Dang (medium red curry sauce with mixed vegetables).  The Gai Yang was probably the least tasty of the four because the chicken was pretty dry.  The Pad Se-ew was okay, as was the red curry chicken.  The best dish of lunch was the Moo Prig King, which was absolutely awesome- the chili paste added just the right amount of heat to the sauce and the green beans were tender yet crisp.  Needless to say, we polished it all off.

I'd be back especially for the Moo Prig King if I were in the area again, though there's so many other choices in the surrounding blocks that I always forget about this restaurant.  Prices were reasonable for the portions and overall, it was a pleasant lunch.
author: Angela H.

description:
This is hands-down my favorite Thai restaurant in SF. I guess I'm somewhat of a Thai food snob being Thai, having grown up on Thai food and having lived in Thailand. Even my Thai parents, my Thai sister and my Thai husband love this place. We're all about authenticity and this place is it. The food isn't sweetened to satisfy American tastes.  This is as close as I've found to good ol' home-cooking.

I also like this place because they have food that's difficult to find in America. My favorite dish here is Tom Kha Gai, Thai hot. I will risk getting an ulcer for a nice, hot bowl of Tom Kha Gai. And it's not overpriced, not overposh.
author: Paweena P.

description: This place really impressed me with it's fast service, delicious food, and cheap prices. My friend's pork dish was really good (very tender meat!) and my pad see ew was delicious. Loved the plentiful crunchy veggies and the chicken wasn't dry as it is in some other places. Minus one star because the waiters are sometimes hard to flag down but that's understandable because the place is packed. The location is also great for pre-going out eating, as it is mere blocks from ambassador and 620 jones.
author: Joyce H.

description:
Four stars overall, five if you account for the cheap pricing.  Food is served fast, and dinner for two was under $20.  The thin egg noodles with pork were pretty tasty, and the peanut chicken was also very good.  A little sketchy - the big jars of Skippy in the back.  Do they really make the peanut sauce from what choosy mom's don't choose?  I always pictured a mortar and pistle and a stack of raw peanuts.  *sigh*
Will definitely be back here
author: Michael C.

description:
Please come here for COCKROACH and DIRT in/on your drink.

I do not write many reviews, but when a food providing establishment is unhygienic passed a certain point, it becomes my duty to write a yelp review to warn the community about the potential health issues that could arise from eating at such a place.

About 30 minutes ago, I ordered a red curry and a Thai Ice Tea to go from Thai House Express. When I reached there, they had the food ready and then began making the ice tea. I was on the phone so I was not paying full attention; when I walked out into the sunlight, I noticed a funny black object on the ice and under the cover of my tea. On a closer look, it turned out that it was a COCKROACH that was SMASHED BETWEEN THE ICE. Moreover, it was split into two parts!

I then asked for a soft drink instead. To my surprise, the can of coke was filled with dirt from the top, so much so that the color of the top of the can was black! Disgusted, I walked out of the restaurant and left both my food and the drink(s) at the counter; I would rather lose $12 to a restaurant then eat or drink Cockroach and Dirt!

I hope this review is helpful to those aspiring to eat some Thai food at Thai House Express; if you are not dissuaded enough by this review, please check your food before you eat, and check it carefully, and then by all means, enjoy.

YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!
author: Nikhil S.

description:
A landmark on Geary Street.  

Crossing the Tenderloin 4:30pm Saturday looking at all the little stores and restaurants nobody ever reviews ... and then on the northern border, a familiar place!  I knew it had been Yelped, but couldn't remember if it was good or bad.  We walked in.  

Nice, clean space, huge windows, lots of light.  Fast, pretty waitress who got the order right on the first pass.  Food was there in minutes, tasting yes, genuine Thai, just what we expected.  Margaret and I were trying to share the food, and the waitress brought over a couple of side plates.  

Bottom line:  Would I eat there again?   Absolutely!
author: David D.

description:
Decent food. Slow service and food didn't come together. When the last item came
out it was wrong, instead of green curry we got red. After about another minute we asked just to cancel because we didn't want to wait anymore. Approached manager or something who was curt and said it was coming in two minutes, and they already re-fired our order so just wait. OK, except she proceeded to tell us how we ordered wrong, my husband eats at this place about 3 times a week and always orders the same thing- green salmon curry. So I told the woman, no actually the server got it wrong she is proceeded to wave her arms and got real angry and told me no and she wasn't going to talk about it. Salmon comes out seconds later, they basically just re-plated the red sauce one, which is fine because it still tasted ok, but if you are gonna tell me you re-fired my order when you just replated it what else are you doing with the food? Salmon overcooked and didn't taste fresh but the eggplant was excellent. Also sever never brought our change was like a war or attrition we just said forget about it and left. Sad because this place was convienient for hubby but he did say the service was always kinda lame but this was last straw.
author: Charla R.

description:
I don't get it, why do people like this place?

I had the most greasy, yet bland Pad Thai of my life here. I had to squeeze 2 limes & pour some weird sauce on it just to get SOME flavor out of it & it still wasn't good.

The prices are good & the service is fast, but so what?!
author: Melisser E.

description:
I have never really had Thai cuisine before (unless you count the times at 4 a.m. coming back from the bar and reheating someone else leftovers).

I was pleasantly surprised with some of the dishes we ordered. I can't begin to tell you what we ordered (Pad ?), but the dish with the "black fungus" was def. interesting (I did have to ask the waiter if it was the same shit that grows on the ceiling of my bathroom and he did assure me it wasn't).

We ended up getting several dishes (beef/ginger, pumpkin curry, pork something and a whole fish - with head intact and all).

This place is in the tenderloin and is sort of a "hole in the wall". BUT, the place was filled and busy (Wednesday night) and everyone seemed to enjoy themselves. Service was prompt and friendly.

Def. opened up my taste buds and would recommend it to Thai enthusiasts or even first timers (like myself).
author: Rob H.

description:
After living in SF for 8 months, this is the place that has compelled me to write my first Yelp review. First off, thai food is my favorite kind of food. I love all food, but thai is that perfect combination of spicy, tasty, comfort and just pure contentment and satisfaction.

This is not the best thai I've ever had, but it is the best I've had in SF. Incidentally, the best thai food I've ever had (outside of bangkok, thailand) was in Ithaca, NY and Fairbanks, Alaska and not in places like New York City or LA! 

For food this place definitely beats out other SF favorites Thep Phanom, Osha, Yukol Palace and Marnee. That said, it is in the Tenderloin and as a result has a gritty bare bones ambience. My favorite dishes are any of the curries (especially the green), the stir fries (minced chicken with basil, peppers, and green onion), and the pork leg stew which will make you feel oh-so-cozy...as good as hot chocolate by a warm fire! I'm not a huge soup fan, but I've tried them here and they're good too.

The lack of the fifth star is for the lack of ambience and the slightly sketchy location; but this adds to the character. Besides, this food isn't associated with posh or loungey decor anyway. I go out of my way to get take out here at least once a week. 

Give this place a shot if you want intensely flavored, tasty thai food.
author: Alexander S.

description:
This is the best Thai food I've had. I came in the door after watching Bruno at the AMC and wasn't even close to hungry (after that movie, can you blame me?), but decided to order once I looked around and started smelling the delicious-ness that was on everyone else's plates.

Curry was amazing ... I had a tofu dish with vegetables and everything was cooked to perfection, not drenched in sauce or overcooked, but nice and crisp. The pad thai my girlfriend had was very, very good as well ... the best I've ever had in fact.

Only complaint was since there isn't any fabric or material that absorbs sound, the restaurant was unpleasantly loud, making conversation difficult. Then again, who needs conversation when you've got great food.
author: Brian B.

description:
The spicy prik king is fantastic - particularly fresh snap beans, perfect fried tofu, no holding back on the heat. The only mistake I made was not ordering the "a la carte" version which I didn't realize would have replaced the large serving of rice with about twice as much of the good stuff.

They were out of the Phuket lager, but fast friendly service and great flavours more than made up for it.
author: Alex B.

description:
Thai = Yum
House = Shelter
Express = Fast

And...ummm, I'm trying to think of a clever punch line but can only imagine eating great inexpensive yum food by the window watching the trannies, drunks, and  homeless parade back and forth on Larkin.

Life is good.
author: greg e.

description:
#50, Chicken in yellow curry is my favorite.  Salmon Curry in green or red is fabulous too.  This has become a place I eat at once a week.  It's right around the corner from my house, always fast, always fresh, always great food.  The service is fabulous too, the staff is fast, refills your drinks, brings your check, and is very attentive.

I would have easily given them 5 if their prices were a tad lower.
author: Mary R.

description:
So lately, I haven't been the best at budgeting. In an attempt to achieve fiscal responsibility in the 2k7, I've been cutting back and meals out are a big target. Instead of decadent FiDi salads and such, I've been making shitty peanut butter sandwiches and throwing them in my purse for work. Needless to say, with lunches like these, I'm trying to make my dinners count. 

After a tough work week, I decided to reward myself by taking a detour and treating myself to dinner out at a place outside of my usuals. So after reading the reviews on this place, I was psyched on it and effin' starving.

Greeting me in the outside doorway was a rather sooty, red-eyed young man with what appeared to be large smears of blood all over this shirt. And by greeting, I mean shuffling around aimlessly with his mouth half open. But hey, it's the TL,  I expect that. What I didn't really expect  was to pay 20 bucks for my diet coke, super greasy spring rolls and unappetizingly spicy basil chicken.

I have to admit, I already have annoyance directed torwards OMG SPICY!!! MORE HEAT!!!  MAKE IT NON WHITE PERSON SPICY LOL! people who think that just because a restaurant will jack up the heat, it's good. I like a bit of spice (I requested medium) but I'd actually like to taste something besides chilis and oil in my food, you pompous asses.

2 stars because service was super fast, portions were large for the price of the entree (my spring rolls cost almost as much as my entree, which was whack)  and the food was still edible. I'd probably go back  if I was in the hood to try something else on the extensive menu- but I'd be requesting mild like the wussy white person I am, thanks.
author: jessica s.

description:
I try to give out 5 stars only for the places that truly deserve it.  I actively try NOT to give out five stars because it means there's hardly anything wrong with the establishment... and not too many places can claim that.  Truth be told, Thai House Express can't claim that either. 

But they do have one thing that overshadows everything else: the best damn shrimp pad thai in the city.  I could sit there all day and just keep smurfing down that shrimpy goodness.  It's perfection re-invented and if I wasn't already a non-believer it would warrant the start of its own religion.  Forget L Ron Hubbard...

I could go on and on about the shrimp pad thai, but you guys want to know more, right?  Well, the food comes out quick.  If I wasn't able to see the chef's making the food, I'd swear they were pre-prepared.  It's almost inhuman.  The wait staff isn't friendly, but they aren't obnoxious, either.  Generally, they stay out of your way.  No serious amount of conversation will be had between you and your waiter.  They won't be your friends, but you won't hate them; they blend in to the background.  The ambience is simple and to the point.  There are chairs, chopsticks, spices, and utensils at every table.  

And food.

Did I mention the shrimp pad thai is amazing?

Stop reading this right now and go there... right now.
author: Kurt C.

description: I ordered takeout tonight at about 7:30. I was told by a really nice girl that it would take about 40 min. I was surprised to see the delivery guy about 20 min later. Ordered the veggie egg rolls and pad Thai. I was thoroughly impressed.
author: Ryan M.

description: Pad Thai was 5 stars. Pumpkin Curry 4 1/2 stars. Steak Salad 4 stars. All very good! Medium spicy just the right amount.
author: Jen J.

description:
LOVE this place for some delicious good-priced Thai. My  friends and I have had nearly everything on the menu, and we've yet to be disappointed. I've eaten at both the Tenderloin location and the Castro one, and they're both good - Tenderloin is definitely more 'Loin in atmosphere, and Castro is more sit-down nice. And clean.

Food is FAST. We've gone in with 10 people and no reservations while it was pretty busy, but most of our dishes were out within 10 minutes. Yes, the service is pretty non-existent and takes twice as long for you to have your order taken then for your food to come out, but compare that with other places, then it comes out about even.

HIGHLY recommend their Khao Kha Moo (braised pork leg stew). I've yet to find this ANYWHERE else, and it is melt-in-your-mouth-OMG-I'm-deliriously-happy good.

Depending on when you go, it can vary from being packed with a 30 minute wait to nearly empty. Go early in the evening to avoid a wait. Later on, it's filled with pre-Polk Street partiers.
author: D k.

description: Today I had the woon sen soup.  I must say that this soup had its share of the silver noodles, but what made it truly awesome and satisfying were all the vegetables that I did not expect to see.  Truly a meal in itself, perfect on a cold night or if you come in really late.
author: Joe N.

description: I've been here a few times they're decent if you're just in the mood for a little Thai food, I don't think they're menu selection is that great I've had better if you're in the mood for something besides noodles & fried rice this ISN'T the place you're looking for.
author: Naz M.

description:
My friend was suggesting our dinner at Thai House Express last night, and when he mentioned that the place was on Geary and Larkin, I immediately thought, "Ah, on the edge of the Tenderloin.." As we walked down Geary from Van Ness, we were hassled a few times by some bums mingling about. Hmm...

But reaching Thai House Express was like finding a "diamond in the rough" as that saying goes. The place was fairly quiet since we arrived roughly around 6:30; I'm convinced now that most San Franciscans choose to eat out for dinner around 7 or so. Anyway, we were promptly seated, our orders were taken, and food was served in less than ten minutes. But it wasn't like they were trying to usher us out quickly; the atmosphere itself is mellow and relaxing. Dim lights, moderate level of noise. We stuck around for around an hour or so (our usual time to eat dinner and sit and chat), and the servers didn't seem to be in a hurry to get us out the door.

The food was pretty good; piping hot and full of flavor. We ordered Chan Pad Poo (#38), which is stir fried spicy Thai noodles with Dungeness crab meat, egg, and green onions. I was able to choose how spicy I wanted the noodles, and I opted for "hot"; wasn't as spicy as I'd like it, but it still had a good kick. We also ordered Gang Ga-Ree Gai (#50), which was sliced chicken in a mild yellow curry paste with potatoes. The curry sauce accidentally splashed on my shirt a little, but that was fine with me (yay for Thrift Town clothes!). We were both scarfing down the food pretty quickly, due to both our hunger and how delicious the food was.

Thai House Express's menu itself is pretty extensive: over 100 menu items, with a good selection of appetizers, salads, soups, noodles, and even a decent sized selection of vegetarian dishes. Prices are a little more on the "expensive" side of Thai food, but two people can still manage to polish off a meal (with dessert) at $25 or so.

Dessert was either Roti (Thai sweet pancake) or the ever-popular, ever-common Fried Banana with ice cream. We opted for the Roti with Coconut ice cream, which was a good choice to sweeten and round out the meal. We both left Thai House Express feeling very satisfied with our meal.

I certainly wish Thai House Express was not located in the TL though, since I usually prefer not to dine in that area of town.....oh well, at least I wasn't dining alone. =)
author: Helene K.

description:
You Yelpers love this place. Can't get enough of it. Say it's one of your favorite Thai restaurants in the city, even.

Clearly, my experience was unlike the rest of you. Pity.

Now, I'm not expecting fine-dining, white-tablecloth service at a place like this. Far from it. But it could be described here as lackadaisical at best. I wasn't given a menu when I sat down, and waited and waited for one to appear. Finally, I gave up and got one myself. My water glass sat empty for a long time, and nobody ever came back to check on me once the food came out. All this in a near-empty establishment. 

I ordered the Pra Ram, which is a dish that comes with vegetables, peanut sauce, and your choice of meat. I ordered the chicken. Unfortunately, it was very unappealing visually. The chicken had been cut into thin strips and then boiled, which lent it a disturbingly pale and rubbery appearance. On top of these snowy white strips was a gluey, orange-brown sauce. A few vegetables hid beneath the chicken. I took a bite and was overwhelmed by the sweetness of the peanut sauce. I had to add heaping teaspoons of dried chili flakes to make it tolerable. Obviously, I ordered the wrong thing here.

The final straw came after I'd eaten maybe one-third of it and found a hair in my food. Blech.

Not wanting to start any kind of hassle - clearly, the staff here could care less about my experience - I paid the bill and left. 

So here's the deal. Anyone who knows me knows that my mom is Thai. I was born in Bangkok, and have spent a lot of time in Thailand. While that doesn't make me an expert by any means, perhaps I'm more critical than some. Besides the obvious fact that there was a hair in my food (and let's be fair, it happens sometimes), I didn't like my dish at all.

Thai House Express earns an extra star because I'm guessing that it was all just a fluke. The hair, the dish, and the service. 

Am I willing to try again and find out? 
Meh...
author: Jasmine W.

description:
I may have passed this restaurant 100,000 times (on the way home), and never once had I considered stopping to eat here.

There are a few reasons for this:
-it's location
-it's location
-it looks like a cheap Thai place in the TL...

So, when we walked in here last night I was pleasantly surprised.  The decor was nicer inside than the outside let on.  It was warm, and somewhat modern.  We were seated right away, and didn't really have to wait too long before they took our order.

for appetizer we got the fried chive cakes with sauce 
for soup tom yum goong
for entrees we got the red curry with beef and the green beans with fried tofu.

The appetizer I would not get again, it was pretty much what it sounds like...fried chives, so it was slimy and weird inside, not a good consistency and pretty bland as well.  I know it was a vegetarian option, but I think it would have been way better with ground beef inside...cut down on the slimy factor at least.

The tom yum goong was amazing...really spicy (my lips were tingling!) and super flavorful.  I loved it.  i would make the trek back for their soup alone.

As for the entrees, well, I liked the green beans and fried tofu a lot, it was slightly citrus in flavor, not heavy either.  The curry, eh, I just may have not been in the right mood for it.  It was good, I just didn't feel as though it was anything special.

The dishes on the tables next to us looked delicious as well, so I will definitely be coming back here...I just wish it weren't in the heart of crackville usa...

I want to give it four stars, but it just didn't display anything super special that would warrant four...we were able to park quickly, and order quickly, which were both nice; but it is in the TL, and the chive cakes weren't that great...so eh, this is a tough one, but I feel like this was just an ordinary Thai joint.
author: Kristin E.

description:
Another Thai spot that gets my seal of approval. Amazingly delicious food and super fast! Although it really doesn't taste that fast at all. They have their act together. 

The curries are great. And the crispy pork-- my mouth is watering.

Great late night as well!
author: Jon N.

description:
Just got back from a trip to Asia, which included Thailand and this place is very close to the Thai food I had on my trip.  Of course, it's not an exact match, but it's damn close enough.  Especially their papaya salad.  The only thing Thai House Express can change to make it closer to authentic Thai food from Thailand would be to make their own noodles.  

My favorite here is #69...the flat rice noodles with minced meat (choice of chicken, beef, pork OR vegetarian)...tossed in a curry sauce.  You can order as spicy as you like.  Just a warning though...the medium in their spicyness might be too spicy for most people.
author: Selene K.

description:
Thai House Express located on Larkin Street is a good thai restaurant. Location is not the greatest in San Francisco, but these days, authentic thai food can only be found in the Tenderloin.  Anyway, the food here is good and the selection is quite large.  If you like curry, this is the place. The yellow curry here is very good. Duck salad (special) is also very good here. They even will make Kai Jew Moo Sub (Scamble egg and pork -- basic thai dish) here too. Kana pra kem is also good too.. :)

With 104 selection on the menu, you can't go wrong.
author: Atiwat K.

description:
When I have one of those "oh-my-man-oh-man-I-need-some-SERIOUS-Thai-food...NOW."  That's when you go to Thai House Express.  I have been a total of three times, and I must say, each and every time I was not dissapointed.  The first time, I was totally creeped out by the area that it was in, all ternderloiny, dodging crackheads in the freezing cold, all the while trying to get into a place that I had never been before.  As soon as I walked in, I knew everything would be fine, the Thai food wafting in the air and Family Guy on the T.V. I was already subdued from the chaos outside, got me some kapao gai and had a taste of some kateow laad naa, happy happy joy joy.

Second time, I went on my own for lunch, got some kateow laad na, and some sticky rice and mango.  The laad na is just too good, you HAVE to try it, that is some serious Thai food going on right here.  I waddled out a happy happy camper.

Third time, we were doing laundry, but had a craving for some Thai, so we threw our clothes into the washers, poured our detergent, and drove like mad peeps getting to Geary and Larkin (with some quizzical "where the hell are we?!"s along the way).  We had decided to get take out, were five minutes out, called and ordered and were told that it would take ten minutes for our katoew laad nah, yum woonsen and sen yai kee maow gai.  We made it there faster than expected, ran in and asked if we could eat there instead.  No problem.  We sat down, and our food came out immediately, piping hot and tasting amazing.  We then got fried banana with coconut, devoured and waddled our asses out of there to make it back to Brainwash to finish our laundry (with some more "What the hell is this street?!"s.)
author: Asha H.

description:
Don't think twice about going....this is one of the best thai restaurants i've been to. They are quick to serve your food, which is consistently yummy. My favorites are the underrated kao soi which is just so rich and filling.I  believe it's #42 on menu (can you tell i go here often?) .If you order this dish get it with combination seafood instead of chicken, the chicken tends to be a little on the dry side. Other favorites include the Tom Yum soup, or any of their curries. 
So why 3 stars instead of 5? They used to close at 1:30 or 2 am or something like that. Perfect for the night owl in me, and now I have to be sure to get there before 12. The other reason is that I have been underwhelmed by the dryness in the  chicken dishes, and their papaya salad is not my favorite.
author: X marks the spot ..

description:
Upon first glance, I would never expect to see thai food in the middle of the TL. But then again, they have vietnamese restaurants all over. It's pretty spacious, and has great food. One of the dishes we had was "spicy" and I kid you not, it was mouth on fire spicy so beware. It's no wonder the wait staff is constantly doing laps around the restaurant with pitchers of water and refilling everyone's cup to relieve the spiciness in your mouths. Smart move, ladies and gents.

The usual thai dishes were solid. Nothing was okay or horrible. Good flavors, very reasonable prices and huge portions. I would go back.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Excellent Thai food. I love the curries. All the food is great here. The atmosphere is decent and the service is satisfactory. I suggest teir specialtes or daily specials.

The noodles are great too. All the appetizers and yummy as well. The neighborhood is kinda rough sometimes, but well worth the "risk". :)
I love Thai food and this place is really tops!
author: jamie c.

description:
I don't understand why people rave about this place so much. The main reason I stop by is that it's on my way home. Anyway, decent but not brag worthy. 

I prefer Chai-Yo when I want a casual, quick place for Thai food.
author: Shawn T.

description:
this place rocks.  If you ask for spicy - it's real.  no joke.

i think the non noodle dishes are the stand outs.  Kao Ka Moo.  This is the place to get adventurous.  I did order the raw sausage - it was a bit too adventurous for me.

all in all best thai in town - marnee and osha are close seconds.
author: suckafree c.

description:
I've been eating here for about 4 years now, out of the 6 I've lived in SF. The best Thai in town. Ok, maybe not THE BEST, but for the price, i think it's one of my favorite places to eat some damn good thai. I also love Basil, Thep Phanom, but this place is the absolute jam!!! I would pick this over anywhere else. Every time we have guests in town to DJ our parties, I always petition to take them here, and they always love it. My girlfriend and I are here at least 3 times a month.

I used to live around the corner and would eat the Panang Curry with beef a couple of times a week, these days I hardly ever go without ordering the Yellow Chicken Curry, It's always so thick and the chicken is choice. I love the appetizer #1. I forget what it's called, but it's some kinda pouch thingy. Basically little deep fried pouches of spiced curried ground chicken, tied off with little seaweed bows. The Thai beef jerky was an incredible surprise, and if you're looking for something basic, i'd go with the Pad Kee Mao. It comes super spicey, so if you're not into that, make sure to ask for mild. The Larb is amazing as well. 

I also highly recommend the mint lemonade. But be prepared to order two, and at around $4 if you're on a budget, I'd just avoid them all together. You'll be too hooked to watch your $.

Only flaw? No delivery. I think they'd probably need a fleet to cover all their deliveries. This place has a LOT of fans.

Oh, and they're open relatively late, which is friggin awesome.
author: Alland B.

description:
I honestly didn't think that this thai place was anything special.  

We tried a few different dishes and the only one that was better than just decent was the peanut curry tofu.  Other than that i wouldn't eat there again.
author: megan t.

description: The food's pretty good, the service not so much. The Kao Moo Dang is great but the portions were small and only served to build up our appetite.
author: Danny K.

description:
Great Pad- See Ew, Tom Kha Gai, and Gang khew wan curry, and I'm picky about my food.

Service is super quick and friendly, 

Prices are reasonable, but parking was somewhat difficult for me.
author: Nancy S.

description: My fam, bf, and I went here after watching a movie. I love how it's open late! Their pad kee mao and gai gra-praw were really good! Their pra ram was a little too lemony. Theyre always refilling your water too! Overall good place to eat.
author: Yvette N.

description:
Dont be put off by the EXPRESS- nothing fast-food about this place...Luv the Green Curry chicken (I think its better than the yellow curry)...Appetizers...garlic chicken wings or the vegetarian spring rolls...THe Tom Yum soup- is probably the best in town...hot hot hot!
My all time fav is their fried fish fillets with string beans with the garlic rice as well :-)
PS I didnt like the duck over rice- it seemed a bit soggy, and TOO oily...probably chicken is better
author: Arissa C.

description: This place need to move to better neighborhood. We checked on yelp and decided to try there. The food was pretty good. Pork leg stew is really tasty. Thanks yelpers for the recommendation. Tom kha soup is good as well. The service is pretty decent an the food came out very quick. Would go back again.
author: Win S.

description:
I love their Tom Kha Ghai!  Its great for when you have a cold...seriously, it cleared my lungs out and i could actually breathe!

I live two blocks from this place and dont actually dine in...i call ahead and pick the order up.  The staff is usually pretty friendly.  They are always busy, but i have never had to wait too long for an order!

Not the most authentic thai out there..but yummy nonetheless!
author: Ripley B.

description:
Ultra casual, but great food and definitely great prices.  Arrive with friends and an appetite, but expect to be filled to the point where going out afterwards is no longer an option.  Yes, this is even if you're sharing...which you should definitely do.

When you order the Papaya Salad, maybe go for mild, because medium spicy burnt my taste buds off.  Luckily, the pumpkin curry cooled my tongue enough that I could enjoy my last bites.  I would give this place 5 stars, but need another visit or two before I get too crazy with the stars.  At any rate, it was some of the best Thai food I've ever tasted.
author: Shaina P.

description:
My favorite Thai place EVER!!  I can't get enough!!   Everything is so delicious here!!  The food comes out super quick--so its perfect when you're HANGRY!!  And on top of that, the prices are great, and they deliver!!!   

There's nothing I'd change about this place--okay maybe its location so its out of the loin and closer to me!! :)
author: Anna L.

description:
Simple, flavorful and affordable is what I can describe this place.  Can't remember how many times have I visit this Thai Express, considering it's such a pain to find a parking in the City.  I was introduced to this eatery by my Thai co-worker and ever since then, I have eaten there and drag my friends over for countless occassions.  

Not a fancy place to Whow! your guest, but food is great and fast.  I love all the curry dishes they got, not to mention the yummy mango with sticky rice dessert..........worth visit!
author: Alice L.

description:
Ordinarily I dont mind the tenderloin district if I am going to Bang San to get my thai fix.The buzz I get after eating the spiciest most amazing culinary delights Ameena has to offer is other worldly.
But the food at Thai House express is certainly not worth running into junkies, all of which look like they are about to assault you.

We ordered:
Gra prow Basil with chicken,asked for very spicy and the dish that came out had the spice level bland enough even for a 2 year old.
Prik Khing with tofu- This one had a miniscule amount of flavor but no depth at all.

We ordered our dishes over rice and the portions were ok.The thai iced tea was the saddest I have ever had.But service was good.

Next time you want thai food late at night, head over to Bang San Thai on Jones instead.
author: Vrushali N.

description:
Thai House was a bit of a disappointment.  Four stars?  I don't think so.  It's more like a Thai diner than it is a restaurant, with an inhospitable dining room, loud and echoey, cold and complacent.  Given the mediocrity of most Thai restaurants in the Bay Area, Thai House is better than many of them, but that doesn't make it exceptional.

On the positive side, I didn't detect MSG -- which is not to say they don't use it, but if they do, it wasn't overbearing.  It's also open until midnight, which may have something to do with its loyal ratings considering that there aren't many options at that time of night in San Francisco or beyond.

The food was okay.  It wasn't great, but it wasn't terrible.  I ordered the vegetarian spring rolls as an appetizer, which were full of a variety of vegetables and noodles.  They were also nicely plump, more of a hybrid between a Chinese spring roll and a Thai one.  The flavor was a little funky, though, and I would attribute it to the possibility of over-used oil.  Nothing rancid, mind you, but influenced by the flavors and aromas of what came before.  

My entree was a red salmon curry, Thai spicy.  The salmon was overcooked.  The red curry was flat, with no zest or body.  It was not spicy either.  When I order a Thai curry, I usually ladle the curry over whatever rice I have left to enjoy the remaining richness.  Here, I was not so inclined.  No brown rice option either, and while I usually love white Jasmine rice (even though I always opt for brown, if available), this tasted more like Uncle Ben's.

The service was terrible.  While the food comes out quickly -- very quickly -- the servers were neither attentive nor responsive.  It took about fifteen minutes to flag a waitress to take my order, and despite several requests for my bill, no one brought it.  "Anything else?"  -- "Just the check."  But then they'd go about their business as if I weren't there.  Weird.

The ambiance doesn't exist.  
The service -- or what one would call what I observed -- was terrible.
The food was okay, but certainly nothing to write home about.

If I were writing only about the food, it'd be 2. stars.
Ambiance is 1 star.
Service is 1 star.

Overall:  1.5 stars.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description:
I live less than a block from here and have walked past it a million times thinking it was just another crappy place in the neighborhood and not really giving it much thought.

For some reason, my partner and I decided to check it out a couple weeks ago and we were pleasantly suprised.  We returned yesterday and it confirmed that this is much better than average.

The food is flavorful with large portions.  They are also more thoughtful than average about presentation and actually seem to care how the food looks and tastes.  

The service didn't really fit the "Express" in the name - it was kind of slow....but I am willing to wait for a good dish and the deep-fried calamari appetizer was a good hold over.

Yesterday we had lunch there and it was delicious again.

If you're like me and live in the neighborhood because you're of a certain income, it might be a little expensive for you, but its not ridiculous.  For lunch (with an appetizer) we spent about $35.  Again - not something I can do every day, but you do get your money's worth.
author: Daniel H.

description: The restaurant has not good ambiance and inside is very loudly that you are not be able to talk eachother. Also the waitress are not polite but the dishes delicious!!! Although I have not liked the restaurant I will get there again , again for delicious dishes!!
author: Hulya Y.

description:
So we met up some visiting friends in the City and I was like ooo, good opportunity to try this place.  We were walking around and as I got my NFT out to check the location, this oldguy all the sudden is like "EXCUSE ME, DO YOU NEED HELP? WHERE Ya NEED TO GO?"

I'm like we're cool and then he sees where I wrote Thai House Express on my map.
Oldguy is like "Why the hell you want to go to Thai House Express!?!"  He is so disgusted and I say cuz I've heard its good.  oldguy says "They don't know what they're talking about.  That place is just ok.  10 other places just as ok as that one in the area."  

The whole time this guy is talking all we can do is stare at his nose hair.  Its so huge, its like broccoli comin' out of his nose!! I aint lyin!!
So I say "Well, where should we go?" and hes all flabbergasted that I don't know.  He says "The last good place closed 5 years ago.  Believe me I know! I used to live in Thailand!"  And with that, Broccoli nose saunters out of our life.  

Well on that note, we were ready for this place to be awesome to show BN up!  BUT, sadly Broccoli-nose can smell an ok place out.  

One of us got the Pork Leg Stew with Rice, and I got the Pork Leg Stew Soup.  There was curry and Gai-ga prow had as well.  Everything was totally Meh!  

Damn you, Broccoli-Nose!  Please come back and lead us to a decent Thai restaurant.  For we have still not found one to match up to YAI's in LA.  sniff sniff
author: eliza k.

description:
3.5 open till 12.  in comparing Lers Ros, Sai Jai, and here, I like them in that order.  came for the special pork leg stew with pickled veggie over rice and the crispy pork with garlic and pepper.
the pork leg stew was too sweetened for me (need to work on the sweet/salty ratio), but the crispy pork was fried very nicely.  it's not like the "wet crunchy" crispy basil pork style, but instead is more like country fried steak in strips.  the meat is still moist inside through.  extensive menu
author: Rob C.

description: I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by Thai House Express. I went here with in a group of six because of its close proximity to the Regency Ballroom where we were going to see a concert. There's a parking garage around the corner from the restaurant & it's walking distance from the venue. It turned out to be a good choice. Although the place was very crowded we were served our food amazingly fast--despite the fact that we required several separate checks and had a fairly large order. The pad thai was excellent, as was the vegetable green curry and the spicy papaya salad. Although it wasn't as good as my personal favorite My Thai in San Rafael, it was definitely tasty, fresh, and satisfying and with their convenient location I know I'll be grabbing dinner there again before I head of to another concert on Van Ness.
author: Juneko R.

description:
My favorite Thai place in all of the Bay Area (so far). I am rating it solely on the food, because if I were to take into consideration the location and the scary local population, the score would drop slightly, as it is located in the unsavory Tenderloin. But the food always brings me back.

I have only ever eaten maybe three different main courses because what they do well, MAN do they do it well. Their Tom Kha soup is delicious, spicy and smooth. I like to get it with tofu rather than chicken because I think the texture works better, and the tofu absorbs the coconut milk and matches well with the straw mushrooms, cabbage, and greens. 

With it, I always get the Chan Pad Pu, which used to only be on the specials menu, but is now integrated into the regular menu, and I would like to think it is because it is absolutely transcendent. I usually prefer the chow fun noodles, but this is cooked with the thinner Pad Thai style noodles in a kind of creamy tamarind sauce, and it has LUMP CRAB MEAT in it. I believe it's Dungeness crab, and every single time I have ordered it (which is many, many times), there have been giant pieces that are sweet and moist and exquisite.

I have also have a variety of their appetizers, all of which have been good. Their naked shrimp are interesting, and I enjoy their fried egg rolls, though they are nothing special. Their papaya salad is pretty tasty, as is their squid salad, and they cook their squid very well. 

I have never experienced rudeness among the waitstaff, and although they are a bit brusque, they have never said anything rude to me, and my food always came out in a timely manner. I wish it would just move to a safer location because it's always a little harrowing to walk there either from BART or my car.
author: Mea H.

description:
A million Thai restauarants have popped up since I moved to the city 10 years ago.  Back then, it seemed like there were only a handful of Thai choices and this is one of the first Thai restaurants I was introduced to.  The other two were King of Thai (back when they only had two locations on Irving St.) and Osha Thai (at their original location on Leavenworth).  

Well, I've tried many of the new places and they pretty much suck.  King of Thai's quality has gone down. And Osha... what the hell happened to Osha?  It got all glamorous on me.  

I'm glad Thai House hasn't changed much in the past decade. The food still takes center stage... except for the occasional crackheads that barge in, but whateves.
author: Erick A.

description:
I was a bit skeptical about this restaurant due to the location...not the greatest in SF. However, it goes to show that you shouldn't judge a place by where it's located...especially in SF. 

Upon entering, I noticed that it was Zagat rated...good sign already, but I would still have to see if it was good. The menus were those cheap plastic menus that you typically get in bad Asian restaurants. However, once the food got there, I was blown away!

We ordered the Spicy Minced Chicken and the Crab Fried Rice. There were two of us...and it was more than enough food for us. The rice actually had decent sized chunks of crab. The real winner was the minced chicken...we ordered it medium spicy, and it was great! Wonderful flavor...went really well with the fried rice. I'm definitely going back to try the other items on the menu. You should try it too!
author: Samir P.

description:
One of the best Thai restaurants in the city. Not pretentious. Authentic, fresh, tasty food that won't cost you $$$ like the other wanna-be-upscale thai-fusion restaurants. Open late. What more could you ask for?

I didn't rate this place 5 stars because they don't make my benchmark Thai dish gai kapraw (spicy minced basil chicken) quite perfect, but pretty close. Also, the stewed pork is awesome... something you MUST try if you eat here. For appetizers, I like the rolls covered with rice paper and topped with crab meat... yummy!
author: Sunny Y.

description:
T.H.E. is my favorite Thai food in the city. I lived in Bangkok for 2 years and this place has the best gra prow around. Don't forget to add the fried egg on top! King of Thai restaurants are a close second when it comes to gra prow. 

Go there with as many friends as possible so you can order more food and share. Other tasty dishes are the roast pork with vegetables and the gang ga ree gai - yellow curry with chicken and potatos. Yumm. Aroy Mak Mak! Only downside is the neighborhood, and parking sometimes is a challenge. Geary and Larkin doesn't mess around.
author: Bobby G.

description:
My favorite thai food place in the city. Their curries are really rich. Their vegitarian dishes are great. My favorite dish is Tofu Pad Ga-Prow; fried tofu with peppers, onions, and basil. Their fried tofu in peanut sauce is also really good as is their fried chicken on fried rice. Oh, and their desserts! Fried Banana with ice cream (try to get coconut if they have it) and Mango Sticky rice are a great compliment at the end of a spicy meal.

Thai house express is average priced. You used to get a lot more food, but they've cut back on their portions a little in the last few months. It can also get a bit busy at nights.
author: Aaron M.

description:
My friend told me that she and her boyfriend eat here all the time, and now I know why. 

I was in the mood for spicy, noodles, rice and perhaps a good curry sauce but the secret hole-in-the-wall amazing restaurant Yamo's (in the Mission) is closed on Sunday. Lucky for me, or else I wouldn't have discovered Thai House Express. I am rarely in the Tendernob area of SF but it was worth it.

All of the dishes have names like Gang Ga-Ree Gai (the yellow curry chicken - AMAZING) so it's hard to remember what I ate. The noodles with crab meat were delicious. 

Note: If you haven't already done so, I'd check out their website (but turn off the volume on your computer first). It's pretty funny that their website is so nice (aka heavy use of Flash) considering that the place was definitely NOT fancy. But hey, 90% of the people eating there were Asian so you know it has to be good. I mean that in the best way.
author: Hannah L.

description:
OK food, great portions in a pretty lively restaurant.

The only thing that keeps it from getting 4 stars is the service.  It took forever for the server to get back to us after we'd been seated.  And I didn't get  one refill on my soda, which is the key to getting me to tip generously.

Regardless, it wasn't a bad experience.  I had the garlic rice & boiled chicken.  I should have had the grilled chicken, as I frequently find that places have the problem of their boiled chicken tasting like soap...which this did.

We decided to have dessert with a healthy portion of coconut ice cream and fried bananas....mmmmm!!!  So awesome, it's worth the return visit just for that!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
My name is Milton Waddams, and I approve of Thai House Express. In fact, I think it is awesome. 

/end SNL scene

Thai House Express is great. I've been there twice, and both times, the food was delicious. Fresh, actually spicy, and authentic. In particular, I loved the curries. 

The restaurant has a very cool atmosphere, which seems out of place in this particular neighborhood. In fact, sitting by the ultra-large windows with my friend, and watching all the bums and panhandlers walk by in the early evening is truly a surreal experience. You feel like you're at a theater, watching a production / social commentary on socio-economic inequality.

After all, there we were, sitting there enjoying this fine meal with our nice clothes in a nice restaurant, and there are people walking by who really have nothing, peering in the window with vacant eyes. For me, watching this act unfold into its unfortunate reality was difficult. But, you know, the sad part is that I bet most people don't even notice. 

/end deep thoughts
author: Frank B.

description: Ok so the location in the tenderloin might not be the best but once you are inside its great!  The ambiance is good for what I expected and there are beautiful orchids everywhere.  Prices are reasonable and the food was delicious.  Lately i've become a fan of thai food and since i moved to SF there are soooooooooo many options.  I recommended this place to some friends that needed a bite to eat while I got ready and they came back raving about the place.  I recommended it because it was always full so I assumed they were good.  I went for the first time today and we got sat instantly.  Both the server and food runners were good.  Best pad thai I have had anywhere hands down! (remember I just recently became a fan and this is the my first visit to a Thai restaurant here in SF, i've been to plenty in SD)  Pad Thai was amazing and reasonably priced (around $9 with Chicken) probably the best pad Thai I have ever had.  My friend and I shared this plate, and another full entree of Mod Tod (deep fried pork $10.00) with sweet and sour and a side plate of fried rice ($2.50).  Needless to say everything was delicious and super cheap.  Our meal came out to be $13 each and we were both full by the end of the meal with a little left over.  I would def recommend!  Try the Thai Iced tea....really good..too bad they didn't have boba that would have topped it off.
author: Claudia G.

description: Hot, fresh, quick. I consulted Yelp to locate a Thai place near where I found myself tonight. I was not disappointed, for the most part. But I can't figure out why so many Yelpers recommended the pork leg stew. It was only "okay". Yes it was tender, but there wasn't much taste. I reached for the salt shaker after a few bites. We were sharing platters so I was quite happy with a red curry we ordered. The rice noodle wrap with Chinese sausage was lovely, as well.
author: Paula H.

description: I must say I don't eat a lot of places because of the location it's at. I live about 15-20 min away from the place. Regardless of the first two statements, I love this place. I mean their sense of Thai food is different than the other Thai corporate restaurants. I love their Thai house fried rice w/ fried chicken. The batter on their chicken is great and the fried rice is not salty. The rice has great seasoning. Also any noodle orders are great as well. When I'm craving Thai food, this is the spot I think of first.
author: Matt B.

description:
This is the best Thai Restaurant in town! I always go there for my favorites. The service is fast and friendly and there's hardly a long wait time if any at all. The great thing about this place is they use fresh and quality ingredients. Chicken is actual breast meat and tastes like chicken unlike some other places that use dark meat and hardly taste like chicken.

1. Beef Salad
2. Pumpkin Curry w/ Beef or Chicken
3. Pad Thai w/ Chicken
4. Tom Yum Noodle Soup with Flat Rice Noodle - DELISH!!!
5. Calamari
6. Larb w/ Chicken
7. Papaya Salad with Dried Shrimp
author: Mai G.

description:
First of all, it's not in Nob Hill, it's in the 'Loin. Second, it's awesome! Delicious, fresh ingredients and VERY inexpensive with large portions. One entree is enough for two people to share or one person to hog up the leftovers at home. Average entree with rice is $7 or $8.

The spicy dishes are VERY spicy (and delicious) and the Param Pak (Crispy tofu and veggies in peanut sauce) is perfecto. My favorite cheap, delicious, neighborhood joint.
author: ms. jared g.

description:
I went again and the catfish larb was even better. It came warm and I wrapped the catfish in the cabbage leaves. Yummy!

Also tried the steamed pompano fish with secret lime dressing. It was delicious but you have to fillet it yourself. It arrives on the table whole and looks beautiful.

My friends loved the pad thai but I thought it was too sweet.

The fried banana has a lot of dough around each banana but doesn't taste too doughy. One order is huge - big enough for 4 people. The mango sticky rice has a good amount of mango and is tasty.
author: Marina N.

description:
i can truly say that this is my favorite thai restaurant in san francisco to date. and this is coming from someone who spent her entire adolescence living in bangkok. 

the price is right. 
with an entree each, splitting an appetizers and a dessert, the total bill comes out to $12 per person for the group of four. that is cheap when other places serve $12 entrees. 

street food love! 
check out the "thai house favorite" section. those are dishes that are favored street food by thai people. simple, delicate flavor, and unseen in most thai restaurants. 

khao kaa moo (pork leg over rice). 
is tres delicieux. the pork was tender, the stewed broth seeps into the rice, the pickled vegetable adds just the right amount of tanginess that breaks the fat. always order with skin! 

fried chicken wings
different from western fried chicken wings - they are golden, thinly breaded, and retained the sweet juiciness on the inside. 

steamed chicken over rice
one of my favorite 4am after club street food. at the THE, it is a little blend at first, but the more you eat, the more you taste the subtle flavor. very healthy as well!


MUCH LOVE to this place!!! makes me feel at home :)
author: Fiona S.

description:
I've eaten there a few times as it's only a couple of blocks away from my place, and their food is tasty and cheap. However, their lack of consistency is notorious, especially when it comes to the service, and with its popularity growing it's only gotten worse.
The last time I was there the waiter seated somebody that arrived after me immediately right under my nose, and when I complained he made it obvious that he couldn't care less.  It's a shame because I liked their food and their prices, but I don't like being treated like cattle. And there's dozens other cheap joints with good Asian food in the Tenderloin to choose from, so I don't think I'll be going to Thai House Express again.
author: eliaws w.

description:
I used to live in the 'hood, and this place was a lifesaver, being open till midnite. My ex introduced me to the place, and when I lived in the TenderNob, I was here almost weekly. Other friends I have brought here, even one who lives in Thailand a few month a year, really loved the food.

My fave dishes are the vegetarian Pad Woon Sen (which can be made with meat, but I think it overpowers the delicacy of the noodles), the beef salad with lemongrass, the fried rice, and the green chicken curry. The latter is to die for; the perfect level of heat, ratio of chicken vs veggies, and they give you a TON of it. I had enough for a second meal on Sunday night. And when you ask for spicy, they give you spicy, not the honky version of spicy meant to accommodate the bland midwestern palate.

The one complaint is I wish they had spring rolls that were not fried. Tried those once, and they were terribly greasy. Other than that, the service is friendly and efficient, the place looks clean, servings are ginormous, the price is right, and I have NEVER had a bad meal there. Four paws up! =^^=
author: LunaCat X.

description: Really simple neighborhood restaurant with affordable quality food! Really enjoyed the Barbecue Chicken and rice. The chicken had a lot of flavor and I nice crispy outside without being too dry.  My friend enjoyed the Pad Thai. The ambiance is lacking but the food is enjoyable and the prices are good.
author: Marissa P.

description:
Ordered via Grubhub and while the delivery time frame was an hour, the food came in 20! Here's what we ordered:
-Gang Ga-Ree Gai (UH-MAZING!)
-Pad Se-Ew w/ pork (yum!)
-Peak Gai Tod (good, but nothing spectacular)
-Thai Iced Tea (zing!)

The ga-ree gai was so so good! Too bad there were too few goodies & a lot of sauce. The Se-ew noodles were also really good, but I had to hunt for the pork, very few pieces. The Thai iced tea was made with the perfect proportion of half & half and tea. Overall, would definitely order here again AND you can't beat free delivery!
author: J. L.

description:
This became a fall back place after going to Lahore Karahi only to see that, of all days that they could just decide to close, it would be the one I would got there with a friend who hadn't had Indian food in the better part of two years.  But I digress.

Food was cheap and tasty, portions were decent sized.  Not over-flowing, but enough to fill you up by the time you left.  The Pad-see-yew and Green Curry Beef that we ordered were both tasty.  Service was quick and friendly.  Decor was sparse, and the Christmas decorations sitting on the ledge were a bit strange.

Overall, a good place, worth going to again should I find myself in the mood for Thai food, or without Indian food.  I think I basically like 'spicy,' 'sauce,' and 'curry' to be found on the menu, so this was a fine substitute.
author: Eric M.

description:
I would have never, ever have tried this place, but last Friday night, I was over at a friend's  house and we were hungry -- we wanted food fast.  Since Thai House Express is conveniently located right across his apartment...unfortunately, we had no choice but to give it a try.  

We ordered food to-go, it was ready for pick quickly... as fast as I downed my kamikaze from the bar right across the street.  I had the Param Pak, number 95, which is crispy tofu and vegetables topped with peanut sauce over rice. My order could probably serve a couple of people, there was a lot.  I wasn't really into it, I ate about a third and set it aside.  The peanut sauce was overwhelming -- too much for my palette, and the only veggie I it came with was string beans.  I like string beans so I'm not complaining.  

My friend enjoyed his food (some glass noddle dish), he gobbled it all up.  I'm sure we'll give this place another try, probably after a night of drinking since it's open daily until midnight, but I can't promise that I'll come back anytime soon...
author: Celeste M.

description:
Excellent.

The storefront looked a little dicey, so I was hesitant to try out Thai House Express.  I decided to give it a shot on a recommendation from Marsha Z.  It turned out that the inside is pretty nice, with some modern artwork on the walls.

But frankly I don't care what the place looks like--it's all about the food.  And it was damn good.  I had fried catfish and greenbeans with a side of white rice.  Thai hot, of course!  The beans were really fresh and cooked perfectly, and the catfish was very lightly breaded.  It was nice and spicy too.

Now I have a new favorite Thai place, and I'm sure that I will frequent it a lot.  Next I have to try Mekong which Marsha also recommended.
author: Rocco B.

description:
Papaya salad with salted crab: I ordered medium-spicy, would've liked it a bit hotter. Flavours weren't as clean as in Ruen Pair's (Albany) version, but there was a lot going on. The work required to get meat out of the small shelly sections of crab leg is daunting but worthwhile.

Pork leg stew rice plate: The meat was taken off the bone, very tender, some flavorful skin but more would've been nice. Served with a crazy-delicious garlic chili oil for dipping, which pushes it slightly ahead of the version I had at Da Nang (also in Albany). Apparently there's a noodle soup version of this on the specials board sometimes: the Holy Grail of noodle soups.

Each dish was about seven bucks. So which is better, Ruen Pair or this? The jury looks forward to consuming more evidence.
author: Brad L.

description: Not sure why the reviews are so high on this one. Maybe since it is cheap? Ordered a duck dish that was not cooked correctly (and poorly cooked duck es no bueno,) an app (fried chive and something thing to appease the vegetarians) that just tasted bad and then some greasy pad see ew. I will admit our menu choices may have been poor (did not get to try any curries or basil chicken,) but I will not be returning.
author: Andrew K.

description:
This place has been consistently good for at least 3 years now! That alone should make you get your ass to Thai House Express. Now I know there are a plethora of Thai places to choose from in The City-many of them in this precise area, however, you would be doing yourself a disservice if you didn't stop here at least once. It's a perfect restaurant to stop in before a show at the Great American or a night of boozing at the Ha-Ra.
Honkies beware! When you order 'spicy' they don't fuck around. You may want to go with medium spice, but hey it's worth it if you like the burn. Soo good!
The soups and entrees are all a perfect balance of flavors and a delight to the palate.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Authentic Thai food can be buried by overwhelmingly amount of Thai-ish restaurants in the city. When I first saw the name, I would never think that it's something close to...say, Marnee on 9th ave. But since it's recommended by my boy and his foodie friend, I gave it a try finally. And the result : nodding my head non stop.

The green curry was SOOOO good!! Spicy, sweet, coco-milky, tangy, with lots of different veggies. For some reason the bamboo shoots taste great in the curry. The flavors of different ingredients blend so well in the dish that's so much fun to eat! However, it's SOOOOO SPICY!! Boy stopped eating after like the 3rd bite, I took over, as someone who are pron to spicy food. I had to stop about half of the bowl. Sooooo good. But we were both gassy and uncomfortable the rest of the day, not because there's anything wrong with the food, it's so good that we couldn't resist it. 

The Pig's feet noodle soup that's recommended by a friend was pretty good too. It hit the spot on a cold day. The flavor of the soup is mild, but still flavorful. I'd like to have more of the soft, gummy, tendon stuff from the feet though.

The dessert: sticky rice with coconut milk and fresh mango was very nice too. Perfect dessert if you were only 70% full, but still perfect if you are 99% full like we were. It just that good that your stomach will make space for it.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
My friend and I were looking for a place to go eat late at night in SF.  This was a surprisingly tall order.  We walked and walked around Larkin street in SF and found very few restaurants anywhere.  It was my second date with this girl and not knowing where we could go was definitely embarrassing.   I had my iPhone with urbanspoon but it wasn't much help to find a place very close.  We found several strip clubs but I figured that's not what she had in mind. (Oddly enough, I read in the SF Chronicle a day later and there was a murder at one of the strip clubs on the night we walked past it.)

Finally we found the Thai House at Larkin and Geary, which emerged almost like an oasis in the desert in my eyes.  Even at 10 PM it was busy.  Their menu has practically 500 different items which is really bad for me since I feel the need to read about all of my options.  I ordered the BBQ chicken fried rice and my friend ordered the pad thai.  It took a while for us to get our food and they delivered my friend's food about 5 minutes after they served me -- definitely tacky.  But the chicken was awesome.  It had a 'slow roasted' smokey flavor and tender texture made the entree really unique.  I can't remember exactly how much our meal cost but the prices were reasonable.  The wait staff was somewhat aloof but I'd definitely recommend this place if you're wandering around aimlessly in SF one night.
author: James K.

description: Quick service, low prices, greasy greasy greasy food. It tastes like they have everything ready-made and sitting there...not too fresh tasting. We used to live nearby and would come here every once in a while but since moving away, we haven't been back...until a month ago. I remembered how greasy everything was as soon as we got our food. Meh, is all I can muster.
author: Nilu r.

description:
the portions have gotten a little smaller. and the price has gone up a bit. (but they still give more and charge less than osha) 

authentic thai food. everything is always good, including service. and theyre open til midnite now. 

i aM definitely a fan, and a regular. if u havent tried it. ur missin out!
author: Lisa N.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants.
Hands down the best Yellow Chicken Curry in SF (probably the best I've had, period).  Ask for it with extra potatoes.  My god, it's heavenly. 
The Pad See Ew, 5 Spice Duck and Yum Woon Sen are all great as well.
I've never had a bad meal from this place and I eat there at least once a month.  
Plus, they're open late!  They used to be open until 2am, but I believe they just shortened their hours until midnight.  Still, for Thai food in SF, it can't be beat.
author: c o.

description:
Wow, it took 3 years of having lunch in the City every day, but I FINALLY found my favorite Thai place.  I've only been 3 times so far (in 2 weeks, and it's a long way from the office), but I've loved all the dishes I've had so far.  The pumkin curry is great (not the absolute best I've had, but close); the green curry is my favorite so far, the tom kha gai is the best I've ever had.  I will be trying a whole pompano next time I go most likely, can't wait!
I'm pretty picky when it comes to Thai food (well, food in general I guess), but as far as I can tell, you can't go wrong with this place.  The prices are awesome, by the way...  oh, and the thai iced tea is just the right mix, not too sweet, not overbrewed
author: Shaun K.

description:
Pork leg over rice with pickled greens = ridiculously good. 

This place is fast and furious. They dish out the plates here like none other. Great menu. Pick anything and you'll be surprised how good it is. It's hip, open-late, and cheap. Go Thai Express...
author: R K.

description:
Wanted to hit up a Thai place during my visit to SF. Both Yelpers and Chowhounders alike rave about the pork leg stew so decided to come here. Early dinner at 5 on a Saturday so no wait, but full when we left. Cute place with modern decor. Food roundoup:

- Pork leg stew noodle soup: Got this with wide rice noodles. Really good, definitely would come here again for this. It was different than I expected, was thinking I was getting a kinda murky soup with noodles (tawainese style beef noodle soup). This was a clear and bright broth with melt in your mouth, fall apart pork. The slight crunch of steamed bean sprouts and crisp fat bits provides a perfect balance of flavors!
- Pad Kee Mao (spicy rice noodle stir fry) - Good flavor, a lot of other places serve this dish and it's bland. 
- House Thai beef - Beef cut on bias with addictive chimmichurri type sauce. Comes with rice, the sauce really makes this dish

Lowdown: Definitely order the pork leg stew noodle soup, it's all that!  The other dishes we had were above average. Great value too, hole in the wall prices without the hole in the wall. Food came out quickly, but no refills on drinks since there were only 2 servers working.
author: Jackie P.

description: I might just be getting lucky recently, but I have been having some amazing food experiences and Thai House Express continues that trend.  For a Thai restaurant, this one certainly had a uniqueness about it.  The pork leg stew over rice is one of the most unique dishes that I have had in a while and the pork was cooked so tenderly that it simply melted in your mouth.  I heard it also had the best Pad see ew and Pad Thai that people have ever eaten.  When I first got there, I was looking around at other people's tables to see what they were getting, and the fact that everything looked so amazing speaks volumes about it for itself.
author: Min P.

description:
Thai friend of mine took me there for a quick bite.  Everything was goo as he ordered.

2nd time I took 2 of my friends.  We ordered totally different things from the first time I was there.  Server asked me how hot it should be - just like any other authentic Thai restaurant.  Everything was perfect for the price we paid from the soup to Curry.  Only thing we didn't like was the Pork Belly dish, which lacked in flavor.
author: Yuko K.

description:
Very cute inside and open very late.... the spicy noodles were SO SO SO spicy, thank goodness, but WOW... danger!!!!!

Delicious soup.
author: Aaron W.

description:
This my 2nd review of this restaurant. Had another great experience. Would give 4.5 stars overall. This is a no-frills, authentic, and packed restaurant. You go there for well-priced, authentic, and delicious Thai food that you would experience in Thailand. I went with a couple of Thai food rookies and we tried dishes across all levels of sophistication. Here is what we ordered and how I rated them:
* Chicken Pad Thai - 4 out of 5 stars,
* Seafood Fried Rice - 4 out of 5 stars,
* 5 Spice Duck Entree - great flavor but would like the skin seared and crispy not stewed. 3.5 out of 5 stars,
* Fried Pork Belly with Chinese  Broccoli - 5 stars!
* Salmon in yellow curry - 5 stars! Salmon cooked just right and the yellow curry was intensely rich and flavorful. Must order!
* Fried Catfish Salad - 5 stars!
* Fried Fish Cake Appetizer - 4 out of 5 stars! Good...but "been there done that."
* We each ordered their Soju Cocktails (Lychee, Pomegranate, Mango). They tasted good but were very, very weak. They charge only $5 each. Would be better to charge $6 and make it for grown-ups and not like spritzers for kids. 3 out of 5 stars!
* Service - friendly, helpful, and real. 5 stars!
author: H E.

description: I've eaten at many Thai restaurants in San Francisco.  Thai House Express is the tastiest of them all.  The food is authentic and the service friendly.  Our Thai-Chinese friend who is very particular about her Thai food introduced us to this place.  We ordered several dishes, including the pad kee mow, moo prig king and a delicious curry.  All were fabulous.  I heard a rumor that they might start delivering.  I really hope so but if not, it is well worth dropping by and having an amazing meal.
author: Jenny K.

description: Not bad for the price. Pad Se-Ew  was delicious. Tom Yum Seafood soup was soo spicy, that even my hair was itching :) But they asked me how spicy I want it, and I said "spicy". I did not realize how SPICY it really was... So, be careful
author: Julie N.

description: I am kind of surprised by all the gushing. This place is cute and OK, but nothing to write home about. I had this pretty bland, but decent chicken dish, which wasn't nearly spicy or flavorful enough. The environment was fine, cute even, but not inspiring.
author: Andrew K.

description: They have really good Pork Leg stew.  I like their Pad Thai too.
author: Jim J.

description: Kinda bummed about my last visit here. My date and I opted for the classic Northern Thai trio: Som tom, khao niao and gai yang (papaya salad, sticky rice & grilled chicken) and a beef larb to top it off.
