All were mediocre and not as well done as I would have expected from a place run by Thais. The papaya salad was too sweet and the chicken was not freshly cooked. The larb was good though not enough rice powder (and get pork or chicken, not beef.) I'll give it another chance, but please refine these most important classic dishes.
author: Brian J.

description:
BEST Thai restaurant in San Francisco .

I always start the meal with Vegetarian Chive Cakes . It's a simple twist to the chinese dim sum, pan fried chive cakes . The only difference is that it's bigger and flat . I actually prefer this over the dim sum . 

Next I would have the Pad See Ew, a sweet pan fried noodle dish .

OR the Rad Na, similar to the Pad See Ew but not as sweet and it drowned ( in a good way ) with the gravy sauce .

OR their Green Curry . Wow, spicy, sweet, creamy, delicious . I always get it with mild-medium heat level .

OR the Moo Tod, which is deep fried pork over fried rice . SO GOOD .

If I'm here with my family, we'll get everything I just named .

Sure, you'll probably get hustled into giving a buck or two to a homeless, but it's worth all the trouble .
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Pretty decent place if you are having a craving for some thai food...
I usually order the chicken and egg plants and mixed veggies over rice...i like to sub white rice with either garlic rice or jasmine rice..yummy....

i also like their fish cakes...used to be bigger but since the economy has been bad...they have shrunkened them to tiny ones...but still tasty...cuz they come with a cucumber spicy salad...

and their thai ice tea is also yummy...

they are nice to give a small tiny cup of crushed peanuts to go for me to put over my veggies....most place wont do that....=P
author: Laimei W.

description:
It was getting close to eight.  Our kids were tired.  We decided to go straight to our rental and have delivery.  Good thing Thai House Express came through.  

They told us that it would be there in 45.  It got there in 40.  Everything we ordered was yummy.   We especially loved the pumpkin curry.  So good.  So were the papaya salad, pad se yew, and basil beef.  My husband is already saying he needs more of that curry.  Can't wait to go back and try other items on the menu the next time we are in town.
author: Bella B.

description: My review includes speed,service,prices,and cleanliness the place is clean service was fast prices weren't too bad for s.f. but they weren't very friendly
author: Clarence B.

description:
Both T.H.E.'s are great resources for dishes other than the run of the mill pad Thai and curries. They are also beloved b/c they stay open decently late, pack one hell of a ~spicy~ punch, and are totally affordable. As many before me have avowed, the kao ka moo is so, so very good. Never has a menu description given less away, "special pork leg stew" doesn't even begin to offer a hint of the tender fattiness that awaits you (I prefer this a la carte as opposed to over rice). 

Every so often I forget how searingly hot "spicy" can actually be. Green papaya salad and pad kee mao ordered spicy have left my lips burnt in that hurts so good kind of way. I think medium spicy to spicy is the optimal range. Last time we tried the sai oou too, b/c deep fried pork sausage intrigued. The links are actually quite good, with interesting herbs and bits of fresh cilantro mixed in. I'll opt to try something new on the next round though.
author: Candice L.

description:
I lived 2 blocks away and ate here almost daily for a good month.

I ate the same thing: spicy green bean with tofu over rice.  Loved it.

The kitchen is essentially in the same area as where you sit/eat...so expect to smell like Thai takeout when you leave.
author: Diego S.

description:
We were suppose to head deeper into the Tenderloin for Vietnamese food but we were skeptical of the neighborhood, so we ducked into this clean 70% full thai restaurant. There was a man standing outside touting all the best dishes to us. Wasn't sure if was a regular or waiting for us to ask him in.

We ordered the Yum Shanghai Salad in medium spicy. It was HOT! like SPICY! Medium in thai = SPICY! It was a tangy noodle dish with sprinkles of ground pork and red peppers. Wish there was a little more greenery to make it a "salad."

We ordered the Thai House Beef for the main. It was a little tough. The sweet green sauce helped cool the palate from the Yum Shanghai.

We ended the meal with a sweet sticky rice with ice cream. I had heard of Philippino dessert like this and have had mango on sticky rice, but this was my first ice cream on sticky rice. And you know what, it was pretty darn good. I would ordered it again. I like the texture from the rice. It lends well to the ice cream.

I would go back to try the other unique dishes on the menu (but now I know to order MILD).
author: Cindy W.

description:
Very very good food. I've been here a few times and the food has always been awesome. 

The wait staff are also very friendly.

Good prices. 

The menu is very large so lots of good things to choose from. 

I'll def be back for more!
author: Ian C.

description:
Excellent food - lots of young people!
Hope to come back anytime again.
author: Florian E.

description:
I went here one day when i was completely blacked out at like 3 PM from drinking heavily at Anchor Brewing Co. 

In our drunken state, we could make no sense of anything on the menu so we pointed and grunted like any other blacked out, starving, yet mildly civilized group of individuals would do. 

we were served some weird fish ball platter in a sweet juice of some sort. 

I was not a fan and am still forever scarred.
author: Victor B.

description: more like 4.5.  Great food, decent portions and friendly servers. Best Thai in the Bay Area. Outstanding dishes were: salmon in green curry, crispy pork, pad thai, duck, coconut dessert. The best part is $124 for 6 all in!  Will be back again for sure.
author: Mario S.

description:
On of the better Thai places in the TL.

I must say though before you go any further that I really don't like super AUTHENTIC Thai as I hate cilantro and just don't understand many Asian flavors... I try but can't get my palate around it all yet.

T.H.E. had the common offerings, a few curries some noodles and some ground meat and vegetable stuff.  See, I told you I don't know what I am talking about.

The day I went I was in need of something that would clear out my sinus' as I was getting sick and was getting annoyed with having to sniffle all afternoon.  The noodle dish that I got sure did the trick, they were happy to give me a bit of a burn.

All in all, I say that the food is just right for the low price and while the ambiance leaves something to be desired you should be in and out so fast that it will not matter.
author: Thadd L.

description:
GREAT FOOD and GREAT SERVICE!!!

A new Thai restaurant to try.  If you're tired of your usual Thai restaurant (considering the abundance of them in SF) you should definitely make Thai House Express your new favorite.

Located in not the greatest areas of the TL and in the area of hard to find street parking.  Don't let this discourage you.  Circle the streets a few times and you're bound to find a parking space.  Just be patient.  If you're a big baller, then just find a parking garage.

As you enter, you're welcomed, and you can't help but notice the modern/hip decorations.  I'm sure we're used to the traditional Thai decorations, but this place has a comfortable trendy feel to it.  Don't let this throw you off.  You're there for the traditional tasting Thai food. 

Service is SUPERB!  We went on a busy Friday night.  We were quickly seated and our food came within ten minutes!!!!  Fast service and they were attentive to assuring our water glasses were full and quickly hustled to our request for more rice.  Again, service was great, considering it was busy.

A must try dish is the Pork Leg Stew.  The pork is so tender that it MELTS IN YOUR MOUTH!  I kid you not!  Full of flavor!  Also try the Lhat Nah (sorry for my poor translations)....it's the flat rice noodle with vegi and meat in a pool of gravy.

Give Thai House Express a try!
author: Justin M.

description:
This place is goooooood! They seem to have more variety than most Thai places but what do I know - I'm Chinese. Seriously, almost everything I've had here is really good and the prices are very reasonable.

The best dish is definitely: #40 Kao Ka Moo - pork leg stew over rice. OMG, it is SOOOOO good. I'm not even a huge pork fan but this dish is really something. It's so tasty! The only one dish I've been disappointed with is the cat fish salad - not sure there was really cat fish in it. I'll let it slide because the Kao Ka Moo makes up for this and more.
author: Barney M.

description:
I guess it's redundant but I love this place too. I've been coming here for 6 years now. In fact, I used to live in Sacramento and would drive to SF one Saturday a month to eat here. It's THAT good. My then bf would ask me to bring him here whenever he came to visit from the East Coast.

This place is one of a few Thai restaurants in SF that I would say serve "authentic" Thai food(I was born and raised in Bangkok). Here are a few dishes I recommend: Kao Kah Moo(Pork Feet Stew), Kuay tiew Rua(Beef Noodles), Kuay Tiew Tom Yum(Spicy Noodles), Kao Mun Ghai(Ginger Chicken??), Thai Suki Yaki(dry), Kao Soy(Curry Noodles), and Koi Si Mee(Pan Fried Noodles with gravy). Other dishes are good too. The Roti dessert is sooo yummy. The one dish I've tried I don't recommend is Pad Thai. It is not even close to authentic. In fact, I can never find authentic pad thai anywhere in the Bay Area. Let me know if you know of any place. 

Lastly but most importantly, the food here comes so fast you think it's fast food. You order and within 5 min, your food is on the table. You take a bite, and life is better again.
author: Kwan H.

description:
This is the closest Thai food I've eaten outside of Bangkok.  The food is tasty and CHEAP.  I like the curries but the pad thai is kinda weak.  The soups are good.  Basically, I come here because the price is right.

One HUGE flaw:  NO REFILLS ON THE SODAS.  What is this, Nazi Germany?
author: Meh M.

description: Food was pretty good, but they got our order partially wrong - and we didn't order at a busy time (9-930 on a monday night).
author: Andy A.

description:
What not to like about Thai food? I'll give any restaurant a 1 even if the food taste heavenly if the toilet is overlooked. 

This place came close to dishes i had over in Phuket and Krabi. 

Tom ka gai/yum goong, gang ga-ree gai, my favorites.

Yum, yum, yum.. this is making me hungry.
author: Jennifer I.

description:
This place is great! If you like  spicy then this is the place for you! I would definitely recommend only ordering spicy dishes here. My first time I ordered the Pad Thai and was really disappointed, but my boyfriends Chan Pad Poo was amazing! We usually go here at least a couple times a month. It's not too pricey and they give you a lot of food for your money. The Chan Pad Poo is always chalk full of tasty crab meat, the spiciness does tend to vary a bit but it is ALWAYS tasty.

Usually the service is pretty good, but I definitely don't come here for the service. It is in the tenderloin, so be prepared for some unique people walking by in a number of colorful outfits.
author: Henriette P.

description: This place used to be amazing.  If it had not changed I would've given it four stars at least.  After not coming here for a few months I returned to see the menu was different, the sign had changed and no one but a cook I recognized still worked here.  It changed owners or something and they raised the prices and cut down on the quality.  The beef with straw mushrooms in oyster sauce that used to dazzle me was now full of rubbery beef.  The yellow curry with shrimp I loved is now only available with chicken.  The then attentive and frienly staff is now indifferent.  Things have changed.
author: Sin F.

description: I have absolutely zero complaints about this place.  Great service, fast, affordable and DELICIOUS.  It's rare that you can go to a place and have the "spicy" food be truly spicy.  They even try to warn you before ordering for the feint of heart.  I will go to here again without a doubt.  One of the best Thai places in the Tenderloin area.
author: Alex R.

description:
When I first got back from Bangkok I snobbishly proclaimed (mostly to myself, in my defense) that San Francisco didn't have any good Thai food.  I have a few favorites in the south bay, and a few in the east bay, but my new home seemed a bit lacking in this particular subset of the southeast asian food-o-sphere.  

I was DOUBLY wrong, and proved so by two restaurants of the same name but different location.  This one's my favorite of the pair.  Though some friends beg to differ, there's something about the thrown-together ambiance of the tenderloin location's interior (not to mention all the lovable aspects of the tenderloin itself) that completely wins me over.

The food is amazing.  If you order a dish that's meant to be spicy, it's spicy.  I don't know when the default became serving dishes mild unless asked otherwise, but I'm not a fan.  And I'm pretty weak as these things go, so I feel like my opinion should count.  My favorite dish, chicken pad see ew, is done excellently--plenty greasy, and plenty delicious.  The curries are good, the salads are good, the soup (at least the tom yum) is good good good.  I haven't ordered a dish that hasn't impressed me yet, and I'm a sucker for Thai food, even the mediocre variety that you can get pretty much anywhere.  

Now, I haven't yet tried the ka prao gai, a favorite that I had become convinced was only served in thai restaurants in tokyo and thailand.  That will be the final test, but I can say I'm quite optimistic.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
The best Thai I've had in SF, plus it's cheap and they are friendly and fast.  To those who think it bland - just ask them to spice it up - say "Thai spicy" if you're really brazen.  I had papaya salad so hot it was almost like a short drug trip there for awhile.  I love the Thai House!

Revision from 5 stars:  I'm pretty sure we were served bad (as in old, spoiled, possibly illness-inducing) prawns here, so gotta take them down a few notches.  I'm still going, but I'll stick with chicken or veggie dishes ...
author: Jes H.

description:
Yeah, this place is great. There's not too many Thai joints I like in SF, but this is definitely one of them. I lived in Seattle for many years and thats when I fell in love with amazing authentic Thai cuisine. 

Whenever I try a new Thai place I always try their Pad See Ew with chicken. So when I first tried this place way back in September, I knew it'd be a place I'd return to. It was fantastic. I really love scoring a table all the way in the back from where you walk in because the restaurant has tall windows facing both Geary and Larkin. It's the TL, but hey, its the cityscape I love. And then afterwards its just so convenient to hop on over to that watering hole The Gangway for a cocktail with trannies and the local faire.

My boyfriend and I just ate here last night and had a feast! Chinese Broccoli and Beef, Pineapple Fried Rice with BBQ Chicken, Spring Rolls, and Shrimp Pad Thai and some Singha. Man, it was delicious. Afterwards we went to the movies and saw Hot Fuzz. What a perfect movie after a phat meal.
author: Matthew M.

description:
Went for a group dinner a while back so everyone got to try a nice variety of dishes, but save for the salads, I personally I found most of it a bit bland (despite the organizer of the event ordering in Thai and requesting certain dishes "Thai spicy", they certainly weren't)

Not bad, but it didn't strike me as anything out of the ordinary.
author: Ian K.

description:
the most authentic thai food in sf, and  the price is unbeatable!!!  Put this way, i was eating every last piece that was left on my plate.  I looooovvvveeee this place... if you want authentic thai food, eat at this place!!!!  Authentic is the key word here!!!!  Their food is not flavored with fakes spices/sauces to bring out the taste.  
for $20-$25 you can eat like the King of Thai
author: Mike L.

description:
Thai House Express has escaped my review for so long because it's become one of those standard neighborhood places where I often stop in for soup or quick dishes on the way home.  I probably wouldn't have thought to review it until I took some friends there last weekend.

It was a weekend night and busier than usual, so we're waiting a few minutes for a table.  While near the cash register, I happen to see a recent health inspection notice just barely peeking out from behind another piece of paper.  78!  ("78," I laugh to myself. "But I eat here all of the time!")  Not wanting to look like a jerk who takes their friends to less than clean spot in their 'hood (what can you expect in the 'loin?) I don't say anything to my dining companions.

Not ten minutes later I was desperately trying to dilute my hideously sugared mint lemonade with my water while biting into a hot, tasty string roll.  Yes, I know what you're thinking:  it's SPRING roll, Holly, not STRING roll.  Perhaps you'd like to share that sentiment with the chef.  I pulled a generous length of twine from the shredded veggies tucked into said "string roll," and quickly called over our waiter.  

Our waiter didn't seem terribly concerned but dutifully gathered up my plate and disappeared into the kitchen.  He came back a few minutes later and said the string rolls would be on the house.  There was still one roll remaining on the table.  I looked at my friends and dared them to take it.  I told the waiter we needed a minute to decide if we wanted the rest of our order and he walked off with no apologies or other offers. 

I'm well aware that there are many worse things to find in one's food than string, but the couldn't care less attitude of this place is striking (at least appear sorry -or shocked!- and appropriately compensate your patrons for a mishap.)  I won't be back until the health inspector's score on this place improves: http://dphwww.sfdph.org/eh/Violations/Loc_CurrentViol.asp?LocationID=14089
author: Holly B.

description:
Thai food in the TL!

this place exceeded my expectations in almost every way. i'm kinda mad that my friend handed all of our leftovers to a dirty man begging for change at the door on the way out. i wanted them! they were good!!!!
author: Ameer N.

description: I used to go there every now and then to grab a bite late at night when they were still called Thai House Express and I remember the food being pretty good (otherwise I would not have chosen to go there). However, I hadn't been in a while and after their name change (possibly owners or cooks too) I left less than impressed. The yellow curry with chicken was oily and definitely not mild as advertised (it looked more like a diluted red curry), not creamy as usual, and contained only a lot of so-so chicken and 2 meager potatoes - not a single other vegetable that I'm used to in this dish (no carrots, no onions, no string beans or bell pepper). It was a rather sad dish and I only ate it because I was so hungry... if they don't get their act together fast (I'm watching the reviews), I won't be back!
author: Marc M.

description:
I couldn't believe my brother was taking me to this place.  I'm not a Thai fan and I'd just given all my tip money to the homeless guy on the corner.

I'm no good with wheat so I ordered the Pad Kee Mao and wolfed down the wide rice noodles.  It was so good I wanted to get STUFFED.  All the while I was gorging my brother quietly sipped his soup and smiled like the Cheshire Cat.

Seems he's been coming for three years and keeping his secret from his brother...  So I sent him a text later in the day:

  Called Thai Express. woman would NOT give recipe for sukiyaki.    
  Perhaps oakland chef will spill the beans.

Just to let you know, one of the Thai Express chefs is now at Chai Thai Noodles, 545 B International Blvd, Oakland, CA 94606.
author: Rob P.

description:
i go all the time.  young fun family people run the place.  food always good.  it was packed today for lunch, 10 year annv. monks and everybody was there.
enjoy
author: Dan C.

description: They are so good here is comparable to the food I had in thailand. I love their crab meat fried rice, pad kee mao (because I love noodls especially flat rice noodles chow fun noodles), my favorite of all time here is their duck salad. If you eat raw shrimps then their naked ladies spicy raw shrimp starter are very good. they have very complete menu, I will have to try other items next time :).
author: Leah C.

description:
I  have been to SE Asia many times and Thai Express is the only thai food in the SF area that I ahve found to date that is even close to what you can get in Thailand.
This place is spot on, it's decor is middle class Bangkok
I think it helps that down on Larkin as that is as close as you can get to a colder seedy area in Bangkok.
The food is not Amercianized which is refreshing.

I will be going here for my last meal of boiled squid in hot ctasup sauce.
Nook mam to u
author: Guiseppe B.

description:
This place is seriously legit. There are several things that keep me in my neighborhood & T.H.E is one of them. Best Red Curry Tofu that I've ever had hands down! 

The restaurant itself is nothing to write home about, so I usually get drunken-takeout. Despite my cognitive limitations at the time I maintain that this be some pretty grub-ass Thai food. There are several other Thai places around that are good, but THE is the best one in Lower Nob Hill. 

If you have the chance, get the Pumpkin Curry, you won't be disappointed.
author: Dan C.

description: We had a very confusing time with our order, but the food ended up all right.  Not great.  Just all right.
author: Paul K.

description: I go to Lers Ros for curry and Thai House Express for fried noodles. Really tasty if you request no MSG =)
author: Bootylicious J.

description: We got the Pad Thai and Pomargaritas.  I was impressed by the taste and presentation.  Besides being in a little rougher neighborhood, the atmosphere was great, the place was packed, and the food was yummy.  The pad thai portions could have served 2 people a plenty.  The Pomargarita tasted good too.  Service was up to par and very friendly, including the toddler that grandma was leading around the store.  So cute!  I'd definitely recommend this place if you're nearby.
author: Janet M.

description:
This place rocks 
Fast cheap and so good
 I usually get duck spiced up 

great for late night dinner
author: AZAM A.

description:
Delicious!
They do Thai better than most in the city.
And the street brawl right outside the window kept things interesting. 
The soup and the curry were fabulous.
5 stars on the food, 3 stars on the brusque service.
author: Jeremi M.

description:
I've been here about 5 times now. Always great! 
The food is not over sauced. And the little bit of sauce that is left on the bottom of your empty plate is NOT a slick of oil.
The hood is the 'Loin and it's shady out there, but what are ya gonna do?
Try the "beef jerky" appetizer! Something I would typically go right past, but a buddy ordered it and it was killer!
author: Rick R.

description:
Thai house is a great restaurant.  Nestled among the crackheads outside, you'll find an oasis of spiciness and hospitality with reasonable prices and great food!

Green curry over rice...BBQ chicken...you name it, it's all good!

On a cold, wintry night, the won ton soup is surprisingly tasty!  I've been sick for the past few weeks and that helped tame my throat.  I'd actually even like to say that the won ton soup may be better than most of the chinese restaurants in the area!

Anyhoo...overall a B+ restaurant.  I've read reviews that the service is spotty, but I've only eaten inside once and the service was fine (not great, not bad) then.  From my experience, it is, however, a great restaurant for take-out!  Enjoy!
author: Aileen B.

description:
Alloy! Alloy!
(delicious in Thai)

Great food and close to my house...good for me, but maybe not for you.
author: Matt V.

description:
My friend who is a chef recommended meeting up at this place, so I knew it had to be good. Although, I have to admit...as I was driving up Geary through the Tenderloin, I was a wee bit nervous. But any worries melted away once I was inside and eating the delicious flavors this place has to offer.

Hands down, the best dish we had was the pork leg stew. So many interesting flavors, I can't begin to describe how good it was. The yellow curry was equally amazing. We also tried the papaya salad...it was good, but not nearly as tasty as the two main dishes we got. My friend said the soup everyone was talking about on here is to die for as well...so I can't wait to go back to try it!

The best part...our bill was $23. 

Seriously. 

Go there.
author: Jaymee S.

description:
YUM! The restaurant was a happy surprise to me and a friend who stumbled into it while waiting for a show at the Edinburgh. The place is clean with huge windows to better see the flavor of Larkin St. Makes for amusing "people-watching" while waiting for your food to arrive. Trust me on this! You see all the action from the comfort of your seat.

Gai Ka Prow is always my test of a thai restaurant since there is a distinct flavor to it that cannot be altered and Thai House passed by a mile. Their catfish larb is an explosion of goodness in your mouth. I will go back for the pork leg stew and Pad Kee-Mao...

Most of all the Thai House staff is wonderful and the servers are fabulous!
author: C P.

description:
This is def one of the best Thai places in the city .. I would actually rather give it 4 1/2 though. 
Only bad part is that it's not the best location .. kind of ghetto over in the loin. I don't mind it but ... girls are never that happy when you take them there :) 
Either way .. the pad see yu is amazing.... all the curries are great and there is some spicy beef dish I get like every time but can't remember the name of. 
Don't forget to read the specials on the wall as well.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Great stuff!  Cheap, quick, clean, and very tasty!

I recommend the pad ke maw (spicy noodles), beef jerky, fried rice, and most anything else.  My girlfriend especially likes spikey-haired asian guy is "very nice," gives "good service," is "very cute," and always remembers her and her friends.
author: Bob C.

description:
I'm new to the city and usually stuck around the area I live and work (which happens to have limited dining options). I had been ordering from the same bland place for months (the owner knows me so well by now she recognizes my voice over the phone). One sad night as I was slaving away at the office until 10 pm, I coincidentally ran into a kind colleague who stopped by to drop off her things. This colleague is not the usual person. She really knows her shit. She's a walking yelp, wikipedia, google, and facebook. I kid you not. 

I was introduced to this fine little place in the Tenderloin district. The atmosphere is very casual, and somewhat relaxed. The food is blow-you-away amazing. I have to admit, I'm not entirely sure what I ordered except that it had really soft and tender fall-off-the-bone pork over rice along with a spring roll appetizer. YUM. It was like eating a simple yet tasty, home-cooked meal. Just as how White Castle hit the spot for Harold and Kumar, Thai House Express really hit it for me that night. On top of this, each dish was well under 10 bucks!
author: Kevin T.

description:
Went there for lunch with a friend that loves this place.  She was recommending the pad thai, but once I saw they had tom yom noodle soup I knew what I was getting.

The noodle soup was delicious as was the pad thai my friend ordered.  If you like more authentic thai dishes this is the place to go.  Not many places I've been to have tom yum noodle soup so that was definite nice find.

Just as a FYI the neighborhood it's in isn't the best...but just go with a friend else go during the day and you'll be fine.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I go once a week with a Thai friend that I have.  He says that the food is very authentic.  And I think it's delicious.  Try the Naked Ladies Shrimp.  And their Tom Yum soup is tastier than most Vietnamese pho places.  Be careful about the spice level.  Know yourself before you order extra spicy!
author: Sean W.

description: I used to go here all the time, but it's no longer very covenant for me.  It's no destination in itself, but if you're within a couple blocks already it's a clear choice.  Really fast carry out and decent prices on food that's consistently good.
author: Eric N.

description: I randomly came here on new years because I was staying at the motel 6 close by. Ended up coming here twice.  The prices are good and the service is fast. The best part is the food was really good.  I would say what I ordered but I don't remember any of the names of dishes. It's not in the greatest of neighborhoods but definitely worth it if you want some good Thai food.
author: Marc L.

description: 5 stars purely based on the pork leg stew that tastes like my mom's homemade stew that had been slow cooking for days-- tender loving for the soul. Every time I feeling a bit sick of the routine Chai-Yo dates.. I head over to this lucky corner to find home. Granted the whole fried fish is pretty tasty, as I am sure other things on this extensive menu... just can't let go of the tried and true! If I ever get the chance (probably this weekend), I am going to have to order this spinach dumpling looking delights that I saw at the next table.
author: sally y.

description: Thank you to all you yelpers for this recommendation! Everyone was super friendly and efficient.  The place is clean and the food was sooo good!! I love my thai spicy and they definitely do not mess around.  Next time I'm in town, I'll definitely be back.
author: Carla M.

description: I use to think this was a good restaurant until this weekend. My friend and I got the worst case of food poisoning. It took us 2 days to recover from it. They really need to clean up their act. There should be no reason  a business in the service of providing food should have their customers get deathly ill. I will never go there again.
author: michael k.

description: For its price, this may be the best Thai place I've ever been to. I live a block away so I've been here dozens of times, tried almost the whole menu, and everything is fantastic. Everyone I've gone here with loves it, too.
author: Phatalie J.

description:
Tried this place for lunch yesterday and it was pretty good.  I definitely need to go back and try another dish before I'm certain one way or the other... I got the pra-ram beef, as I am required to try this at every Thai place i visit at least once; while it was pretty tasty, it was a little too sweet and heavy on the peanut sauce IMHO.  I was tempted to try the pad Thai but due to aforementioned requirement was unable to do so.

Service was very fast and friendly and prices were reasonable.  Three stars.
author: Kevin G.

description:
I've eaten here many times, and would eat here more often If I lived closer.

The food is good. vegetables are very fresh, not over cooked.  Tofu is cooked perfectly.  Try the Praram tofu, or Egglpant and Basil over rice and vegetables.
author: Shea G.

description: I have been coming here for years! This is the Father/Daughter place for me and my Dad! We love the Pad thai here, its amazing!!!! The chicken wings are a favorite too. We have a particular dish we get EVERY TIME that I think is quite underrated, unfortunately I can't tell you what it is because I fear it will get too popular and they will raise the price hehe. I love this place though. Great service, great food and very affordable!
author: Tati N.

description: I was in SF for a conference and found this place on Yelp. I had red curry with tofu and vegetables. It definitely hit the spot. Sweet and spicy, one of the better red curries I've had. Prices are very reasonable. It's the first time I had a mint lemonade, I think I'll be making these at home.
author: Teri G.

description: Have had the Pad Se-Ew twice now. It's been really good both times. Seems consistent in quality. And even when it's super busy the time is always the same.
author: Tim M.

description: Easily one of the best thai food restaurant i have ever been to! My boyfriend and I ordered the Chicken Tom Yum (Medium Spicy) and the Kao Pad w/ beef & brown rice. Oh em gee!! Both dishes were absolutely delicious! When the friendly waitress gave us our check, we were surprised to see that it only cost us $20! You can be sure that we will be coming back!
author: Angela T.

description:
the pa thai was pretty good and i liked the tom yum goong soup too ( i eat spicy n sour so i like it, if u don't then don't order it ... ) 
i was expecting better tho when i saw it's review (u_u)"
author: Jenni C.

description: Very good Thai restaurant. Food is cooked quickly and is always delicious. I highly recommend the Chinese sausage fried rice and the Pad Sew Ew Chicken.
author: Colin C.

description:
Great authentic Thai food.   

I have a Thai friend who visits me often from Boston and we spend a lot of time in this restaurant.  He claims that it's the best Thai food out of Thailand.     

The ambiance is ok but the food is great.   

My friends says that the food is better than its sister restaurant in the Castro but I cannot tell the difference.   

Thumbs up from me!
author: Paul A.

description: Fantastic! Reliably good, quick and great value. Hands down best spicy eggplant with basil in town! I can't think of any other Thai in the city that is this good for this money. Love the place.
author: Original Z.

description:
Best Thai food I have had in San Francisco.  As good (and authentic) as many restaurants I have gone to in Bangkok over the years.
Be careful in this neigborhood, however.  It gets a little skeevy.
author: Preston F.

description:
in the style of the menu: 

23. THE FOO DIS YUM MEE
thai food, sometimes noodles, sometimes curry, delicious, warm

107. COME HEER TO EET
open late, close to great american music hall, bathroom for customers only

i am addicted to thai food. i get the same thing everywhere (pad see ew, spicy, tofu, eggs okay) and it was delicious here ! portions looked small at first, but once i dug in i realised there were a lot more noodles on that plate than i had first suspected. yummmmm ! this place is great for pre- or post-show munchies, since it's walking distance from GAMH and open noon to midnight every day. the waitstaff is nice, the bathroom was CLEAN which i love, especially in SF. oh, and they were playing some station that alternated between hiphop remixes, german techno, and katy perry. weird, but i'll take it !
author: Shannon C.

description:
Hubby's Review:

Wifey and I ended up in the 'Loin for one reason or another.  The one time I was trolling around for trannies or crack...haha.  Anyways, the food is decent and you won't get sick eating it.  Pretty tasty.  I hesitate to nominate this as my favorite Thai place.  Personally, I love Thai food...it reminds me of Chinese food with a twist...a really good twist...I have yet to find one that has stolen my heart...I suppose it's like falling in love with the right person..you don't just do it with the first thing that comes along.   The search continues...
author: Mr. and Mrs. L.

description:
I would frequently visit the Thai House Express after a night of drunken stupor when they were opened until 2 or so in the morning when I lived in the tenderlon. This was of course before I was married and do no such things anymore...but MAN, the pad thai tasted really good after a night of drinking...and then again the next morning!

Now i go there with my husband and we gorge ourselves on the splendor that is thai food. We have since moved to San Jose and have tried a few places down there, however, they just do not compare. I am determined to find a good place down there but I am so tired of eating mediocre thai food....it's not as good and more expensive! Something just does not compute...I'm tempted to just pick up some from Thai House Express on my way back down to San Jose...
author: Alison B.

description:
In real estate, it's always location, location, location. In food, it's "Food" first, "location" second. I mean, if you can get some great grub in a not-so-great area, then who are we to judge? This is the case with Thai Express House ( 901 Larkin at Geary). Seriously some of the best Thai in the city. Seriously, one hell of a neighborhood. 

Let's start with my Thai deal breaker: Pad Thai. While others in the city have proven a whimpy flavorless dish (hello Bangkok Noodles on Powell ???) this one just rocked. Great flavors and not greasy. The Gai Ga-Prow was a tasty, spicy mix of chicken, chili, and bell peppers. We asked for it spicy and I'd say it was medium spicy. The decor is unexpected modern. The large windows let you see the show outside...kinda like your own personal "Urinetown." The service is quick, not personable, but you get your food and that's what matters. After the Great American Music Hall, this is one yummy place to be!

Check out my full bog review: http://dontcallitfriscoblog.blogspot.com/
author: Dont Call It Frisco D.

description: brought 2 friends who have lived in thailand and they said it was the most authentic thai food they've had in the states! you gotta try this place!
author: Cindy S.

description: Food is comparable to Osha Thai and a lot cheaper!!!
author: Y L.

description:
My first yelp review!  I'm only writing this b/c it comes with a new dish that you should try, I think it should be called the triple threat

Overall, I'd give the restaurant a 3.5.  The food I'd give a 3.  I'm only rounding up this 3.5 to 4 because it's cheap and the food wasn't greasy.  
We basically ordered what the waitress told us...and we decided to try an appetizer.  I have no idea what it was called but it was #2 on the menu.  The first bite was amazing, but I'm pretty sure its b/c I was soo hungry.  I didn't think it was that good after the first bite tho, the sauce was too thick and heavy.  (side note: Im done with the 's for now b/c I broke my right pinky playing bball the day before I came to san fran and I cannot deal with having to type the ' with my ring finger anymore, same with a lot of capitalization...but not to worry, ill keep spelling for the most part!)

So my mom and I ordered the pork leg stew thing with the rice, shrimp pad thai (b/c 1. all the comments about the pad thai on yelp and 2. b/c it also had a best in san fran award albeit in 2005...so maybe that's why it wasn't so good? Unless you cant win twice?), and the basil chicken on the waitress' recommendation....im glad we decided on 3 entrees and an appetizer for the two of us haha

The pork leg stew was the rice was soo tasty.  The meat was so soft and tender and the flavor was good.  Haha as my mom said, "its kind like ma ma's hong shao rou (but still not as good), it's so tender".  The pork leg stew comes with some sour sauce that has garlic in it, but we didn't use it with the pork.

My mom decided to get the chicken basil b/c she said that's basically what she uses for her san bei ji (Three Cup Chicken).  We got it with mild spiciness, which was still spicy enough to realize that it's spicy.  The chicken was chopped to tiny pieces and full of flavor.  We got it with brown rice, but it didn't look like it b/c it looked like red bean rice, but it was still good.  

The shrimp pad thai was really disappointing.  It was orange and overly sweet.  It was just one solid flavor with this sweet sauce that was too thick.  Ive tried my friends pad thai at Nonya (? I think its like a chain of Penang) in NYC, which was really good, full of flavor and very colorful.  That one had lots of green onions, eggs, and a little spiciness (and some other stuff that I didn't really care for haha)  This one had almost no eggs, not enough green onions, or shrimp.   

Now...for the TRIPLE THREAT!  More than halfway thru our meal, I was telling my mom about the pad thai I had in nyc and how it had been spicy, when all of a sudden, I was like OH the basil chicken is spicy!  Let's make it chicken shrimp pad thai!  So, we mixed in the rest of the basil chicken and the brown rice (b/c there wasn't much of it left),  which gave it a bit of a spicy taste.  I wish I had thought of it earlier b/c we had SO much pad thai left over that the spiciness was much less noticeable (but not absent).  Then my mom thinks to pour in the sour sauce with the garlic b/c it's too sweet...

The triple threat pad thai might best be put this way.  I knew we were going to have leftovers, and I was not looking forward to eating the original pad thai b/c it was bland/overly sweet and I couldn't bear to waste a plate of noodles.  I was actually excited to wake up in the morning and eat this for early lunch/late bfast.

The Triple Threat.  Shrimp pad thai + chicken basil with brown rice + sour garlic sauce from pork leg = More texture, flavor, and a little spicy, sweet and sour pad thai.  TRY IT.  
We told one of the guys (he seemed to know a lot about the dish, he was like Ohh yea?! The combination of garlic and spice!  Hmm!) there about it...I hope they make it a new dish haha.  

Seeing how long this is, not sure if ill be writing many more
author: Anna Z.

description: I approve!  The pad thai and pad see ew were perfect, and came in generous portion sizes.  The green curry was a bit lacking though.  Also, as a Viet I don't appreciate the pho appropriation.  C'mon, Thai people!  We know you make bomb-ass food, but do you really have to take pho from us?
author: Jimmy V.

description: I love this place! The food is very tasty and it's very reasonably priced, only $6-$7 on average for each dish! I came hear for my graduation dinner and I was soo happy that I came here. The food is absolutely delicious, and their desserts are amazing too! It's at a good location and parking isn't that bad. The restaurant itself is very clean and it's dimly lit and night which makes it extra special. This is a must try if you love Asian/Thai food!
author: Doris Y.

description:
This is a reliable restaurant when it comes to value and taste.  Yes, it is not in the best neighborhood but it is located at a convenient corner - Geary and Larkin.  

It was on a Wednesday night at 8:30.  After a couple of Mojitos from Lush Lounge which is only a few blocks away, my friend and I walked there to have our dinner.  The restaurant was quiet and there were only three tables when we walked in.  We ordered two dishes, one bowl of Tom Yum Goong soup noodles (a bit salty for my taste) and my favorite rice dish, No. 46 - stirred fried chicken with veggies (baby corn, mushrooms, carrots, bamboo shoots, unions and scallions) and clear broth sauce over rice.  We shared the food so we both get to enjoyed having soup, noodles, rice, and veggies.  It was a decent meal and it cost $10.50 per person (tax and tips included).
author: SFGAM d.

description:
The roasted pork leg stew (khao kha moo) is excellent. If you need it, you gotta come here (no one else serves it).

Yellow curry chicken is good too. I think it's cooked like a stew  (unlike all the places in the south bay where the chicken is boiled until it tastes like shoestring, then thrown into the curry with parboiled carrots). 

Down half a block is the Edinburgh Castle pub. Excellent place to hang out, get a drink and sometimes see a band.
author: Mr T.

description:
Absolutely delicious, great service, fast, easy, what more do you need?

Food can be a tad heavy, not something I could eat everyday, but when I crave it booooooy do I NEED it!
author: Remi M.

description:
Awesome reasonable priced dishes!

My favorites are Veg Thai red curry, Pad See You (don't know exactly how to spell.) and egg plant dish.  Their Thai ice tea is good too.  I also like coconut ice cream and fried pan cake kind of dessert as well! So good! 

It's just kind of scary to go there since it's in Tenderloin...
author: moshi m.

description: When comparing the numerous Thai restaurants in the vicinity: Lers Ros, Sai Jai Thai, Thai Idea, Osha, I would say the quality of food is all roughly the same. The only difference between these and Thai House is that the service here seems, to me, unprofessional. They're open late...but why bother.
author: Denise N.

description:
hmmmm mmm mmm mmm mmm! 

I am so glad I live near this place! 

The food- fantastic! and comes out fast! 
The service- quick and friendly! 
The prices- very reasonable! 

a few favorites:
-that tom kha soup (i can't remember which one but pick whatever cause they're all good!): is delicious and so flavorful! 
-dessert! fried banana with ice cream, drizzled with honey! the best fried banana i've ever had. 
-chicken with eggplant and basil
-pad-see something
author: Amanda W.

description: Best pad thai I've had in a while but I'm from Boston so that might be why..  I can't see how a dish can get better, the further away from its place of origin you get..
author: pete C.

description: Surprisingly not that hard to find parking around here for a quick lunch, my favorite thing is the pumpkin curry.  I love it.  Fast, filling, flavorful, friendly.
author: Melissa B.

description: So far, I like this place to eat.  We order some food and all of them turn pretty good taste.  I will come here again next time.
author: Max T.

description: I came here with family and ordered family style. The food was mediocre and portions were small. I have definitely had better thai food. We ordered a variety of items but the best was the salmon curry and pad thai. Not sure I would come back here for the food, but it is located at the corner of a large intersection, and it is quite spacious with a view of the kitchen.
author: Vickee N.

description: I love this place. Go there with my girlfriend all the time. Excellent food, quick friendly service and not pricey. What more can you ask for? I definitely recommend thai house over any other thai restaurants in the area.
author: Kalen F.

description:
People who don't like Thai House Express:

1. Don't know anything about Thai food

2. Wouldn't really like Thai food if they did know anything about it
author: Snubby J.

description:
Amazing. Simply amazing. 
I laugh, though, that it says it's in Nob Hill. It's in the 'Loin man. In the friggin GHETTO! 
Dishes I recommend:
Pad Thai (of course!)
Pra Ram
Red Beef Curry
Thai Iced Tea
Mango Sticky Rice

At least thats what I always get there.
author: Marie S.

description:
when you are at rye and after a few swigs wanna grab a bite and say go to osha...STOP!  walk down three more blocks and nearly across the street from hara is voila!!  best thai in SF.  hands down.  my third fav restaurant in my city.

order the beef jerky, pumpkin curry w/pork, duck larb salad, chicken pad sew and pineapple fried rice.  there was me and five girlies that all left stuffed, but of course i got to play dish clean-up boy!!  yay!!  i was so happy and all for like 65 altogether.  

do the math and find your ass here soon.  you will be a fan  ;P

oh...if i was gay, i would be here hitting on all the gay thai boys that work here every night for dinner.
author: omar b.

description: DRY TOM YUM NOODLES at Thai House Express is the best OFF MENU dish ever.  I came in several years ago with a couple Thai friends who recommended the dish so I tried.  It was AMAZING!!!!  I've since made several attempts to order the same dish at many other Thai restaurants and none ever got it right.  I have come back here several times and ordered the same dish and they all have been CONSISTENTLY GOOD.  Beware of super spicy dishes.  They aren't kidding around when they say spicy.  If you don't ASK FOR "MILD" the default might have you wishing you had.
author: A T.

description:
Alright first off - I'm writing this from the perspective of someone who is very allergic to shellfish but loves Asian cuisine (which I realize is problematic.) This place is close to my new apartment so I was really digging some Yellow Curry the other night and excited to try this place. Since I have an allergy when I ordered take-outYellow Curry Chicken I mentioned to the lady taking my order that I was allergic to shellfish and if she could mention it to the kitchen so that they make sure my food doesn't touch any contaminated knives or countertops. She looked at me blankly and said..No sorry. I was a little taken aback since I've never gotten that response before so I explained to her again that I was allergic to shellfish etc etc. She proceeded to get all flustered and pissed off telling me that there was shellfish in the yellow curry. I mentioned that I wanted it with chicken and she told me that the yellow curry comes premade with shellfish in it. Now, I'm sorry but that is total BS. I love Yellow Curry...I've been eating it for years and I've never heard of shellfish coming premade in the sauce (and ew premade curry suace?) I guess our little scene was noticeable because a bunch of the staff started coming over wanting to know what was going on. After much discussion it turns out that the yellow curry sauce is NOT made with shellfish. I was a little nervous about getting it but I was starving and REALLY craving yellow curry. 

I got home (finally) with my takeout but it was totally inedible. GREASY slimy suspect pieces of chicken (was that really chicken?) floating in a disgusting mire of bland oily curry. 

I may consider going here again but only because everyone else on here seems to really like the place and I'd hate for one bad fluke of an experience ruin a whole restaurant. We'll see...
author: Tam G.

description: My friend Daniel and I went here for lunch yesterday and we had the Tom Yum soup (#31), the Red Beef Curry (#54), and the Five Spices Duck (#45). All of the food was delicious, and the service was good too - our water glasses stayed filled, and our food was delivered fast! I'm a fan.
author: Sally M.

description:
food is just slightly better than king of thai, ehhh.
dont order spicy, it's a kick in the face, stick with medium.
it's so loud in here, like a happy hour bar.

walking back to my car, noticed a kitty litter box shoved beneath my car.

good grief.
author: Ethan L.

description: We came here because one of our friend didnt had a previously good experience with Osha. I love Osha, but i am glad we tried Thai House Express. Their food was actually pretty darn good. It was very authentic and i was impressed since it was only a few doors down from Osha. The services was fast and portions was generous. I would come back here again to try out their other dishes.
author: Ernie P.

description: Consistenty decent Thai dishes, fast, cheap, and well worth the stroll through the Tenderloin, past the doo-doo pies, puddles of piss, tweaking meth addicts, and mentally infirm.
author: Daryl E.

description: Not too bad on a Friday night - was able to get seated right away. This restaurant isn't exactly in a good neighborhood so I normally wouldn't have stopped here for dinner. My friend recommended this place to me for Thai food so I gave it a try. Between the two of us we wanted something light. So we ordered the Pad See Ew and the spring rolls with veggies and tofu inside with plum sauce. I liked both dishes. The sweetness of the plum sauce gave the spring roll the flavor it needed. The Pad See Ew wasn't too sweet and they were generous with the chicken and chinese broccoli. I would come back here again but not by myself.
author: Candace F.

description: I think the girlfriend and I have just found a favorite Thai restaurant. The Pad Thai was one of the best we both have ever had and we both loved the fried chicken with a great sweet and sour sauce. We loved the fact that we could control the heat of the dishes. There were 4 options no heat, mild, medium, and spicy. I look forward to checking out more items on the menu If we find that we love the next few items we order 4 stars will shoot to 5.
author: Brian P.

description: This has become my standby for thai food in SF.  consistently good.  We got the beef with green curry sauce and the chicken with green beans, mint, basil and chili.  Both were top notch.  Service was good, food came out quickly. The price is right.  This place is a bargain.  They are willing to give it to you spicy if you like it that way, and don't tone down the flavor or spice just because you are a westerner.
author: Aaron T.

description:
DIRTY! I went into this place with a friend about a month ago for my last time. 

THE WAITER GAVE ME THE WRONG PLATE THEN TOOK IT AWAY TO GIVE TO ANOTHER CUSTOMER AFTER I HAD EATEN FROM IT!

The waiter giggled with one of his coworkers afterward. 

I have yet to report them to the health department.

I was once a regular at this place.
author: I.B. T.

description: I had wondered wondered why I feel sick after eating here. I found out that they use an insane amount of MSG. Disappointed, I called and asked if they could hold the MSG on their dishes if requested to do so. They said this is perfectly fine on any dish that was not a soup or curry because those dishes are already made. So I went in and ordered a simple dish with no MSG. When I returned home, I felt very sick for hours and I am not even MSG sensitive. I believe a restaurant that poisons their customers is disgusting, especially if they promise not to. I will never return.
author: Kelton B.

description:
One of the many great places in the Tenderloin!! Always good and hearty.  The price is right.  I have taken many friends and they always want to go again.
The curries are great and so are the peanut sauces.
The wait staff is always pleasant.
author: Sandy W.

description: Okay guys if you have a taste for thai food , you have to try this!!! They have great good, friendly staff, and fast service. The food gets to you piping hot! My favorite is pad thai with lots of tofu. My husband loves number 75 basil spicy chicken. Best thai restaurant in the city!
author: Lovi K.

description: Pretty close to a five star Thai place for price and quality. It just took a bit too long for our food to arrive despite there being less than a dozen people in the place. Oh well, worth the wait. The Pad Thai and sticky rice were bad-ass.
author: Peter S.

description: So I love King of Thai Noodle but the location can be annoying. It's smack in all the shopping bustle and parking is a byotch. So when I'm not in the mood to cope with the crowds, I just head a little further west to Thai House Express, a worthy contender! I love Thai House Express as much as I do King of Thai Noodle and both delivers distinctively different twists on the same dish. Their pad see you NEVER fails to delight me. Every noodle perfectly cooked and smothered evenly with their Thai sauce. Their basil eggplant is always spot on. The service in clean and attentive and quick! The price is right for all the flavors that they deliver to every dish. Can't complain! I'm always a happy camper here when I leave! And even more so when I don't need to go smack into the shopping crowds and can easily navigate my way to my car! Thank you Thai House Express!
author: Pamela L.

description: I stumbled into Thai House Express few years ago when I was walking around TL and ever since, I've been going back to get its sold Thai dishes.  Some of the standouts for me were stewed pork leg, catfish laab and fried rice with sour Thai sausage.  I don't think curry dishes are THE's strength.  It's not in the best neighborhood at night, but worth the trip for the authentic, low cost meal.
author: Yuko K.

description:
Thai House Express vis-à-vis Osha Thai is just like me vis-à-vis other gay men.

I know you're all expecting me to write about that time I was a Thai hooker who smuggled coke past the TSA by shoving it up his ass -- oh my hole feels so NUMB! -- and dropped in on a trick with a hypo dangling from my arm 'cause I fancy myself to be the gay William Vollmann and I'M HARDCORE but no, Thai House Express is like me because we're both slightly frumpy, we both could use a facelift, we're both overshadowed by the sexy sleek hawtness that is Osha (other gay men), but when you come right down to it OUR DISHES KICK ASS. So I say: Let everyone else get suckered in by the suave appeal and muscular style of those popular Osha clones! I dunno, maybe fighting so hard for something insubstantial served by snide wait staff is somehow appealing -- most people are fucking masochists anyway -- but me, I'd rather luxuriate in the hearty Thai dishes of Thai House Express than work my ass off for the limp ministrations of an Osha who won't give me the time of day not because he's a self-centered asshole but because he's constitutionally INCAPABLE of remembering his fucking name LET ALONE tell the time. I mean, fuck, I know I'm supposed to love everyone in homo town, and I DO -- I'm the shit-shoveler on the Love Train -- but it's fucking HARD sometimes! Look, all I know is when God approached me in the womb and said, "Hi Darin!" "Yes God?" "Darin," he said, "Darin I'm gonna make you a cocksucker," and I said "Woo! I get to take it up the ass!" I can honestly say with a straight face that I was NOT told that my membership in the gay coterie ALSO meant that I'd be rattling sabers with select members of the Idiot-Of-The-Month club! I mean, have you ever spoken to someone and felt not just your brain cells dying by the second but, in fact, LIKE YOU WERE BEING LOBOTOMIZED AT THAT VERY MOMENT?!?

What was I talking about? Oh yes, Thai House Express is a solid choice for excellent Thai food.

So why am I giving only three stars instead of four or five?

Well kids, the last time I was here with my incredibly vulgar and offensive vegetarian friend who shall remain nameless, oh hi MJ, I ordered a veggie pad thai as the entrée and decided to try the toong geurn yeung as the appetizer. The four toong gern yeung -- minced chicken and vegetable balls wrapped in rice paper -- resembled stuffed, savory, meaty, deep-fried ball sacs. I greedily downed all four.

Around an hour into our meal, I began to feel...Strange. Uncomfortable. My stomach was starting to distend. At first I thought it was heartburn, so I took a break and hoped it would pass. It didn't. Unable to finish my pad thai, I had it boxed up and decided to call it an early evening.

Maybe a little exercise would help me digest. I walked home.

As soon as I entered my front door, I rushed to the toilet and proceeded to puke uncontrollably, BLEEEAARRRCGGHHHHH! BLEAAAAARRRCCCHHH! So violent was my purging that the toilet water splashed up into my face. As my knees knocked and the toilet water dripped from my nose and I trembled and felt my heart palpitating, I inspected what I had puked up, it's something I do, I like seeing what was lingering in my stomach, plus I'm still looking for that dental dam I 'accidentally' swallowed months ago. And while fingering the noodles and peanut bits I noticed that some of the minced chicken from the toong gern yeung was FUCKING UNDERCOOKED AND PINK! That's right -- SPECIAL DELIVERY FROM SALMONELLA TOWN!!!

So why am I giving three stars instead of just one?

Because I'll probably return to Thai House Express, bitter and crazy, table for one. I've been there many times, so I'll assume (hope?) this was simply bad luck. Like I said, Thai House Express is just like me. And I make people puke sometimes, too.
author: d s.

description: The food was great, the service, not the best. I liked it because it was because it was quiet, clean, and reasonably priced. Don't order the chive cakes.
author: Eboni B.

description: Thai House Express, YOU'RE SO HOT! and I am so in love with you right now :) It's the best Thai food I've had in a really long time! When they say 'HOT" they really mean it, they show some respect by not underestimating your ability to eat spicy food. I loved my Tom Yum noodle soup. I went with 7 other friends, so I got to try 7 other plates which are all so goooood....... It's so Thaiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii! 555+
author: Marlis T.

description: This is by far, the best Thai restaurant I've came across! The food is better than a lot of the other thai restaurants I've went to. I really like their Pad Thai and their different selections of fried rice and their dessert roti with ice cream is really good too. Definitely will see me coming back!
author: Jane Z.

description: Love this place. The noodle salad is to die for. Also the Chan noodle stirred fried with crab meat is super good as well. This is very close to what we get back home in Thailand.
author: J V.

description:
this is the best place for thai food in the city, hands down. other than that, i wait until my cousins/great aunt from chiang mai fly out to make me authentic northern thai cuisine.

the curries are well-balanced and the noodle soups are flavorful and SPICY. 

careful when you ask for "thai spicy." they WILL put in a fair amount of the real thai chili peppers. the ones that will give you blisters on your tongue and you'll feel your digestive track for the next 2 days. 

i still love them though. i'll go in for their "sawadee ca" any day of the week.
author: May T.

description: Crabfest '06-'07 continued tonight with some crabby noodles from Thai House Express.  Noodles were good, lots of crab but also bits of shell sprinkled throughout.  I wasn't that impressed but will give them another chance the next time I'm in the mood for Thai (and remember not to order anything that once came in a shell)
author: phil h.

description: I was here with a friend last Thursday before going to Cafe Royale for some music.  I had the pineapple fried rice with chicken and it was very good...almost as good as any Thai restaurant.  It was light and tasty.  I'd stop by again when in the area.
author: TJ K.

description: They are not kidding! I told them I'd be there in 5min and asked if they could expedite my order? I arrived less than 5min and my dish was prepared in a bag and ready to go. Boyz, they are fast! The food is D-licious too. I love you Thai house. I know I can always rely on you when I'm hungry.   grung grung, time to call...
author: Michael K.

description: Excellent late night dining eats--perfect place for a meal after hitting AMC.  It's good food you'll enjoy, drunk or sober, cheap and hearty Thai that never fails to satisfy.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Best Tofu Pad Thai ever! Literally stumbled upon this place. It is open late and has many vegetarian options. The service was good and so was the price.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Some of the BEST Thai food I've ever had!  My former roomie travels to parts of Asia frequently and got back from Thailand this year after taking cooking classes over there. The ONE dish he didn't get a chance to try/learn was Kao Soy.  The ONLY place other Thai restaurants in SF (like Osha) said would have it was Thai House.  He went there and was blown away and recommended it to Natalie and I the other night.
GET the Kao Soy! It's amazing! It's a Northern Thailand dish consisting of a mild yellow curry over egg noodles with chicken, red bell peppers, mustard greens and some red onions.  Crazy good!  The pumpkin curry wasn't the best I've ever had and neither was the pad thai but for the amount of food we ate, dinner for two netted us generous leftovers and super full bellies.  It's a pleasant dining environment in the heart of the TL and never feels seedy or gross despite being on the corner of Geary and Larkin.  I'll be back to see how the rest of their entrees stack up but the Kao Soy is worth the trip alone!
author: Jill D.

description: This place is F*ING GREAT!!!!  Crab Pad Thai is da best!!!.....my favorite Thai place by far!!
author: anthony b.

description: Went here after climbing at PG SF.  Good food and it was definitely express.  I now realize that I can't handle overly spicy foods--it just makes my forehead sweat lol.  The food was tasty and hit the spot after a good work out.  Recommend coming here for a late night snack!
author: Christopher W.

description: Mmm.. Tasty.. I love all Thai food in general. Good service, clean, and good portions. Nice waitresses too. I like their thai tea.
author: Colleen W.

description: I've eaten there 34 times and never experienced any bad meal. Man, I just love this place.
author: D'Andy C.

description: What can I say, I've eaten at this place seriously over 30 times, the service is great and fast, the quality of the food is so consistent. And everything I tried randomly for my curiosity was simply so good. Order the chives cake, or the naked ladies they are raw prawns with a spicy chef sauce. Of course all the curries are just amazing. Just talking about it makes me want to go now!!
author: Mattin N.

description: I am very much a fan of this restaurant.  The chicken pad thai here was very good.  The moisture level was perfect in my opinion.  The only negative was that I felt the portion was a bit on the small side for the price.  The flavors are solid though and so I give this a 4/5.
author: Bobby R.

description: I love Thai.  Thai loves me.  This place is amazing!  I went here with my cousin and got panang and a thai iced tea.  I think we split a curry doughy appetizer that was also good.  Do yourself a favor and get your butt to this place.
author: Christopher L.

description:
it's the thai naan n curry. cheap, hot, crowded and huge portions.  beware if you ask for it spicy. 

the ground chicken with basil is the diggidy.

good location for a pre-van ness 1000 movie
author: M B.

description: Spectacular value, well-executed food, speedy service, and Thai music videos on the flatscreen:  sweet!  This is what I remember the original Osha Thai down the street tasting like until the prices went up and the quality went down.   I'm going to be craving that pad kee mao for a long time now.
author: Nat K.

description: Well, let me just say that I moreso had an APPRECIATION for this place rather than anything.  I had the ....damn can't remember the name, but it was sliced pork in Chef's "Secret Sauce".  I like the kick the sacue gave!  And the portions were good as well.  The reason it truly gave 4 stars in my book , though, was the NINJA style skills they got!  THEY ARE FAST!!! And, to have good food, decently priced, quick service...PERFECT for a late night Post Yelp event spot.  We were tired, and had work the next morning, so the experience we had here was exactly what we wanted!
author: Gio G.

description: One of the better thai places around. The green curry is excellent. Even the spicier versions have a depth of flavor to them. I'm trying to think of a bad dish I've had here, and I just can't. It's all pretty good and the service is friendly and efficient.
author: The Sock S.

description:
best value in town.  we ordered four dishes for four people and walked out stuffed and happy and paid only $12.50 per person including tip!  the yellow curry was amazingly creamy and sweet, the pineapple fried rice and pad kee mao were excellent as well.  

for those of you from LA, this place is comparable to the thai restaurants in Thai Town - ggggggggggreat!  too bad they don't have a singing thai elvis who performs love songs in a sequin jumpsuit while you eat (a la Palms Thai restaurant...if you've never been...you gotta check it out...and get the duck curry when you go!)
author: Tabatha Y.

description:
This is the most authentic Thai restaurant that I have found in the United States period.  I have visited Bangkok two times; and Chiang Mai in the North of Thailand once.  I thus  got to eat at the famous street food vendors, and mom and pop restaurants that proliferate these cities; and since both Bangkok and Chiang Mai are the food centers of Thailand, folks who have been to or lived in these two cities know what makes Thai food great.  Thus, Thai House Express is the most authentic Thai restaurant as it is very comparable to Thai food you'll find in Thailand.  

For example, the Green Curry Chicken is well balanced and alive with flavor in the coconut milk, and spices.  This reminded me of the green curry chicken I had prepared by a master chef in a cooking school in Chiang Mai (Northern Thailand).  Secondly, there is a southern thailand regional dish called 'Kha Nom Jeen' which is my favorite. It is fish curry with preserved vegetables over soft vermicelli rice noodles.  That dish reminds me everytime of the well reputed Siam Square food courts  in Bangkok.  Totally authentic, and every flavor as it should be.  Keep in mind that 99% of Thai restaurants in the US do not carry this dish.  So for a Thai food lover, this is a special treat! 

A third dish that I like is the grilled chicken with sticky rice.  This dish is particular to the Northeast region of Thailand; Isaan; and it is marinated with honey sauce.  Thai House Express makes this grilled chicken superbly and truly like the one that I had in an Isaan specialty restaurant  in Bangkok.  Not surprisingly, Thai House Express is frequented by Thai students, and American men  who bring along their Thai wives. (Actually I should say it's the opposite; it's the Thai wives who drag their husbands to this restaurant because the food is so much like home).    So, to see so many Thais at this restaurant tells you something about how authentic this place is.

I also like the fact that they do not make the food overtly spicy.  It is moderate/medium in spiciness; and you can add chili powder or green/red chilli sauce over your dish if you so prefer.  Highly recommended; and you'll save yourself the $900 flight ticket  to Thailand.
author: Harry C.

description:
i've been coming to this place for several years now since i only live a couple blocks away. i think it's the best thai i've had in the city so far. granted i haven't tried all that many because i really love this place.
they were voted best pad thai in the city, which i have to admit is really good although i haven't had it since i discovered their pad see ew (with beef). it's REALLY f*ing good!.. and they have these little deep fried appetizer thingies with minced chicken and veggies, served with that yummy cucumber and red onion salad. the servers are cute and friendly. unlike the stuck up little twats at osha.
author: Mister F.

description: Thai House Express is my corner Thai place (I'm lucky enough to live right here in the Castro) and I eat there way too many times to mention. The food is terrific: maybe not the best thai I've ever had, but close to it. I recommend the yellow curry chicken (I forget the name) There's always a crowd of good looking people.
author: Scott G.

description: In a city with an abundance of good Thai Food, I go far and wide and out of my way to order from Thai House Express. The walk amongst some unsavory characters (more tender than Nob) is well worth it. Easy, quick, fresh and delicious. Love the spring rolls, interesting and crispy, no mush or bland. Wide Noodles with Garlic, curries, Yum Yum. The staff will let you know the real deal on what's good if you ask. Take their suggestions and you definitely won't be dissappointed. Sit or pick up!
author: Vanessa J.

description: Had some great green curry here. The friend I was with who lived in Thailand for a few years said it has the subtle flavors that are typically lacking in other restaurants green curries.
author: Mike P.

description: Yellow curry chicken was only yellow curry sauce, chicken that was pink/brown not white like I like it and 2 small slivers of potato.  I could have overlooked the chicken if the dish came with more veggies or at least more potatoes.  The sauce itself was pretty good.  Overall I found this place to be disappointing.  I did get cat-called on my way there, though, and it's been awhile since that's happened.  No doubt this guy was on his way from or to the meth clinic.  Oh well, I'll take it.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
It was a lazy sunday afternoon. I had enjoyed a nice afternoon movie..shrek 3...with fellow yelper jesse. Afterwards, he told me I must check out this thai restaurant. He was not wrong. We arrived to a very scary looking location but once we got inside..it was amazing. A very chic little restaurant hidden away in the city. 
The meal began so quickly and I was very surprised. I let jesse order for me cuz I had no idea what to get. Everything sounded great. The food arrived quickly and was every bit as delish as it smelled. I, of course, was talking jesse's ear off and so the meal lasted forever. 
The service wasnt great. It wasnt bad but they didnt go above and beyond. I did have to wait awhile for refills and so I was a little annoyed for having to wait. But the food and quickness more than made up for it. 
There was even a show with the meal. I was able to see a transvestite, a crack whore and a man who was yelling at himself. It was quite a show and free with the meal. 
I would recommend coming here for a sunday lunch and stay for the show. Its well worth it.
author: Adam B.

description: Now this is what you call good thai food. Their name may say express, but when you taste their food, it sure doens't seem to be rushed.
author: David M.

description: #42 Kao Soy = delicious.  The yellow curry was perfect over the egg noodles, excellent creaminess.  Downsides: I wish the chicken had been more tender, and the rice paper rolls (#2) were good but not my fav.  Overall, though, the kao soy hit the spot so well that it deserves my four stars.
author: Melinda C.

description: I lived and worked in Bangkok for two years. I visit the Kingdom 3-4 times a year. I consider it, the people, and the cuisine my own in many ways. So I'm always looking for authentic (and not too expensive) flavors and experiences that will take me back ..... I've been to about a dozen Thai places in the city and I'm ever expanding (there must be 50 or more) and one dish that sets some apart is Kao Soy - northern Thai noodle soup.  Thai House express gets the flavors right.. although I think the spice level is made for us farang.  I prefer that the chicken be bone in the way it is done in northern Thailand  - the skin on drumstick is quite tasty. Here it is cut pieces of chicken that are a bit dry but nevertheless, the flavors are quite nice.   Service was quick... and I always know I'm eating in the real deal if there is a prominently displayed picture of the reigning and past monarchs of the Kingdom.  Thai House express will get my repeat business. I am anxious to try many of the standard dishes included those from the northeast (Esan) part of the country.
author: Anthony B.

description: Not a big big fan of Thai food, but I used to eat here almost everyday for lunch after work with my friend. Decent prices, tasty dishes.
author: kristin e.

description: Seriously, I have never been disappointed with Thai House Larkin...ever...and I frequent this place every week. The food's great, there's hardly a wait for the food and never usually a wait for a table unless it's a crazy busy friday or saturday. Also, you can't beat the price for such yummy food. The only thing that sucks is that it's in a crumby neighborhood and if they leave the windows open, you can smell cigarette smoke during your dinner.
author: Maureen B.

description: When I say spicy, I mean spicy. I should be sweating and reaching for tissues to blow my running nose. Sure, it's not a pretty sight, but it's how I like my food dammit. Thai House Express definitely delivers in the spicy department. Everything I've had is good (but I have only eaten Tom Yum soup and vegetarian dishes, so I can't vouch for the meat). It's super fast too, and open reasonably late (midnight). Definitely go here for quick dinner, but if you want it hot, don't forget to bring your Kleenex.
author: Rebecca H.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by this place. With the word "express" in the name I was expecting bland, greasy, and bad "fast food" type of Thai food, but luckily that was not the case! The prices are reasonable and the food tasted as good as some of my favorite Thai food restuarants in LA and the Bay Area. Even though we had a huge party of 20+ people, the service was great and all the dishes came out roughly on time. If I'm ever in the area again I'll stop by this place.
author: Will M.

description: Thai house express is great if you: a) like thai food  b) like fast service c) feel comfortable meandering in the gulch and d) want good food at a reasonable price. My wife and I constantly visited for thier Tom Kha Ghai, Pad Thai, Crab Noodles, and thier green curry or the yellow. Great food in a land of many good restaurants.
author: J B.

description: This is one of my favorite Thai restaurants.  I have not been disappointed with anything I've ordered here.  I'm a noodle lover though, so that's what I'll usually order.  When I want to eat rice, I like to get the Gai Grapow (Basil Chicken) and kao pad poo (crab fried rice).  Some of my other faves are the naam moo, gui chai, and som tum poo (crab papaya salad) which I usually pair with fried chicken and sticky rice...YUMMERS!  Downfall...it's sooooooooo hard to find parking and the neighborhood is not so pleasant (smells like pee).  Try it though, it really is good.
author: Sandy J.

description: I have had some seriously amazing meals here. Their pad thai is the gold standard for what it should taste like in my book. The curries are all excellent and some other random dishes I have had here have all been worthwhile. It kind of annoys me that this place is in the middle of the TL because that means no parking and crackheadz in traffik... I even wandered out of the Castle on new years and got the beef jerky appetizer that is so damn good.
author: Sven S.

description:
this place is awesome.  waiters are really nice,  the food is super tasty and service is quick - what more can you ask for at $5.99??

at any rate, i still drool over their shrimp paste fried rice and braised pork over rice..  drools..  i think i might have to drive up to SF just for thai house express - it's that good.  watch out when you ask for extra spicy, make sure you have a strong stomach because your digestive system will not like you the next day - speaking out of experience here (and i'm thai).
author: Mon C.

description: Hands down for the chicken and rice.  #44.  Ok so maybe my girlfriends and I might be a tad obsessed.  But nothing beats steamed chicken over garlic rice with extra sauce.  Ok so maybe we just go there for the sauce but we do need to rice to go with it so we don't look crazy.  Well that isn't the only thing that we order when we go.  We do order another item like the larb (its a salad) with chicken.  Beware though if you can't eat spicy ask for mild.  Their medium is pretty kicking.  Even though they didn't have the chicken and rice that last time I was here.  They still get 5 stars.
author: Allison T.

description: I go to this place every Sunday and it is my favorite thai restaurant.  I am not sure who the taller server is but he is always friendly and my order is perfect everytime.
author: Justin H.

description:
