I keep going back for the consistently good, if not great, Thai food.  Really 4.5 stars here.  They have a few more inventive dishes than most places, and the execution is superb.  I particularly love the combo seafood soup, duck salad, pad see yew, and any crab special they may have.  I've only been 4 or 5 times, so I still haven't tackled half the menu.

My only HUGE gripe is that the staff has ZERO understanding of timing.  If you're like me, and want your dishes staggered so as to create courses, then make sure you order them one at a time.  Otherwise you're bound to get your soup after your noodle dish, with your "appetizer" of chive cakes somewhere in the middle.   Don't even try to tell them everything at once, asking them to space things out, thinking that this will happen.  Trust me, I've tried it.  To my dismay, the waitress went to the kitchen (which you can see from the dining room) and proceeded to call out the entire order, which as usual showed up in a jumbled mess of plates on the table, all out of order.  OK, so I'm a little OCD about this, but I like to enjoy things one or two at a time, and with correct temperatures, etc.  They don't understand this concept, so to counteract, you have to literally order one thing at a time, and fight to keep your menu.  But once you have this down you're set.

Oh yeah, and remember, spicy means SPICY!  I love spicy, and usually just go with "medium" here knowing that I can add spice in one of 3 different ways with the condiments.  However, the last salad I asked for "medium" burned holes in my tongue, while the pad see yew "medium" was super gringo non-spicy.  Hmmmmmm.
author: Pedro, aka Burgundy M.

description: We ate here twice last week, and it was great both times.  The restaurant always seems to be pretty busy, but the service never flags--go figure.  The food is very fresh and just more lively than a lot of other Thai restaurants, and the selection definitely goes beyond the norm.  The duck larb was fantastic, noodles with crab also terrific, even the pumpkin curry was great--the typical coconut curry but invigorated by the addition of pumpkin.  The waitress convinced us to order a roti (fried crepe) with ice cream for dessert, which was the perfect ending.  It's low-key and a bit noisy, but Thai Express is definitely a winner.  I hope I get to eat here twice this week too....!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Wow.  Thai House Express was a huge disappointment, and probably one of the worst Thai food experiences I have had for a while.  How can this place have earned a 4-star average?  My friend ordered #47: Kao Pad Ka-Na Pla Kem (Fried rice with egg, salted fish, and Chinese broccoli), and I ordered #61: Sukiyaki (soup version).  After one bite of the Kao Pad Ka-Na Pla Kem, my friend was already groping for spices.  Turns out the fried rice was too bland, the Chinese broccoli overpoweringly bitter, and the salted fish gag-inducing.  She literally spent the next 20 minutes separating the Chinese broccoli and bits of salted fish from the rice, bit by bit.  And after this exercise in culinary archaeology was over, she just ate the rice, adding more and more spices to each progressive bite.  Skeptical, I took a bite just to try to prove that she was being too picky, only to discover that she was absolutely right.  I had to close my eyes and go to a happy place.

As for my Sukiyaki soup, I thought that I had mistakenly ordered #200: Bowl of Pink Vomit.  It smelled faintly like turned fish, but I hunkered down and started to eat.  The flavor was predominantly sweet with a bit of sourness.  But there was no underlying savory body, no umami.  It felt like I was eating a bunch of seafood boiled in Thai ketchup.  The one-dimensional flavor got old fast.

I'm still flabbergasted by our experience.  Don't know if the chef was having an off night, or the dishes we ordered are supposed to taste bad, but I know that even if this place somehow got up to a 5-star average, I would never visit it again.
author: Durian Y.

description: Super yummy and spicy. Everyone at the table was happy and satisfied. Pad ke mao was good, gingery tofu stir fry thing was good, egg rolls were flaky, and I'm giving extra points for having the rarity kao soi on the menu. Service was super quick and they were open late. 5 stars.
author: Erin M.

description: Had been meaning to try this place for a while since a Thai friend of mine said its her favorite in SF. Tried the pad-kee-mow, the braised pork leg over rice, pumpkin tofu curry, and a beef dish. Pad kee mow plenty spicy and tasteful. I loved the braised pork... moist and savory, meat fell apart with a fork, and something different from what you may have at another Thai restaurant in SF. All that for $20 a head, I'd have to say a satisfactory experience.
author: Lorenzo C.

description: I'm not afraid to say that Thai House Express is my favorite Thai restaurant in the Bay Area. I've been there with Thai friends, and they all tell me that this is as authentic as it gets. There are no frills at Thai House Express, but the food is fantastic and very affordable. I love their tom kha gai, their curries are really good too. The catfish salad is pretty good, as is their green papaya salad. Don't miss their desserts, especially the fried banana with ice cream. On top of that, the service is very friendly and efficient. Great lunch spot as well if you get a dish over rice. I like this venue better than the newer one on Castro.
author: David S.

description: Went here for lunch with some friends who said that this was great thai food. Maybe my expectations were too high, but it was sort of a let down. I ordered to black bean eggplant dish that I usually get a thai restaraunts. It was just OK. Nothing too memorable. I heard a few complaints from some of my friends who have been there before, so maybe they got a new chef?
author: Jenica M.

description:
Finally, a thai place that will give me "extra spicy" without the are-you-sure? look.

Rice plates are very reasonably priced. Big portions. Delish.

Update 5/08. Tried the pumpkin curry and it wasnt good as other dishes. The pumpkin wasnt as tender as I've had it. Osha can make this dish better.
author: Retired B.

description: SF cheap eats doesn't get better than this!  Clean, quick and fantastic food!  I love this place.  Service is always friendly.  I've never ordered a dish that I didn't like.  Some of my favs include any of the noodle soups, pad thai, and red beef curry.  The only down side is that Thai House isn't in the best hood.  I'd suggest parking close to the restaurant and exercising a bit of patience when finding parking.  Otherwise, it's a gem!
author: FoodJunkie S.

description: Well, it's fast.  I took the yellow curry chicken and pad see ew - yelper favorites - to go, and they were both fine (i prefered the curry, myself).  Flavor was OK - not great - but I appreciated the fact that the no frills dishes came quickly and seemed a little less greasey/ fatty than the same stuff would be at other Thai places of this ilk (Osha).  Kitty-korner from the Ha-Ra so you can pop over, sip a whiskey and hear 'the history of the world according to an alcoholic' while you wait (but you won't wait long, so drink up!).  Open late.
author: Ryan W.

description: Consistently flavorful, speedy, friendly and cheap. This place is my default when I don't want to cook, and I want left-overs for lunch.
author: Heather M.

description: I loved this place.  Everything I tried was delicious, including what my friends ordered.
author: Tanya P.

description: Food good, service good, pad kee mow good, all really good. GO!
author: Rikki D.

description: Best Thai Food in SF, bar none.  Hell, it's almost better then Thailand!
author: Antichris E.

description: I recently ate here, and was severely disappointed. The restaurant has changed ownership and it shows via the lack of quality and flavor of the food. Dishes with peanut butter sauce are not to be drowned in it, and soups are supposed to have flavor. In short, too many other great Thai eateries in this area so spend your money wisely somewhere else. A shame considering they used to be one of the best.
author: Kenny G.

description: 2.5 until I try more dishes. One of my litmus tests for good Thai is the quality of the Pad Ma Kuer (eggplant, basil, bell pepper + chicken or pork or beef)... mine had good flavor but overall the dish was way too greasy. So greasy that it would have behooved me to be drunk eating it and therefore the stomach wouldn't be taking the express train to Heartburn. Hubby's won ton soup was actually pretty good. Again withholding stars until I can try more but on first impressions, meh.
author: Genevieve R.

description: Love the Pork Leg Stew, the Thai House Noodle, the Fried Bannanas and Ice Cream, the Beef Ball Soup, and the Tender Beef Stew.  I also love the spaciousness of their restaurant compared to other Thai Restaurants in my neighborhood.
author: Aimee G.

description:
Absolutely the best Thai I've had in San Francisco. My new roommate wouldn't believe me and kept exploring other places, until I brought some food home from THE.

He was blown away!

The coconut milk soup with the fun little mushrooms is amazing and a must to start every meal! The decor is hip, the waiters are young, and a good place to chill without feeling terribly rushed.
author: jacobe ..

description: Another one of my Thai favorite restaurants. It's about the same to me as Marnee Thai, but not as expensive. I especially like how they have this common dish, "khao man gai" that's served in Bangkok, Thailand, but hard for me to find in a lot of Thai restaurants.
author: Pudgy G.

description: Love their food!  I like their fish curry with noodles, others may not like it because of the smell but it's very tasty, their shrimp paste fried rice is soo good too but they don't always have it.  Most all the dishes I've eaten there are right on.  One of my favorite Thai restaurants in the city
author: Chibinko -.

description: Ate here last night,  and had the Gang Dang = veggies, pork and red curry.  It was very tasty and perfectly spicy.  My girlfriend had the pineapple fried rice and she really enjoyed it also.  Portion sizes were plentiful and I was happy with the meal.  We had a couple of Singha's to cool off the spiciness and left with smiles on our faces, and our bellies full.   I would definitely go back.
author: Vinny M.

description: I've eaten here only a few times, but I left happy and full each time. You are seated right away and the waiter promptly brings you menus and water shortly after. Two items that I frequently get are the five spices duck noodle soup with flat rice noodles and the kao pad goon-chiang (fried rice with Chinese sausage, egg, carrot, dice green bean, and onions). The items on the menu are very reasonably priced and the portions they give are very generous. I almost always have left overs! For drinks, I usually order a Thai iced tea (sometimes it's a little too sweet) or fresh coconut juice, which is absolutely delicious. The coconut juice tastes exactly like juice straight out of a fresh coconut. Also, they include thick slices of coconut in the juice, which you can eat after!
author: Jonathan C.

description: This has been my goto Thai in the city for 3+ years.  I don't know what happened, but something changed recently.  The last three times I have ordered have let me down.  Big changes in the dishes.  Ga Prow Gai now doesn't get made with ground chicken.  Sliced instead.  Sauce, flavor, spiciness is all different for the worse.  Possibly a change in staff and/or ownership?  Regardless 3 strikes and now I need to find a new place to replace this on my list.
author: K B.

description: Do you need Thai food NOW?? Well you're in luck - just head on down to Thai Food Express. The food is tasty and inexpensive and the staff is friendly. "But I'm really drunk," you say? No problem Thai food Express is open late and they serve drunks too - unless you cry when you're drunk. Then you need to go home - for real.
author: J F.

description: go there often to order  basil chicken, they seem to not care about the way a customer wants the basil chicken! I told so many ppl  about this place and they treat ME like crap ! All about eat pay and go!  They are very negative and should take my freaking order right this is the second time they didn't add a hint of chili paste to my basil chicken after asking if i want it.THE first time they made it to spicy after I ordered mild, they replaced my order mad LOOKING  at me talking in their language bad vibe, when they brought it back IT   had no spice at all an gave it TO ME  on the side! SHE SAID THEY CANT MAKE IT MILD......... Today i ordered on the phone thinking maybe if they dint see me they will get it right lmao! sure enough they added no spice, the man said, basil chicken no spice with rice i said no basil chicken mild the girl comes saying SHE MADE THE MISTAKE sorry they all looking at me crazy, ACTING LIKE THEY DID NT WANT TO FIX MY ORDER THE WAY I ORDER IT . I JUST TOLD THEM WHAT DOES IT TAKE TO GET IT MILD AND ACTUALLY BEING SATISFIED WITH IT IF IT'S NOT A OPTION DO NT ASK IF WE WANT SPICY OR MILD ! LUCKY I WORK RIGHT THERE  OR ELSE LOL! for now on imma make em deliver right! the first time they messed up she told me he can make it mild they must have new cooks lol!  no star's yeah they just for the money and dOnt need tips  ha ha roger that! put them to the test San Francisco!
author: billy b.

description: Thai express has a good reputation in our neighborhood.   No easy task considering there's lots of competition within blocks.  We've eaten there many times and experienced consistently good food.   We stopped by for a late night snack at 10 minutes to midnight.  There's a bander outside bragging about their extended hours.   Management should tell the employees about it.   They had the "closed' sign up early and were reluctant to serve us.  I think that closed at midnight should mean the time that you stop letting customers in the door not the time that you stop being polite to them.
author: Peter O.

description: I agree with every good thing said about this place. They make the best yellow curry in SF and man, if you want spicy - they'll make your world go around! I just wished the rice serving was a bit more in quanitity. And yes, they have about a 100 things on the menu so write down what you had, and try something else next time.
author: Sav B.

description: Meh indeed. Steamed chicken never looked this unappetizing. I guess I should be happy they at least had a steamed option on the menu, but when it comes with so much dark meat and layers of fat, I'd rather pass.
author: Jason B.

description: This place has the best Thai in my opinion. They have a lot of great dishes on the menu. The service is indeed fast. And the food is delicious! I had been craving Thai and came here and was not disappointed. So yummy! It's also a great place to go before a show at the Great American Music Hall, as it's just a couple blocks away or so.
author: Barbs J.

description: I haven't been here in a little while, but it's one of my favorite cheap Thai places in my hood. The red curry and the pad kee mao are always delicious. The Praram is pretty fabulous too.
author: Kelly L.

description: I'm guessing this is closer to Thai fusion than pure Thai food from the reviews I've read?  During my visit, my friend really wanted to eat here, since she raves about how good the pad see-ew (sp?) is.  We spent 15 minutes driving around searching for parking because she was that determined to eat there.  We finally got in, she ordered her usual pad see-ew, and I got the pork shoulder over rice.  Oh man, I've had some good pork shoulder, and that was right on par with the best I've had.  They gave me a little too much skin and fat, but that's no big deal.  The pork was cooked through so thoroughly I can imagine it just fell off the bone, and the flavors were spot on.
author: Geoff Y.

description: I stumbled into this gem one night and decided to get take-out on a lark...I'm so glad I did because the food is pretty tasty!  My favorite is the Pad See Ew
author: Femita J.

description: To date this is the best Thai food I have ever had. Great noodles, great everything.
author: Stephen W.

description: Yum!!!!  Best Pad Thai ever.  Very good calamari with garlic sauce.  Extremely fast and friendly service.  Nice, big space.  Highly recommended.  I can't wait to go back and try some of the more adventurous dishes.
author: Ester C.

description:
First time I ever tried salmon curry, OH SO GOOD!
If you like spicy go for the GREEN CURRY..you have a choice of green or red.  The seafood fried rice..to die for.  They're very friendly, and they recognize you.  You should try their calamari..not like italian..soooo goood!  Their pompei fish is pretty good tooo.
author: Janet W.

description: When you think of Thai food.This place is a solid find for Thai in the                   neighborhood.The food is fresh  and the price are right.The curries are great and the service is also excellent.
author: Rujira S.

description: Came with a friend. Ordered the pad kee mao which was unsatisfactory at best. It was both bland yet spicy at the same time. Quite an achievement.
author: Andy L.

description: The food was very tasty, the crispy pork was great. Wasn't too loud, but also wasn't a very quiet place. They didn't come to refill our waters once. At a place with spicy food, that's a big minus 1.5 stars. Our group of six was assessed an extra "service charge". Which might be okay, but the bill was completely unreadable, so until we asked, we had no way of verifying that we'd been charged the appropriate amount. So minus 1 star for that.
author: Tyler E.

description: Thai house is really good not to sweet Thai food. It's my favorite place in the city for Thai food. I like the beef jerky and the tom kha gai. It's the closest to my favorite Thai restaurant in Houston. This is where my Thai friends eat. Although, they were raised here, but so was I and I AM an authority on Pakistani food. So, yes, this place is good and cheap for dinner but not so much cheap for lunch.
author: mazzy s.

description: Thai house is delicious, and open late, I love the mango and sticky rice at 1am. You'll never have to settle for Sparky's again, that is, unless you want to.
author: Stellah D.

description: Hands down - this is the best Thai restaurant I've ever been to.  The soup is incredible.  The dishes are even more so.  Everything is perfect!  Even the tea!!  This is a great place to take a group of friends and is easy on your wallet.  Everything is very inexpensive and the service is great.    I live in San Bruno and make the drive to eat here at least four times a month.   So yummy.
author: Cyan C.

description:
When you walk in, it feels oddly like a cafeteria - there's the big kitchen in the back left, a large wall of art in the back right, and a big space in the middle with basic seating.  Clearly functional, and not much more than that.
But the food is cheap!  Curries are about $7, and the most expensive of the specials tend to be about $13.  I had a 3-flavor salmon, which struck me as more of a Chinese flavor than Thai - the sauce was very strong (fairly tasty, but strong), and it entirely overpowered the mound of crispy basil, which was very sad because I absolutely love the taste of basil.  It's one of the reasons I'm a Thai food addict.  On the plus side, though, it was basically an enormous, tasty slab of salmon which was very cool.  I've been too many places where the "green curry with salmon" is green curry, with perhaps 4 small bits of salmon, if you're lucky.  This was like 1/2 pound of salmon, on a plate, covered in crispy basil, and smothered in a rich sweet/hot/acidic sauce.  You get your money's worth.  I need to go back and try the curries.
The Thai iced tea was also quite pleasantly large.
author: Don H.

description: I've made some good headway into the world of thai food in the last 2-3 years, and I still haven't found a thai place in the bay that does spicy minced beef/chicken with basil as well as Thai House Express...word!!
author: Cliff C.

description: This place is terrific!  The food is delicious and inexpensive.  Try the Larb Pla (catfish salad).  It's spicy and definitely new culinary experience, at least for me.
author: Margaret C.

description: Absolutely delicious, and really fairly priced.  The staff is nice, and the place is clean-a very good choice for Thai food lovers and newbies as well.
author: asia c.

description: Fastest Thai EVER!  By the time I put on my shoes and walk over from my apartment a block away my order is ready.  The service is good,  the decor is very Y2K modern (which isn't a bad thing in this case), and the food is GREAT.  It's the best Thai in the area,  and that's saying something.
author: Matt G.

description: This is the place that I'd go to if I'm craving super spicy, 'tastes like mom made it' Thai fried noodles or spicy salad. The kind of food you want when you're out drinking with friends,  going to a show, or just want a casual no-frills bite to eat. The Pad Kee Mao (drunken noodle), Larb, and Yum are great. Authentic, low service, thai style diner/noodle joint.
author: Sirima S.

description:
this is one of my friend's favorite Thai place. after hearing him going on and on about, last night i finally dined here [before a show at Great American - very convenient]. 

pumpkin currys w/chicken = so, so good. savory yet sweet. the curry is thick, has a nice body, and full of flavor but not overwhelming. lot of chicken!  

pad thai = it was pretty standard. they use a slightly thicker noodle, and it wasn't runny which was a plus [for me]! the shrimps were small though. oh, no crushed peanuts! 

definitely, to add to my list of affordable good Thai place to eat in SF!!! 
[Osha down the street is still my favorite though] 

the only thing is that you're seat really close to your neighbors so you lose a bit of your personal place and have to a little cautious when swing your arms around.
author: Jocelyn T.

description: Everything is pretty good on the menu and the service is not bad as well.  Naked lady, crab fried rice, fried catfish, and tom yum goong are really good but spicy.
author: Mary L.

description: I think this place is awesome, one of the best "quick bites" in an area filled with great places for quick bites. It has a vast menu, offers speedy service, and is close to a number of bus lines. I love going here before a show at the Great American Music Hall or a movie at the AMC on Van Ness. Try the crab cakes!
author: Lucky G.

description:
the good is pretty tasty here.. very close to the movies..  a good spot to eat at if you don't want mel's or tommy's.

we used to eat here all the freakin' time.  for some reason amc 1000 van ness and the thai house was the ritual of my group of gf and the bf of ours who have come and gone, and the ones who still remain...

i like their pad see yew and the sticky rice w/mango.  mmmm mmmm mmm
author: Sheri N.

description:
We went to Thai House Express last night for a dinner meeting. The place was popular but there was no wait.  It wasn't too noisy so we could talk and hear ourselves. There were four of us with good appetites and we ordered family style.  We ordered the papaya salad with dried shrimp, beef panang curry a la carte, hot and sour coconut soup with tofu, and Thai House Noodles and steamed rice.  All medium spicy. After the meal, I think I could have done with hot spicy. The papaya salad is always one of my favorites.  I had hope for a little more tartness in the salad, but we gobbled it up like we didn't have anything else on the table.  Peter, the one who recommended we come here, told us to try the Beef Panang Curry. These are delicious soft chunks of beef stew meat in a very rich sweet red curry wit basil.  And they didn't skimp on the beef either.  I continously ladled the curry on to my steamed rice, forgetting that I'm supposed to be low-carbing it. The coconut soup was pretty good and I would order it again with chicken.  The Thai House Noodles were clear vermicelli noodles served under ground meat and veggies.  Pretty good and good noodle consistency, but not as spectacular as the beef panang curry. Overall, the portions were good, and the food very good.

The only annoyance was that the table seemed too small for the serving plates and everything else on the table. The wait staff was prompt and nice.  The restaurant was clean and they were quick to clear off our table after our meal (which I like).  Water service was good and no one had to ask for refills at all!  I would go back again to try some other delicious yummies!
author: Betty L.

description: Best Thai food in the city. That's all I can say and all I need to say.
author: Janel A.

description: Yes, their food is great and following other people's advice I went for a mild on the spice scale and that was good.  Thai iced coffee - yummy.  Food really comes out lightning fast.  Roti dessert with Thai ice scream.  Yes, scream, it's that good...not just cream.  You're on a bit of a sugar high afterwards, but it's what keeps you bobbin' past the bums outside.
author: David B.

description: Ode to conciseness.  We stumbled to this place because it was the least ghetto place on the street.  Because we were in a rush, I didn't even look at the menu except to say to the waiter that I wanted Pad Thai (every Thai restaurant must serve that).  It was 8:30 and movie started at 9:00, so as soon as the Pad Thai came, we got take out boxes and the service was very understanding about everything and were quick about it, too.  We ate the Pad Thai in the movie theatre.  It was okay, but a little too sweet for my liking.  Is this the fairest review of the place?  Probably not.
author: David Y.

description:
I used to really like this place, and have gone here (and the one in the Castro) many times.

Why 2 stars? Two of four dinner mates found hairs in their dishes tonight. I was trying to impress someone, and this put a huge damper on the evening. These were two different dishes, so it's not likely they shared a single contamination source.

Please use hair nets.
author: jj w.

description: Currently my favorite Thai restaurant. Always busy whatever time I go, which is always a good sign. Cheap, fast, good food. My dining companion thinks they have the best beef noodles and boat noodles in the city. I usually get the curries but now and again get the noodles - tasty but somewhat greasy. I guess the oil is what makes it delicious. I just tried the vegetarian chive cakes, which were piping hot and crispy. I frequently order the green beans and tofu, and the green beans are almost always perfectly cooked - crispy but still fully cooked.
author: Amy E.

description: This is our favorite Thai restaurant.  Fresh, fast, delicious and inexpensive food.  Always consistent and great service for such yummy dishes. We have lunch there at least once a week for nearly the last  year and have tried  just about everything.  Absolutely the best place to have a freshly cooked lunch when you're pressed for time. They'll accomodate your preference on degree of spiciness and will even adjust the fat content of their signature Pork Leg Stew.  Most Asians love the fatty pork is what we're told. We've had it both ways and prefer the leaner meat. The portions are also generous.  We love it and highly recommend it!
author: Jane F.

description: My favorite dish here is the Pork Leg Stew Noodle Soup.  To me its the best noodle soup you can get in San Francisco.  Better than any Pho, Ramen or duck noodle soup I've had.  You even get to choose what noodle you want with it.  I usually get thin egg noodles, but whatever floats  your boat.  The pork is reasonably tender but the broth is so flavorful that everything else is an accompaniment.  I'm not sure I can describe what the flavor is like but its just a deep flavored broth that's not thick like Ramen but much more intense than any Pho I've had.  Its good stuff on a foggy day.
author: David C.

description:
thank god for friends in the know.  and yelp, of course, which is like the most knowledgable (but sometimes schizophrenic) friend ever.

one of my foodie pals dragged me to thai house express after we'd ODed on yuppiedom at bar americano.  from $14 glasses of champagne along the embarcadero, straight into the loin - that's why i love san francisco!!

we had the friend whole pompono (divine!), chinese brocolli with salt cod, beers, braised pork, and a mixed veggie dish.  everything was fantastic, and they even have brown rice.  LOVE!  

did i mention it's wicked cheap?
author: nicole l.

description:
3.25 stars

definitely good for late night, they close at 2 a.m.

they have a pretty extensive menu, don't forget to check the specials board (hanging up on the wall near the kitchen).  

i especially like the calamari, and fish cake appetizers.  so tasty!  i usually get something kinda lame like spicy chicken with basil, but that's what i like!  :)
author: Wendy S.

description:
So my friend Jas and I were on our merry way to the Tenderloin for what reviewers were calling "the most authentic Thai food in San Francisco." We had Doris Day parking karma and found a spot 20 feet away on Larkin when we arrived.

The decor is really non-descript but the smells coming from the kitchen were fab. After reviewing many ChowHound and Yelp reports, here's what we ordered from the blogs recos: Kao Ka Moo (Stewed Pork Leg over Rice), Shrimp Paste Fried Rice and the House Special Pumpkin Curry with Chicken (which was a special that day).

Stewed Pork Leg Over Rice (3 stars out of 5)
Overall, I enjoyed this subtle dish. It's very similar to the one my mom makes except she cooks with pork hock (read pigs feet). Me thinks this is really an Ethnic Chinese dish as it's prevalent in Chinese deli places all over SoCal. It is stewed with dark superior soy, ginger, garlic, sugar and star of anise. The skin has a deep complex flavor with that smokey soy and unmistakable flavor that only comes from star of anise after countless hours of stewing. It's served over rice with a clear broth that's been mixed in with the stewing liquid. The issue I have is that the broth was bland and really dumbed down the stewing liquid since they added too much of it. But I think I'm hardcore cause the version my mom makes is 10 times more flavorful and would give mainstream eaters an aneurysm.

Shrimp Paste Fried Rice (2.5 stars out of 5)
OK, maybe I'm a food snob but I was disappointed with this dish because the name is misleading. Jas and I both agreed that the quality of the ingredients were really fresh and it was nicely presented. However, we could not taste any hint of Shrimp Paste in this dish! It was good "Shrimp Fried Rice" but where's the friggin' paste? And it was a tad greasy to boot (unforgiveable for good fried rice). Shrimp Paste is one of those things that if you cook with it, your entire apartment building will know because it will smell like you picked up a beached whale and it's been sitting in your hot humid apartment for a good month or so. But oh, the taste! It's one of those Stinky Tofu experiences - if you can relate. If you can't, ping me and I'll take you for some stinky tofu. Next time, if we order it, we'll ask for extra shrimp paste. I think it was dialed down for the Western audience. 

Chicken Pumpkin Curry (2.5 stars out of 5)
I never had Pumpkin Curry with so much Lemon Grass before. And they used white meat. Sorry, we don't know any "authentic" Asian restaurant that uses white meat. The meat was so dense, overcooked and fat-less that it just can't absorb the flavor of the sauce or curry.  I think it was fine but OSHA's version is much better. Smokey and complex with a million grams of fat from the coconut milk. I'm not a huge OSHA fan unless I'm expensing it but they do a couple of dishes really well like the Pumpkin Curry and Crispy Pork.

OVERALL:
I think this is a good Thai restaurant. They have some dishes that just do not exist on other menus but I think it's very overhyped. If I lived in the Tenderloin, I would totally come here for quick take-out.
author: Tai K.

description: the food is just ok in this place the portions of the appetizers are super small . i was not impressed with their flavours - oh well east bay has better thai food .
author: Princess L.

description: Very good, and quick thai food. Its definitely cheap for what it is. I thought everything was delicious but maybe a little greasy.. oh well.. yum yum. Pad Thai and pumpkin curry were great!
author: K A.

description: Dank-ti-tude. Mmm Garlic Rice. Thai House Beef with some bomb green sauce. Whatever. It tasted soo good, The place is clean fast, and the service is friendly, ughhh shy away from the wine. It flat sucks. Other than that its all good!
author: neal e.

description: I'm Thai, so I should know what passes the test. Well, I'm happy to share that all of my favorite local dishes can be found at Thai House Express. Cheap, fast, yummy, and spiced the way I like it! Check out the white board for all their special dishes listed in Thai, but ask your waiter for a description. Enjoy!
author: Nim P.

description: Squatting on the corner of one of the most eclectic 1 block radius of the Tenderloin sits this great modern Thai joint. Great food, a modern and clean ambiance the defies the world outside of it's large glass windows, with prices that will make you giddy and great hours (open until midnight for your post-craw vittles) the Thai House is not to be under appreciated. Added bonus-- fun watching the indoor and outdoor peeps.
author: Rob S.

description: Not bad, actually.  It was worth the walk from Market through the Tender-jungle.
author: Matt P.

description: You are in the city, you went to see a movie and it's almost 10pm, then Thai House Express makes lots of sense
author: Alex A.

description: Very good food, even better price.  Try the Red Curry.
author: Peter W.

description: Very fast, reasonably priced. Food was spicy, but not in a way that blew away it's normal flavor. Had a variant of Pad Thai, and the dish was tasty without being too oily or heavy.
author: Jason S.

description: I've been to Thailand and really loved the food there, but I still can enjoy just about any mediocre or better Thai food here in the US. My boyfriend is a different story, though. His visits to Thailand (2-1/2 months or so total on 2 separate trips) left him so enamored of the cuisine's subtleties that he is a super-snob when it comes to Thai restaurants. So far, this place still qualifies as his fave in the city. And I think it's pretty great, too. Definitely a cut far above the average amid the ubiquitous Thai joints in this town. That makes it worthy of five stars in my book. Well, that and the freedom from arguing and/or cajoling the bf to get him to accept it as a meal destination. This place has great food and supports relationship harmony. (Sure hope that what I just read here about the chef leaving for the east bay doesn't mean the food will suffer...)
author: Michael M.

description: I like this place.  The food arrives fast and is tasty.  The portions are large and it's not expensive.  If I'm ever in the neighborhood again and have a craving for Thai food, I'll eat here.
author: Naomi N.

description: The food was excellent! My only concern was that the restaurant was some what dirty. The floors were scattered with napkins and straw paper cover. . They even used wads of napkins to stop a few tables from rocking. The employees weren't that friendly, too. I had to give 4 stars for the food. They would have gotten 5 stars if the place was cleaner.
author: Damien T.

description: I have eaten a whole lotta thai food and this is by far the best and most flavorful. Fast service, cool prices.
author: Ms. Q.

description: There are Thai restaurants about every 3 blocks in my neighborhood but this is the best I've found yet.  Fast, inexpensive, terrific friendly service and extremely tasty food.  You know it's good when the place is filled with Thai people.  Try the Pad See Ew with beef or the Gai Ga Prow.  I'm not a big duck fan but they have a plum duck dish where the duck is actually deep fried in an egg batter and then served with mushrooms and other vegetables in a plum sauce.  The way it was prepared really toned down the gamey duck taste and it blended well.  Very impressive.  My mother in law specifically requests that we take her to this restaurant every time she's in town from San Diego.  Don't walk, RUN to this place!
author: Jon B.

description: Wow, I thought I was in Thailand again, including seeing the pros and tranees walk by on Larkin :-).  The food was spicy, flavorful, and so good, wish I ordered more.  Right on the corner of Geary and Larkin, make sure you face the window so you can see the interesting people walk by, never boring in the Tenderloin.  Can't pass up if you're a fan of Thai.
author: Bhavesh M.

description: Especially good thai food -- the BF is really into noodle soups with very spicy sauce, he enjoys the benefits to his sinuses. He had the five-spice duck noodle soup -- easily some of the best, most complex and savory broth I have had in SF yet. I had the shrimp-paste fried rice, which was also quite good. Excellent place for a hangover lunch or after a long day of... whatever.
author: Fred L.

description: I wouldn't say this is a destination restaurant, but it's a great stop if you're in the neighborhood. It's not a fancy place, but the food is good.
author: m t.

description:
My FAVORITE Thai restaurant in San Francisco!

Pros:
Large clean dining area with modern decor.
Amazingly fast service and food preparation.
Delicious high quality authentic spicy Thai food.
Lower prices than most other Thai places. How do they do it?!?

Cons:
None!

Try the Roti with coconut ice cream; it rocked my world. The slivers of real coconut inside the ice cream were actually warmed up. My new favorite ice cream flavor is now coconut!
author: M. W.

description: Most of the my thai friends say this is as close they'll get to their own home cooked meals. So, you know - It's gotta be good. Quick and delish!
author: Nicole O.

description:
I just picked up my food order on my way to the office. Ordered Crab meat fried rice, it said $9.99 on the menu, at least on the one posted on the Window.

I never thought about it until after, but I ended up paying $11.90 for it. Um.... I dont think tax is 19%, unless they added tip to my order for take-out. So after it sank in, I realized I got jipped, but I didn't care I was hungry. Rushed to work to dive into my meal.

Crab meat is quite scarce in the meal, not sure its worth the extra $4 to order crab vs beef or chicken, but in the end, the rice is still quite tasty. Definite perk is that it took less than 5 mins to make, so can't complain too much. And only found 2 pieces of shell in the whole meal.

Next time, will likely try a different asian themed restaurant in the area though, since there are many.
author: S. S.

description: I really like this place, but hate walking here from bart. If you take certain streets it's fine, but other streets are pretty sketchy. Anyways I really enjoy the shrimp paste fried rice. Their tom-yum goong is not as good as others. Also, if you order soup they bring it out with the rest of your order unless you ask them not to. I'll try more menu items when I get the chance. The service tends to be very good and sometimes they keep the tv on the animal planet, isn't that awesome?!
author: Ryan C.

description:
Very very good food. Only had some of the standard Thai dishes this time around. I need to try the more authentic dishes for which they are known. 

My only problem was a minor service faux pas, which was the main course and appetizers came out at the same time. With the larb coming out after all the main dishes. I attribute this to the price point and most asian restaurants seem to be afflicted by it. 

That said. I must try the more traditional thai dishes and update this review.

Update: Second time around the service was good. The larb was excellent as usual and all the other dishes were excellent as well. 5 stars.
author: Arun R.

description: I went there on a Friday at 9:15, and got seated right away.  The service was quick and the food was spicy, and I ordered it mild.  A little pricey though, so it really should be 4 and a half stars, but I can't figure out how to give a half star.
author: Thomas G.

description: SOOOO TOTALLY NOT the most authentic thai food in San Francisco! Have you been to thai land? You're trip'n Mike W. BUT!!!!! It is damn good food, and reasonably priced. The service I have had has been lack luster. It was the first place that started my love for trips to the bathroom to check out if a resto carried out it's design full spectrum. I come here mainly at night to play.... dun nuh du ruh duh ruhn!... Tranny or Tramp! You look out side and guess if the prostitute out side is a lady or a dude! It's great with a group of drunk friends... and sometimes if your lucky, you can play inside the resto with the other patrons! GREAT FUN!
author: danny e.

description: My favorite Thai place in the city.  Great, cheap food and open late.
author: Erin D.

description:
according to my three criteria thai food analysis, this place only get's 3 stars becase:
1. their pineapple fried rice is mediocre and doesn't automatically come with shrimp as well as the meat of your choice.  the shrimp should be a staple.
2. palm juice is on the menu, but very rarely in supply.  my advice is that they should remove it from the menu so that i don't go in there and get my hopes up only to have them dashed to smithereens.
3. the mango sticky rice is on point, but not enough to make up for the misses on points 1 and 2.

i do give them cool points for being conveniently located close to my previous place of employment.  honorable mention also for the television that always plays animal planet during the lunch hours and for the friendliness of the staff.

most of this review applies to their sister location in the 'stro, only they usually play tbs movies when i'm there and they are closer to all of my party spots in the castro...great for pre and post drinking munchies.
author: Lex E.

description: What a great place in a not so great neighborhood. LOVE the pad se ew noodles.  And open till midnight?? In SF???  Wow..there's something rare!
author: Shannon M.

description: Love the pork pad se ew noodles!!  Yummy.  Very good curries and you can't go wrong with some pineapple fried rice.  Have been there three times and will definitely be going back for more.
author: Andrew L.

description: This is 1 of really 2 places I head to when I want to have food that approximates what I used to get for every meal when living in Thailand.  It is pretty awesome - especially all their noodle soups.  Also, try the dry suki (short for sukiyaki) and, if you're like me, ask to replace the pickled squid with fresh.  The duck larb is another highlight.  The neighborhood is not pretty - standard 'loin.  If you avoid this 'hood, though, you will miss most of the best Asian food in SF.  Enjoy!
author: David S.

description: Their food has lots of flavor and comes out fast.  I like the beef stir fried dish with onions over rice.  Yums.  The atmosphere is nice too.  Nothing fancy -- especially considering it's the Tenderloin -- high ceilings, minimalist table design, and big windows.  Worth it.
author: Nuey T.

description: I found my dish (crispy tofu) to be excellent. The service was also extremely fast. The only reason I would give it a 4 instead of 5 is that it doesn't offer brown rice in place of white rice. This is not quite a date place (totally fine to go out with friends to, though), but also not a sketchy hole-in-the-wall kind of place.
author: Ajith N.

description: I've been to thai house a half a dozen times now, and I've never been dissapointed.  It can get a little busy on the weekends, but never that bad.  They have a good menu, and good service.  Great late night spot.  Well priced, nuff said.
author: Luke G.

description:
The final time I visited, there was an unfortunate incident there with an altercation between the wait staff and some man. I seemed that he had walked in to steal money left on a table. The staff confronted him by blocking the exit and locking the front door.

Trapped, the person starting to threaten violence by lifting a chair. Being the Tenderloin, it was just another distraction to my dinner. Even more annoying was the staff's willingness to trap all us customers with someone showing signs of violence. 

The standoff went on for 5 to 10 minutes, with the trapped customers all pretending to go about their meals, while watching the situation out of the corner of our eyes. Eventually, the police came and dealt with him, but I feel that our safety had been threatened by the staff who were more concerned about losing a few bills than its patrons. This reinforced my earlier experience of the staff being short with customers and rushing us with the bill immediately after serving us our dishes.

It would have been safer and more pleasant for all of us if they had just allowed him leave and concentrated on serving customers instead of law enforcement.
author: Lawrence L.

description: This place is good and open late. I went there the other day with my girl friend and we loved the food. Being Thai, you can really enjoy  good Thai-Thai food, if you know what i mean. We had the 5 spice duck over rice and the kuo mun kai (chicken over coconut/garlic rice).. Both were very good and not too expensive. For desert we had the roti with ice cream and it made me think of thailand. This place is one of my favorites and for many other thai people. If you see a  thai  resturant with Thai customers that means this place is pretty good.
author: william w.

description:
Its easy. If you want delicious authentic thai food then this is the place. If you want bland american fake thai food then head over to Basil or something like that because you wont like it here. 

I eat at this place around 3 times a week. Everything on the menu is awesome. The only negative thing I can find is that their appetizers are expensive, same price as an entree. 

I dont know if I could survive without this place.
author: Maggie X.

description:
Highly recommended!  I have been here several times and have not once been disappointed.  The food is great.   I have ordered several items on the menu and not once been disappointed.  (Bonus:  The know how to use the spiciness factor all Thai food should have),

I could easily eat here every night!  And the service is also speedy without compromising the quality.
author: Lara F.

description:
Food isn't too bad but the for the price they charge and the amount food they give = rip off.

Not recommended if you are hungry ... you will be grabbing a bite afterward.
author: John S.

description: Thai House Express is a good alternative to Osha. The staff is friendlier and the food is just as good.
author: UT V.

description: If you love Thai food, as I do, you must experience this hole-in-the-wall dig.  It is unquestionably the best Thai I've ever enjoyed.  Forget the neighborhood (tender-nob), the atmosphere (bare necessities), just delve into the most fantastic food and you'll be as hooked as I am.  Dishes you must try:  Duck Larb (spicy shredded duck with rice meal, onion, cilantro) Cured Pork Sausage, and apparently everyone's favorite, the pork leg stew, always available on the chef recommendations list.  I live in Sonoma and drive into the city almost once a month for this incomparable Thai fare.
author: Reese A.

description: This place is awesome.  We always come here for an authentic treat.  Great food!!  You can't go wrong with any dish.  I personally like Kao-ka-moo and Kuaw-taew-tom-yum.  It's cheap and fast (express).  Highly recommended :)
author: Pitipat P.

description:
The food was actually good, better than most places.  It was a worry because of the location.  

Bad ambiance- loud, super noisy.  You can't wind down here.  Would want to be seated by the wall and not in the middle if I went again.
author: e g.

description: this place is so delicious, my mouth is watering right now while i write this.  i am currently addicted to their minced chicken and rice in chili sauce with fresh basil and red peppers.  my roommate is addicted to one of two tofu dishes: the fried tofu dish with (i think) chili sauce and/or the tofu in peanut sauce.  friendly service.  i love the guy who works here, he's always got a happy smile on his face.  and hey, it's in the tenderloin, so it's a worthwhile adventure for sure.
author: Brooke W.

description: ok these is a great place to get a bit of thai food it's a small place, not fancey at all but the food is great try and chan pad poo it great and the thai ice tea and it's a match made in heaven
author: LON B.

description: Cheap and pretty good Thai food. The place is always busy at night and sometimes you have to wait a few minutes for a table, but it's worth it. Their service is good and the quality of food has been the same on all the occasions I have been there. You should definitely try their Tom Kha Gai soup. The atmosphere itself is quite warm, but since the place is busy it can get loud. They do have a flat screen TV if you are eating alone to distract you from your loneliness :-P.  It's a great place for dinner with a group of friends. I prefer to go there at night when the pace is full, otherwise it is a little bit chilly.
author: Natalia P.

description:
The food is generally very good. Every now and again you get something that should be better, like a plate of chicken or pork that is fatty. I've been there 7 or 8 times and keep going back because the food is good and the prices are down right silly affordable. The neighborhood could be better, but hey, it's the 'Loin... I have several Thai friends who go too, so you know it is authentic when the Thai ladies like the place. The place is clean, the service is good and fast. 

It's a solid four stars and could be five stars if it weren't for the occasional non-American standard/quality meat issue. Some folks probably love it when there is some fat on their meat, it is just not my thing. All in all, it is a great casual dining experience. This isn't anything fancy, just good authentic Thai food!
author: Steve T.

description:
I really like the food in this place.   The food comes out within minutes of ordering, nice and hot...steam rising above it.  One of my favorite dishes is the #82-sauteed eggplant with basil and your choice of meat.  The mint lemonade is refreshing as well as the thai iced tea.  For dessert, the roti has just the right amount of sweetness without going overboard and causing a diabetic seizure. 

 The only possible downside is the area....it's on the boarder of the TL (Tenderloin)... one of the more "sketchier" areas of the city, but otherwise, it's worth going to.
author: erica d.

description:
this is my jam.

want spicy? yes please. 
green curry = delicious.

quick takeout.
author: tiff f.

description:
Love, love the food here.  I'm fairly partial to the Pad See Ew, but really everything here is good.  

I work nearby and we come here occasionally for lunch.  My husband, who is Thai, couldn't possible believe I could have found a good Thai joint on my own and wouldn't come here.  UNTIL he got a recommendation from some other local Thais and they told him to come to Thai House Express.  Now everytime I have to work late, I get a phone call - - "You're bringing takeout from Thai House Express, right?"  He's sold and you should be too.
author: Kelly K.

description: This is a good thai place.  I order the curry chicken and it was spicy.  Just the way how I like it.  The shrimp is excellent.  One of the best that I've had in the city.
author: Naomi H.

description: I love this place.  The food is fan-fukkin-tastic, portions are huge and prices are even better.  I would definitely turn this place into a routine, but unfortunately, I dont wander in that neighborhood alone because im a lady and real ladies dont wander in the Loin.  Sorry all. Either way, it is an awesome place to go with friends.  Sadly, the last time I went was about half a year ago.
author: Diana T.

description: tasty food and good, fast service.  great place to stop if you need to grab dinner before going somewhere in the area.  spicy means spicy- not not spicy like it does at so many other places.  destination worthy?  not really, but good solid reliable food fast in a pleasant atmosphere.
author: Samantha W.

description: ok this is my new go-to thai food. osha was too sweet. ban sang was a little pricey. thai stick was simply not good. thai house express was just right. the food was tasty and generous, also cheaper than other places. the service was surprisingly good. food arrived with blazing promptness. waters magically became refilled without our notice. the table was cleared right after we were done eating, and the check materialized shortly after, telling us that our meal of two entrees cost only $15.
author: Dana D.

description: The food is great and atmosphere is wonderful.  The restaurant is spacious so it's very comfortable.  It could just be me but sometimes the dishes can seem oily, though probably not oilier than other thai restaurants.  Nonetheless I do recommend this restaurant!
author: Max M.

description: Love love love this place.  Inexpensive, convenient, and always hits the spot.  The po tak soup is SO SPICY.  Even the "medium spice" had me coughing with the first sip.  The next time I ordered mild, which was perfect for me since I can't handle it too spicy.  The red curry is my other fav.  This is a place I am not reluctant to try everything on the menu because I know it's going to be good.
author: LT B.

description: best cheap thai in sf. everything has been delicious and arrives super fast. pair with an evening at the shooting gallery, great american and/or olive and you'll be all set. strip clubs optional of course.
author: Domenique B.

description:
i ate here on saturday night and was sick all of sunday. my girlfriend and i shared a red curry rice plate and a noodle dish with yellow curry powder, don't remember that exact name. anyway, my girlfriend had a terrible stomach ache that night and i had one the whole night and next day. this could have been a fluke, so i give 2 stars.

the portions were large and when you say spicy, it is legitmately spicy.

so, just beware.
author: Saikat P.

description: pretty close to the real deal as far as circumstances allow. only  in bangkok along phra ahtit you would find something better. take this as a compliment....
author: bmwcafe c.

description: If you are daring enough to risk crossing TL where the creepy people out number the regular non creepy people, then go to Thai House Express.  It's worth the risk!  Unless you're a sexy female walking all by herself.  If that's the case, find a body guard (like me) to get you there, cuz the food is worth it.  I got the dish that is described as spicy pan fried noodles with dungeonous crab, egg, and green onions.  It also comes with sprouts even though it doesn't say.  It was basically a spicy pad thai without the chicken/shrimp/tofo/peanuts but with a little bit of spicy kick to it.  Needless to say, the crab and noodles were HMM HMM GOOD!  There's a pretty good looking asian waitress there too.  The place has a relaxed feel to it.  Service is pretty good too.
author: Nelson W.

description: big portions, always consistently good.  everyone i've ever taken here loves it.  their pad thai is one of the best in the city, and they actually give you lots of noodles and lots of veggies.  yellow curry is yummy and tom kha soup is uber yummy too.  open fairly late too.  service is okay, but for the price and food, it's pretty much as good as it gets.
author: Latef X.

description: Awesome Tom Kha Gai soup and pork stew. Great desserts too.
author: Josh B.

description: this is one of my favorite thai restaurants in the city.  they have the best pad thai in sf.  the spring rolls ain't bad either.  i used to like to get take-out and bring it to shows at edinburgh castle, but now that i'm old i don't go to shows as much.  the servers are nice and the food gets to you really quickly.  this is one of the things i miss about my old neighborhood...
author: Kate W.

description: The pad thai, fried rice and egg rolls were ok. Nothing was very flavorful and it was rather greasy. The portion sizes are pretty good for the price.
author: Molly B.

description: Yum!  Cheap, delicious Thai in the Loin.  Twice as delicious coming home from the bar when hanging out in the TenderNob.  Quick question though - what's up with the salted crab in the papaya salad?  Are you supposed to eat it, suck on it or push it to the side?  Next time I think I'll stick with the dried shrimp option.  The salted crab had an overt aquarium smell that's wrong or that I'm not used to (which makes it wrong in my book).  Ask for Thai-hot when the dish offers that option than balance it out with Thai iced tea.
author: Marcel C.

description: still me and my bf's favorite thai place in the city by far. pad kee mao, larb, beef salad, even wonton soup - all awesome. and they *will* make things spicy if you ask, even if you're not thai.
author: Angi C.

description: I have eaten at Thai House Express about 5 times.  The first 3x were a good experience but in the last year or two the food quality seemed to go downhill.  I tried it about a year ago and got mild food poisoning from the salad dressing.  I recently gave it another shot (remembering the food was good a few years ago) but couldn't eat more than a couple of bites of the appetizer, the main course or even the iced tea.  I asked for the check after 5 minutes with full plates.  I won't go back again.  There are so many other good thai places in SF.
author: L M.

description: I'm so happy for this place to be right down stairs from my apartment. Quick, reliable, and delicious. Good options for vegetarian visitors too. Historically I tended to stay away from Pad Thai, it being the cliche dish to order in American Thai restaurants, but I cannot get over how delicious theirs is. It brims with a perfect balance of fishy sweetness and pan seared finish. It is chok full of all the fixins including many shrimp, tofu, and chicken. Served with crispy and fresh bean sprouts on the side, it doesn't get much better. Despite my ease at gushing over this dish, the Pra Ram is still my favorite. Your choice of meat and fresh vegetables in a delicious creamy peanut sauce served with rice. The peanut sauce is sweet and spicy and the vegetables are cooked just enough so that they still hold their crunch. This is my regular. Great flavors, a huge variety, and consistency keep me coming back to this place. Don't forget to call the right location if you're taking out, they have another location too!!!
author: Thomas K.

description: this place is good and really clean compared to a lot of thai places around here. the curry is a little salty, but the rest of the other dishes were great. the area is still the TL, but i guess that's where the good food is at.
author: Katherine F.

description: this is my FAVE thai place hands down......Osha on 2nd St is prob second but this is my spot =)  LOVE curry chicken over rice and the pork leg stew over rice i always get this when i come here......the sweet rice and ice cream is a tasty dessert.......the service is always good and theres not too much of a wait on weekends.
author: Jeff M.

description: I used to go here a lot when I lived in the TL and now I miss it. I usually get the Pad Seau. It's a lot better than all the other places in SF. Osha is too oily and theres always a bunch of noodles still clumped together when you get it. I like the Pad Seau here bc they use Chinese broccoli and they put a good amount of sauce in it. It's a few cents cheaper than other Thai places and they give you more. The Phad Thai is pretty good too but pretty standard. The people are always pretty nice too.
author: JeF m.

description: went for my second time here today.  first time was great.  but today it didn't taste like the same place.  the flavor was gone ... what happened???
author: apurba p.

description: Ah, this is the place I go to when I need to satisfy my cravings for the foods of my childhood.  Yummy!  If you're looking for authentic thai food, this place is it! Beats Osha any day of the week.
author: Jewelz T.

description: This place is great, but it's in the Tenderloin. You people up on Nob Hill need to quit claiming all our TL-goodness as your own, because it isn't, so stop it.
author: Fire P.

description:
the food here is very good, 
the best noodle soup ive had in SF
author: warren a.

description: consistentlly delicious, huge menu, and open till midnight.  what more could i ask for?
author: CC C.

description: this resturant is tasty, tasty, tasty.  i love thai food and love thai house express. it's fast, funky, yummy, and probably the cleanest in the neighboorhood! we had awesome veggie drunken noodles and a great yellow curry. we were smiling while eating. and just because it as so good, we ordered dessert--mangoes with sticky rice--and we weren't even hungry. all super good and super nice waitstaff. this is my new favorite thai resturant in the city!
author: joseph j.
